**An Account of the Imperial Visitation**
*Composed by Zhou Yanzhi of Jiangdong Circuit*

Behold—
In the Kaiyuan era, when the Son of Heaven reigned in fullest glory,
He sat in lofty repose, radiant and unbound, dwelling in nonaction.
People and spirits harmonized, Heaven’s will was fulfilled;
The Grand Astrologer, consulting the auguries, inscribed felicitous omens.
The Six Ministries gleamed deep into the vernal night,
While the crescent moon, veiled in mist, bathed pavilions in light.
Golden bells hung still in the palace’s quiet halls;
The imperial mind, serene and clear, abounded in leisure.

Within the vermilion walls of Zhaoyang Palace, the night watch stood guard,
Their ears attuned to the forbidden drums echoing through the halls.
Suddenly, in a dream, the Emperor beheld a divine presence—
A thousand banners, ten thousand canopies, descending from the empty sky.
Dark clouds dispersed, revealing azure celestial thoroughfares;
The Wind Lord and Rain Master dutifully attended their posts.
Deities of Heaven, Earth, and the Watery Realms followed in procession,
Escorting with reverence, front and rear, in perfect array.
A golden chariot, drawn by dragons, stood amid the clouds,
Its august form as stately as a jade tablet held in ceremony.
Rainbow banners and phoenix canopies cast their radiant shadows,
While the faint chime of jade pendants rang clear and resonant.
Then, from the azure heights, a voice resounded—
The divine host descended to the sacred capital, halting its celestial retinue.
It declared: *"By imperial decree, I am charged with a mission,
To traverse the Nine Heavens and personally seek out the Way."*

*"I have heard of the secluded purity of Mount Lu’s peaks—
I wish to claim but a single acre to establish a palace for the Dao.
For five hundred years, the rites of supplication have flourished here,
Bestowing boundless blessings upon all living beings."*
The silver arrow marked the swift passage of spring’s fleeting nights,
And the Emperor’s tranquil slumber was broken by the cock’s crow.
Awakening amid the fragrant halls,
His eyes beheld a world of blossoms, scattered and wild.

At dawn, the imperial cortege proceeded to the Hall of Bright Radiance,
Where, seated before his assembled ministers, he spoke of the auspicious dream.
None dared to deceive the imperial ear;
They pointed to the six dreams as signs for earnest prayer.
After days of fasting and purification within the deepest halls,
The ritual procession emerged in the clarity of day.
Five-colored clouds shimmered, more vivid than in the dream,
No longer a fleeting vision of Zhaoyang Palace.

The assembled officials bowed in unison, their voices rising in acclamation.
Swiftly, the court painters were summoned to capture the scene in vermilion and azure.
Sealed decrees, bound in clay, were dispatched to the lands south of the Yangtze—
A thousand gates and ten thousand households complied in an instant.
The imperial envoys surveyed the winding paths to Mount Lu,
As couriers, spring and autumn, bore the Emperor’s prayers.
Heavenly incense and sacred petitions ascended to the Ninefold Palace,
Each yellow wrapper and seal bearing the imperial insignia.
Dragon towers and phoenix pavilions soared amid clouds and mist,
And by day, immortals were said to nest within their eaves.
Though the years of construction stretched long,
Only the towering cypress and wutong trees bore witness to the passage of time.

Each year, on the eighth month’s Lotus Assembly,
The people of Jiang and Huai hastened to offer gold and cowrie.
Not merely to suppress malevolent vapors with upright virtue,
Nor solely to pray for bountiful harvests—
The jade-green ravine roared with ten-thousand-zhang waves,
While emerald cliffs, layered like screens, stood sentinel against the flames.
Spring thunder unleashed its fury, transforming dragons and serpents;
Nightly rites summoned the stars and constellations to pay homage.

Alas! The chroniclers’ accounts are not without embellishment,
For fear of exaggeration, they may have subtly altered their brush.
Thus, the wondrous and the subtle have faded from record,
Scattered and lost, these marvels and traces of the extraordinary.
Yet we have heard of Master Xuan’s dream of the Celestial Music,
Where, holding his breath for seven days, he at last spoke of its wonders.
And of Emperor Wu of Han, who dabbled in esoteric arts,
Summoning fair maidens to his orchid-scented chambers on clear nights.
Their methods and schemes, though recorded in nearby annals,
Remain vividly clear through the ages.

How could such auspicious signs be mere coincidence?
Five hundred years have passed since that reckoning.
The supreme virtue of the Upper Realm rivals that of Tang and Yu,
While the diligence of Gao, Kui, Ji, and Qi earned the sovereign’s praise.
The Nine Yi and Hundred Yue tribes heed his every command,
As the myriad transformations turn upon the pivot of the divine.
Auspicious omens and felicitous portents arise without cease,
And the harmonious qi pervades the vast expanse of the realm.
Its ripples extend even to the lowliest creatures,
For the divine words were no empty boast—truly, they were not false.

This humble servant, narrow and unworthy, offers no grand counsel,
But having witnessed these wondrous responses, can only sigh in awe.
I pray that the historians’ brushes record this faithfully,
Leaving for ten thousand generations an eternal symbol of fortune.

*From the old records of the abbey*
*Concluded: First Scroll of the Verified Facts of the Perfected Lord of Mount Lu’s Taiping Xingguo Abbey*
*Second Scroll of the Verified Facts of the Perfected Lord of Mount Lu’s Imperial Visitation*

May the realm enjoy great peace, and may the black-haired people abound in wealth and longevity. We bear the descending gaze of the lofty heavens and present offerings of pure silk. As the season reaches the mid-point of spring, we extend our rites with solemn music. Now, as the jade prayers are concluded and the golden chimes fall silent, we once more reveal our sincere devotion and solemnly proceed with the pure rites. For its manifestation of benevolence and utility arises at the very inception of form, thus it is called "Responding to the Origin." Yet the canonical records remain incomplete, left to later generations to fulfill.

Now, with my humble virtue, I inherit the sacred legacy. Alas! The great Dao alone flourishes, and the glorious deeds of the past alone endure. We expand and illuminate its splendor, engraving fine jade with its praise. All rites are duly performed, continuing the aspirations of our forebears.

May the resonance of our utmost sincerity evoke a luminous response; may trust and blessings attend my humble self, granting me abundant fortune. May it assist our realm, enduring for a hundred million years. As we record these events in their time, may they forever remain unsung in lament.

**Memorial in Petition:**
The Perfected transcend proximity, and the great Dao defies naming. Thus, we adopt the old titles and inscribe new records. Envoys are dispatched afar to reverently announce this to the true palaces. Choosing an auspicious day through divination, we command the officials to prepare the rites. We look up, entreating the divine gaze, and bow down, reflecting our sincere devotion. May the long-neglected ceremony be fulfilled, and boundless blessings be bestowed.

**Sacrificial Announcement:**
The wondrous Dao reaches the heavens, and its beneficent works extend to all things. Its radiance shines as divine brilliance, though its form eludes description. We reverently uphold its glorious titles, solemnly performing the rites of gratitude. Our sincere devotion is present, and its illumination is timely.

**Rite of Presentation:**
In our office, we revere and exalt, daring not to neglect the duty of spiritual reverence. With utmost sincerity, we offer this sacrifice, fittingly adorned with words of luminous gratitude. Thus, we initiate the conferral of illustrious titles, devoutly extending our solemn veneration. We look up, entreating a gracious response, and pray for enduring auspicious blessings.

**Dissolution Rite:**
The supreme spirits are formless, though beyond naming, their profound virtue resides in humanity. Following the signs given, we unify in reverent display, initiating the presentation of illustrious titles. May they accept our praise and exaltation, and may felicity and blessings endure forever.

**Red Memorial for the Dissolution Rite:**
We reverently serve the exalted Perfected, initiating the proclamation of their illustrious records. Gazing toward the celestial vault, we extend our devotion within the sacred precincts. The blessings they bestow bring fortune to the people, and the pure felicity they confer extends the prosperity of our glorious reign.

**Opening Memorial for the Installation of the Jade Records:**
The Lu Peak stands majestically, a true shrine of immortals and sages. The jade records are newly inscribed, illuminating the grand ceremony of this auspicious day. As the rites conclude in celebration, we dare to present wondrous offerings. May the sentiments of all be universally fulfilled, and our sincere prayers be extended.

We humbly pray: May the supreme spirits manifest their presence, their divine insight aligning with our devotion. May the emperor’s longevity be boundless, expanding the vastness of his imperial legacy; may the three seasons bring no harm, and the people and all things flourish in peace and abundance.

**Dissolution Rite:**
This famed peak of Mount Lu is indeed the sacred abode of celestial immortals. Though its dreamlike appearance by day was first recorded in the Kaiyuan era, its renown has long resounded near and far, evoking the distant origins of the True King. In the world, he serves as an aide to emperors; in heaven, he oversees the functions of ears and eyes. A thousand years ago, his name was first inscribed in the Yuanfeng era, and four characters were initially added to his illustrious title. Now, as this felicitous time arrives, we perform these rites of veneration. Jade is engraved and inlaid with gold, its brilliance forming constellations in the heavens; from the imperial balcony, the records are proclaimed, enhancing the grandeur of rivers and mountains. As this splendid occasion unfolds, we choose an auspicious day to offer our prayers.

At that time, as the imperial plaque was conveyed by river to Xie Family Bay in Taiping Prefecture, the Dragon King of Shunji appeared upon the boat, his golden scales and jade claws over a foot long, coiling around the floral branches. The prediction was precise, and all marveled at it.

chunks.translated_text:
**First Petition for the Offering**

With reverence, I inherit the shelter of the Dao’s grace—how could I forget the devout heart of service? Humbly knocking upon the gate of Heaven, I dare to lay bare my earnest plea.

I reflect that your humble consort was born to a sagely sovereign, her blessings gathered in the Empress’s chambers. Though her years have reached the prime of middle age, each day she cultivates the nurturing of filial devotion. Favored by the August Emperor’s regard, she trembles in awe before her own small self. Thus, she offers the remnants of her adornments and cosmetics, reverently approaching the profound depths of the jade palace. Carefully following the sacred rites, she seeks to repay her modest sincerity.

May the three thousand six hundred parts of the universal offering ascend as incense to the scrutiny of the heavens above; may the one thousand two hundred years of brow-longevity extend the cultivated lifespan of the Most High. May the Empress’s palace receive the fullest of blessings, her sacred sons and divine grandsons numbering in the thousands and millions. May my aged body enjoy the fortune of health and peace, my eyes seeing clearly and my ears hearing keenly.

Furthermore, may the surplus of this grace overflow to moisten all within the Four Seas. May each year bring the auspiciousness of abundant harvests, and may the people know no fear of plague or pestilence. In this single chant, I lay bare my crimson devotion—might you deign to bestow your vast protection?

**Second Petition (Intent as Before)**

**Second Petition for the Offering**

With a heart of pure sincerity, I do not shrink from making my plea again and again. Though the vault of Heaven spans ten thousand miles, surely it will bestow its luminous regard.

I reflect that your humble consort, having given birth to the sacred person of the Son of Heaven, dwells in honor within the palace chambers. Nurtured by the joyful devotion of the myriad realms, she has indeed been favored by the private grace of the Nine Heavens. Thus, she offers the surplus of her robes and ornaments, reverently approaching the secret halls of the immortals. Presuming to extend this humble offering, she seeks in small measure to repay the gifts of life and growth.

Reverently performing the true rites for the ten cycles of the celestial realms, she prays to augment the sovereign’s years, that the divine and the human may join in the threefold acclamation of Mount Song. May the Empress’s palace receive the auspiciousness of the sun’s dream, and may her later years flow on like a river’s endless course.

Moreover, may the shelter of the Dao’s grace widely extend to all beings. May those who follow the Primordial Unity swiftly attain the wonders of ascension; may those who delight in the Buddha’s teachings swiftly enter the gate of perfect enlightenment. May the four seasons be harmonious as the jade candle, and may the hundred grains bear the golden signs of abundance.

Only by the great perfection’s compliance with desire do I dare to present these humble words. Overwhelmed by my reliance upon your grace, I trust you will deign to bestow your luminous regard.

---

**Memorial for Border Protection**

In the second year of the Longxing reign, cyclical year *jiashen*, the eleventh month, on the day *renwu* marking the new moon, the twenty-eighth day *jiyou*, your subject, the heir to the throne, humbly petitions for the pacification of the borderlands, as the court deploys troops, and beseeches the granting of unseen assistance.

Respectfully dispatching the Left Court Gentleman for Dispersing Culture, Academician of the Hall for the Diffusion of Literature, and Acting Prefect of Jiangzhou Prefecture, bestowed with the Purple Gold Fish Bag, your subject Tang Wenruo, I dare to solemnly present this offering at the Hall of the Nine Heavens’ Inspector of Responses, the Perfected Lord Who Protects and Upholds the Mandate, within the Taiping Xingguo Abbey.

I reflect that the demonic rebels encroach upon the borders, still wantonly wreaking their cruel ravages; the armies encamp in the wilds, yet have not achieved the merit of repelling them. Daring to lay forth my sincere devotion, I look up to your heroic scrutiny, hoping for the assistance of your numinous might, that no demonic visions may coil and fester.

May the offering be enjoyed.

---

**Bestowal of the Title "Divine Grace" upon the Dragon Shrine**

In the fourth year of the Jiatai reign, the first month, in accordance with a document from the Ministry of Rites, itself following a report from the Department of State Affairs, which had received a petition from the Jiangxi Circuit Transport Commission, based on an application from Jiangzhou Prefecture, which cited a memorial from Dehua County, submitted by the local scholar Liu Kui and others:

They observed that behind the Taiping Xingguo Abbey, at the Dragon Pool in the ravine of Three Mountains, the dragon’s response to prayers for rain from nearby clans and distant families has been manifestly efficacious. During the two years that Prefect Wang Rong served in office, whenever drought occurred, he prayed for rain, and the rains fell in answer. In the first year of the Jiatai reign, when no rain had fallen by the sixth month, the prefecture dispatched the Acting County Magistrate Chang Quan to personally visit the Dragon Pool, where he welcomed the sacred water and installed it in the hall for the offering. Before the rites were completed, a great rain began to fall, reviving the withered seedlings, and the year yielded a bountiful harvest. The prefecture then constructed a shrine at the Dragon Pool to honor and worship the dragon.

They petitioned for the bestowal of a noble title and shrine plaque.

The commission dispatched Shangguan Shiji, Vice-Magistrate of Yongxing County in Xingguo Prefecture, to personally investigate, and subsequently assigned Sun Ren, Vice-Magistrate of Fengxin County in Longxing Prefecture, to verify the matter. The aforementioned numinous traces indeed bestow grace and favor upon the people.

After confirming the facts, they awaited the imperial decree.

Later, the matter was referred to the Ministry of Rites for deliberation and submitted to the Department of State Affairs. Shortly thereafter, the Court of Imperial Sacrifices was instructed to deliberate. Following their report, it was noted that in accordance with the directive issued on the sixth day of the first month of the third year of the Jianyan reign, shrines demonstrating numinous efficacy were to be granted plaques first; and in accordance with the directive issued on the nineteenth day of the sixth month of the fourteenth year of the Chunxi reign, henceforth, shrines where prayers had been answered were to be reported by the circuit transport commissions in accordance with regulations, and imperial decrees were to be sought for their ennoblement.

The Court of Imperial Sacrifices noted that the transport commission of this circuit had already dispatched officials to investigate, verify, and report in accordance with regulations, and that the proper procedures for ennoblement had been followed.

Upon deliberation, it was determined that, in accordance with the aforementioned directives, the shrine should first be granted a plaque, and the appropriate decree should be issued.

Humbly requesting that the Ministry of Rites submit this to the court for an imperial decree to be issued for its implementation.

After the Ministry of Rites deliberated, it was determined that the matter should proceed in accordance with the Court of Imperial Sacrifices’ findings.

Awaiting the decree.

By imperial decree, the plaque shall be bestowed with the title **"Divine Grace Shrine."**

---

**Jade Tablet for Protecting the State and Praying for an Heir**

In the first year of the Jiaxi reign, cyclical year *dingyou*, the tenth month, on the day *jimao* marking the new moon, the fifteenth day *guisi*, your subject, the heir to the throne, humbly petitions to safeguard the continuation of the imperial line and reverently prays for the blessing of an heir. Respectfully offering incense and gifts, I have solemnly established the subtle rites, commanding twenty-one Daoist priests to perform a one-day-and-two-night **Lingbao Ritual** at the Taiping Xingguo Abbey in Jiangzhou, culminating in the dispersal of an offering of three hundred sixty parts. I have pledged alliance with Heaven and Earth, invoking the manifestation of auspicious omens.

Carefully following the ancient forms, I approach the presence of the Nine Heavens’ Inspector of Responses, the Perfected Lord Who Protects and Upholds the Mandate. I present a **golden dragon and jade tablet**, hoping that the Most Sagely and Most Perfected may deign to regard this crimson offering. I beseech that it be transcribed and submitted, ascending to the Nine Heavens.

I reflect that the position of crown prince remains vacant, and the auspicious dream of the bear has not yet unfolded; the borderlands are divided by encampments, and the tiger tallies of military command are still deployed. Within, I desire to strengthen the foundation of the state; without, I seek to pacify the miasma of war. Gazing up, I recall the arduous accumulation of our ancestors’ legacy, and am deeply moved by the daily fear of failing in its succession.

Furthermore, it is hoped that your humble consort may enjoy firm teeth, clear eyes, and a strong, healthy body; and that the Empress, née Wu, may see her palace flourish with blessings, her lineage prospering like luxuriant branches and leaves.

May the Most Sagely extend the benevolence of sheltering grace and generously bestow the power of sustaining aid. Should a son be granted in answer to the augury of *Zhen* and *Suo*, may the dynasty flourish for a hundred generations. Should arms be laid down to usher in great peace, may the four quarters be settled in governance. May the foundation of the state be secured in firmness, and the people and all beings be placed in tranquil repose. Reverently drawing near to the numinous blessings, I forever rely upon the Great Dao.

**Memorial Requesting Additional Enfeoffment**
Your servant Xiong Shouzhong respectfully pours forth his foolish sincerity, lifting his plea to the celestial hearing. In retrospect, I fear my presumption and willingly submit to the standard punishments.

I reflect that your servant is but a withered remnant of the mountains and forests, a wanderer of clouds and waters subsisting on bamboo bowl and gourd ladle. My person drifts with the world, while my resolve is stirred by the times. I have witnessed the Perfected Lord Who Protects and Upholds the Mandate of the Nine Heavens’ Inspector of Responses at Mount Lu in Jiangzhou—from the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors of antiquity down to the Tang, through successive dynasties, his name has changed, yet his manifest numinosity has descended with blessings. He governs the celestial and terrestrial mandate of the state and oversees the sacred charts of ancestral heirs.

In former times, imperial plaques were bestowed, lands granted, and enfeoffments and prayers established as enduring precedents. As for dispelling drought and flood, quelling the scourge of war—his responsive efficacy has twice been proven, as recorded in steles and annals. At the inception of the Perfected Lord’s manifestations, he declared that after five hundred years, blessings would extend to the living and the state’s destiny would be safeguarded. Now, five hundred and eight years have passed, yet none have penetrated the depths of his celestial hearing.

I further reflect that your servant, though born of a Confucian family, was commanded by his father to enter the mountains. By grace, I donned the feathered robes and have tended the incense and flame of the Perfected Lord for over fifty years. Since my mistaken appointment as abbot, I have eradicated corruption, reformed abuses, and renewed the sacred precincts, leading the ranks of the Daoist clergy in prayers for the prolongation of the sagely emperor’s life. For every year’s abundance or scarcity, for the people’s sufferings and hardships, I have purified my heart day and night, offering sincere prayers in pursuit of responsive efficacy, aspiring to assist this enlightened age.

Though I am not one bound by official duty or burdened with the responsibility of speech, my devotion to the state and love for the sovereign arise from innate nature. Thus, I dare to present this plea with reverent urgency, ever cherishing my longing for the imperial court.

We humbly pray that the Nine Heavens grant their favor, the Three Realms shine their presence; dispelling calamities to bring peace to the times, and stilling the weapons of war without battle. May we further hope for timely rains and sunshine, abundant harvests of grain; may the myriad people be free from pestilence, and the four seas delight in the transformative blessings of peace.

Heaven is impartial, for it aids only those of virtue; the Supreme Dao has its essentials, and only through sincerity can it be accessed. Warfare encroaches upon the borders, and the master and disciples remain encamped in the wilds. The cruelty of the long battles along the Sichuan and Huai frontiers pierces this heart; the majesty of the nine provinces and all lands beneath heaven should rightfully return to the Middle Kingdom. We reverently recall the Perfected Lord of Nine Heavens, Surveyor of Responses, Protector of the Mandate: he manifested his supreme numen in ancient times, and his illustrious title was exalted in our dynasty; at the appointed time of auspicious destiny, he fulfilled the long-held hopes of all living beings. May all witness the signs of purity and tranquility;

*Qingci* to the Supreme Emperor:
In the inaugural year of Chunyou, as we tread the auspicious threshold of royal spring,
within the sacred precincts of Taiping,
we humbly hope to receive the private blessings of imperial favor.
With meager offerings, we inherit this glorious legacy.
Heaven, knowing remorse for calamity, has fortunately eased frontier defenses;
the people, fearing famine, ponder the still-meager state granaries.
Ever inscribing our anxieties upon vermilion tablets,
we beseech the azure vault for succor.
Thus, we command the feathered ranks to solemnly invite the perfected ones’ arrival,
to unfold the secrets of medicinal arts,
and to renew our reverent offerings with refined devotion.

We humbly pray that harmonious qi may suffuse and transform,
that malevolent vapors be cleansed and dispersed;
that the blessings of a thousand fortunes and a hundred felicities unfold like wings;
that the circulation of grain and goods flow as smoothly as fish in formation.

*Qingci* to the Perfected Lord:
Responding to the mandate to safeguard destiny,
you prolong the world’s allotted span;
manifesting virtue and establishing merit,
you are revered by the imperial court.
Since your sacred traces were glorified on Mount Lu,
your illustrious titles have been bestowed by former dynasties.
Now, following the time-honored rites of exaltation,
we seek to manifest the wondrous transformation of the true Dao.
Thus, we present our petition to the Supreme Emperor,
offering celebration and praise to the divine glory.
With solemn offerings of orchids and reeds,
we invoke the perfected ones’ arrival upon the mushroom chariots.

We humbly pray that the nine heavens’ wondrous creation may descend,
blessing and averting misfortune;
that the four seas’ living beings be pacified,
and the realm attain supreme stability;
that the wolf-smoke of war be stilled,
and the auspicious dream of the bear be early fulfilled.

*Jiao Intent for the Shousheng Guangfu Abbey and Dazhong Xiangfu Abbey:*
In the first year of Chunyou, cyclical year *xinchou*, on the eighteenth day of the second month (day *bingzi*), the heir to the Son of Heaven, your subject [Name], reverently considers:
The Perfected Lord of the Nine Heavens’ Inquiry, Responding to the Mandate and Safeguarding Destiny, Wondrous Transformation,
whose Daoist attainments are the wellspring of the tradition,
whose blessings overflow like a river,
who governs the sacred peaks and is the august spirit of the imperial court—
his divine strategies long renowned,
his illustrious titles ever augmented.
Following the conclusion of the jiao rites of gratitude,
as the hundred spirits converge in celebration,
we unfold the profound liturgy,
continuing this grand occasion.
Thus, on the eighteenth day of this month,
at the Shousheng Guangfu Abbey on Mount Lu in Jiangzhou,
we shall establish a one-day-and-night *Lingbao* Daoist sanctuary,
reciting scriptures and performing the ritual circumambulation,
consecrating the star lanterns,
and conducting a grand *qingjiao* (pure jiao) with one hundred twenty altar stations.
We shall invite and guide the arrival of the supreme perfected ones,
reverently praying for the radiant solar essence.

We humbly beseech that the divine glory harmoniously assist,
fulfilling the era of people’s peace and the realm’s prosperity;
that the frontiers be free from peril,
and the signs of heaven’s clarity and earth’s tranquility be witnessed.

**Green Petition**

Extolling the wondrous transformation of the august title, the hundred spirits converge in celebration; facing the Supreme Emperor of the Mysterious Heavens, a single thought flows forth. Not merely to amplify the brilliance of the sacred rites, but also to manifest the majesty of divine favor. Thus, we perform the rites of purity and reverence, jointly expressing our private veneration.

We humbly pray that the sagely enterprise be upheld, jointly preserving the grand design for eternity; that the frontiers be tranquil and serene, guiding the people toward great peace; that the imperial heir inherit blessings, and all under heaven enjoy clarity, harmony, and prosperity.

**Memorial from the Prefecture Requesting Imperial Incense**

Your servant Li Wenfang, on behalf of Li Shouhao, the abbot and supervisor of the Taiping Xingguo Abbey on Mount Lu in Jiangzhou, respectfully submits: This abode is the sacred site of the Divine Inspector’s residence, where the emperor is revered in the Benming Shenfu Hall. Each year, during the spring and autumn state *jiao* rituals, the local governor writes the imperial name on the memorial tablets. The decree states: *"To pray for the well-being of all living beings and dispel calamities."*

In the first year of Xiangfu, it was decreed that imperial incense be bestowed upon the halls of this abbey. However, the abbey has not since petitioned for this privilege. We reflect that the incense offerings in the hall of blessings have been revered by successive sages; the bestowal of imperial incense and the establishment of *jiao* rituals to protect the state and pacify the realm have yielded manifest efficacy. The edicts and documents attesting to this are too numerous to count.

Recently, when the prefectural authorities, concerned by the delayed auspicious snow, performed a *jiao* ritual, the response was immediate: a hundred thousand households were suffused with harmonious *qi*, and five centuries of blessings flowed as foretold. From Xiangfu to Jiaxi, whenever imperial incense was bestowed and *jiao* rituals held, divine responses followed. The throne once bestowed the honorific title *"Miaohua"* upon the Perfected Lord and conferred the imperial calligraphy *"Sanqing Pavilion"*, along with ordination certificates, aloeswood, camphor, altar consecrations, and silks for the *jiao* rituals to protect the frontiers and pray for an heir. The texts of these decrees remain preserved.

Yet, all previous bestowals of incense and *jiao* rituals were initiated by the prefectural authorities. Now, we humbly request that, in accordance with precedent, the prefecture memorialize the throne to revive these ancient rites. The details of the foregoing memorial must be submitted for imperial consideration.

Your servant respectfully notes: The Taiping Xingguo Abbey is the seat of the Nine Heavens’ Divine Inspector, and from the Kaiyuan era of the Tang to the present dynasty, over five hundred years have passed, during which the deity’s responses have been manifold and imperial honors repeatedly bestowed. Since the founding of the dynasty, imperial incense has been granted annually as a regular observance. However, by the Longxing era, this practice fell into neglect.

In the second and fourth years of Jiaxi, the abbey’s supervisor, Xiong Shouzhong, petitioned, and the throne graciously bestowed the honorific *"Miaohua"* upon the Perfected Lord, along with imperial incense. Since then, no one from the abbey has petitioned, nor has the prefecture submitted memorials, thereby contravening the intent of successive dynasties to honor these rites and constituting a grave omission.

Recently, when the auspicious snow was delayed last winter, your servant personally visited the shrine to pray for the people, and the response was immediate, as if echoing our pleas. The triple whiteness heralded a bountiful year. Given such manifest efficacy, it is fitting to report this in accordance with established protocol to glorify the divine favor.

We humbly beseech Your Sagely Compassion to issue a decree reviving the ancient rites of the dynasty, granting imperial incense to this abbey each year, and instructing that the *jiao* rituals be conducted in accordance with the directives issued in the gengzi year of Jiaxi. This memorial is respectfully submitted for imperial consideration, awaiting your sagely decree.

**Fourth Year of Baoyou, First Month**

**Imperial Incense Decree**

By order of the Ministry of Rites, in accordance with the memorial from Li Wenweng, Prefect of Jiangzhou, submitted on the eighth day of the second month of the fourth year of Baoyou, requesting the revival of the dynasty’s ancient rites by granting imperial incense annually to the Taiping Xingguo Abbey on Mount Lu in Jiangzhou for the performance of *jiao* rituals:

The matter was subsequently referred to the Ministry of Rites for verification of precedent and submitted to the Secretariat. Upon review, the Secretariat forwarded the matter to the Court of Imperial Sacrifices for thorough examination and clarification before reporting back to the ministry.

Thereafter, the Court of Imperial Sacrifices submitted: *"Regarding the request in the memorial to revive the directives issued in the gengzi year of Jiaxi for the performance of *jiao* rituals, we now propose that the ministry report to the throne, instructing Jiangzhou to implement the directives in accordance with the precedents of the gengzi year of Jiaxi."*

The original memorial was forwarded to the ministry for submission to the throne. Upon review, the judgment was issued: *"In accordance with the Court of Imperial Sacrifices’ submission, Jiangzhou is to implement the directives as originally decreed and report on their execution, with a copy to the Secretariat for reference."*

The ministry has reported this to the throne for consideration. The prefecture is to act accordingly, implementing the directives as originally decreed. The prefectural authorities have complied and reported back, and the abbey has acted in accordance with the directives.

Thereafter, the Taiping Xingguo Abbey submitted a report detailing the dates and precedents of the throne’s bestowals of incense and *jiao* rituals, requesting the prefecture to report to the ministry for verification of past examples and issuance of the appropriate directives:

- **Third Year of Taiping Xingguo**: Spring and autumn *jiao* rituals; ordination certificates.
- **Third Year of Taiping Xingguo**: Spring and autumn *jiao* rituals; ministry documents; three volumes of vegetarian feast accounts.
- **Thirty-First Year of Shaoxing**: Bestowal of incense, *jiao* rituals, and prayer tablets.
- **Second Year of Longxing**: Bestowal of incense, *jiao* rituals, and prayer tablets.
- **Third Year of Duanping**: Memorial from the Ministry of Rites for *jiao* rituals to pray for harvests and dispel warfare; seven volumes of decrees and texts.
- **First Year of Jiaxi**: Bestowal of incense, *jiao* rituals, and jade tablets to protect the frontiers and pray for an heir.
- **Second Year of Jiaxi**: Bestowal of incense, *jiao* rituals to dispel warfare; decrees, silver, paper money, silks, and other items in three volumes and four pieces.
- **First Year of Chunyou**: Bestowal of the honorific title for the Perfected Lord; decrees, prayer tablets, incense, abbey documents, silver, silks, and imperial edicts in four volumes and five pieces.

Having submitted the foregoing documents to the ministry for verification and issuance, the prefecture affirms their accuracy and humbly requests the issuance of directives for implementation.

Awaiting the imperial directive, it is noted that Li Wenweng of Jiangzhou has submitted a petition requesting the revival of the former dynastic rites, the bestowal of imperial incense, and the performance of a *jiao* ritual at the Taiping Xingguo Abbey on Mount Lu in Jiangzhou. Upon review, it is found that in previous reigns, imperial incense, calligraphic scrolls, ordination certificates, and silks were indeed bestowed. Now, in accordance with the petition of Li Shouhao, the abbey’s acting superintendent, and upon verification of the original imperial decree, this prefecture has directly submitted the request as per precedent. On the ninth day of the sixth month, the Three Departments jointly received the imperial edict, ordering that incense be bestowed upon Jiangzhou as before, to be delivered to the abbey for the *jiao* ritual, with the same provisions as those granted in the gengzi year of Jiaxi. The Imperial Pharmacy, the Palace Eunuch Directorate, the Hanlin Academy, and the Jiangzhou abbey are each to act accordingly.

The above is hereby issued to the Taiping Xingguo Abbey on Mount Lu.

Dated this day of the sixth month, the fourth year of Baoyou.

By imperial decree, Vice-Minister Li of the Bureau of Military Affairs is instructed: On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, the Taiping Xingguo Abbey in Jiangzhou shall conduct the state *jiao* ritual. Herewith are bestowed thirty taels of aloeswood, ten catties each of *jian* sandalwood and *jiangzhen* incense, to be used for the ritual offerings. For future prayers, any further bestowals shall be duly recorded and reported.

Dated this day of the seventh month, the fourth year of Baoyou.

Prepared by the Eunuch Directorate of the Inner Palace, the Palace Attendant of the Ruidian Hall, the Acting Supervisor of the Dragon Diagram and Celestial Chapters Pavilions, and the Acting Supervisor of the Imperial Treasury and Hanlin Bureau, Mao Cungong.

**Memorial on the Bestowal of Imperial Incense**

Your subject, Li Wenpu, humbly submits: Upon assuming my post in the borderlands, my prayers for divine favor were answered. Mindful of the abbey where the Perfected Lord stores blessings and recalling the longstanding dynastic custom of bestowing imperial incense, I found that the abbey had failed to petition for its renewal, nor had the local authorities taken the initiative to request it. I thus urgently memorialized the throne and was graciously favored with an imperial response. By imperial decree, it is ordered that each year, thirty taels of aloeswood and ten catties each of *jian* sandalwood and *jiangzhen* incense be bestowed upon the Taiping Xingguo Abbey for the autumn *jiao* ritual on the fifteenth day of the eighth month. For future bestowals, these offerings shall serve to pray for the eternal mandate of Heaven, the protection of the state, the pacification of the frontiers, and the universal well-being of all living beings, that all may ascend to benevolence and longevity.

Now, as the sacred precincts are prepared and the vermilion memorials laid forth, I humbly beseech the radiant imperial gaze to witness the sincerity of the Ninefold Palace. May the imperial favor be bestowed anew, upholding the annual rites. Through these meritorious acts, may abundant blessings be secured.

To His Imperial Majesty:
May your grand designs expand boundlessly, and your legacy endure through generations. May the seasons prove fruitful, the people content in their labors; may the Central Kingdom know peace, the four barbarians submit, and the frontiers remain undisturbed by dust.

May the Perfected One, who surveys the Nine Heavens, grant that Your luminous scrutiny be justly reflected upon the throne. Yet now, the afflictions of Shu and Guang have deepened, and the wounds of Huai and Xiang fester. Flood and drought alternate, while troops and treasuries grow ever depleted.

This humble servant, entrusted with office and indebted to sovereign grace, gazes toward the vermilion steps to offer loyalty, and toward the Crimson Mound to beseech blessings. We humbly pray that the Emperor’s person enjoy longevity and joy, that the foundation of the state remain secure and strong; that the four seasons’ qi harmonize, bringing abundant harvests of grain; that the three frontiers stand firm, forever free from the peril of beacon fires; and that all the realm’s subjects equally partake in the Dao’s responsive grace.

**Respectfully Receiving the Court’s Bestowal of Funds for the Universal Salvation Jiao: A Secret Edict**

Respectfully receiving the imperial decree: Since the warfare of last year, many loyal and valiant men have died in battle, and countless displaced souls have perished in untimely deaths. These orphaned spirits, without refuge, truly evoke our deepest concern. A Universal Salvation Jiao shall be conducted to enable their transcendence.

In Sichuan, the rites shall be held at Chongqing; in the Two Guangs, at Mount Heng; and in Jiangnan and Jiangxi, at the Taiping Xingguo Abbey in Jiangzhou. At each of these three sites, a Jiao of 1,200 offerings shall be performed. For each location, the following shall be bestowed: 100 taels of aloeswood, 10 taels of borneol, 300 catties of *jiangzhen* incense, 100 catties of yellow wax, and 100,000 strings of official currency. Designated personnel and soldiers shall be dispatched to oversee the delivery, ensuring strict accountability and meticulous preparation. The rites shall commence within the eighth month, spanning three days and nights.

Decrees have been issued to the Sichuan Military Commission, the Guangdong Pacification and Defense Commission, the Guangxi Pacification and Defense Commission, the Hunan Pacification Commission, and the Jing-Hu Military Commission.

*Fifth year of Jingding, sixth month.*

---

Formerly, the Tartar barbarians, devoid of the Dao, advanced insatiably. Yet relying on our people’s readiness for war, we prevailed in every battle. Some wielded shields and spears in defense, others seized poisoned bows to scale the heights. Never did they face the enemy with thoughts of survival; all sought to annihilate them before taking sustenance. Their loyalty was spent to the utmost, viewing death as a return home. The killing energy pierced the heavens, reeking of carnage, while their heroic souls, though cast upon the dew, grew only more resolute.

Yet we grieve that their forms have perished, and their sacrifice remains etched in our hearts. Therefore, on the twenty-fifth day of the eighth month, at the Taiping Xingguo Abbey in Jiangzhou, a Great Universal Salvation Jiao of 1,200 offerings shall be conducted, invoking the power of the Dao to enable their transcendence.

**Memorial by Shi Dazi, Requesting the Conferral of Honors and a Sacred Register**

At the Taiping Xingguo Abbey in this prefecture, we revere the incense and flame of the Nine Heavens’ Inspector, Responsive to the Dao, Guardian of Fortune, and Wondrous Transformer, the Perfected Lord. According to records and gazetteers, during the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, Emperor Minghuang, moved by a dream, was instructed by the Perfected Spirit to establish a shrine on Mount Lu. Five hundred years later, blessings would extend to all living beings. Thus, the Nine Heavens’ Envoy Temple was built in Jiangzhou. The emperors Gaozong and Xiaozong frequently dispatched officials to offer prayers for border security and the repulsion of warfare. Since His Majesty’s ascension, he has bestowed calligraphic works and imperial incense, honoring the deity with even greater reverence.

Last autumn, when I was stationed here, the barbarian horses stealthily crossed the border. I received an edict to advance with the Yellow Banner to reinforce Hubei. Upon receiving the command, I set forth at once. Yet my authority in Fujian was inherently weak, and Jiangzhou, deemed an interior region, faced the enemy without generals or troops. To retreat and defend the central river would mean a city with low walls and shallow moats; to dispatch naval forces to Hubei would be thwarted by contrary winds; to reinforce Huangzhou with reinforcements would invite swift disaster. The people were restless, the soldiers’ morale low. The fate of the ancestral altars hung in the balance, and success was uncertain. Thus, I beseeched the Perfected Shrine to conduct a Great Universal Salvation Jiao of 3,600 offerings, praying for the nation’s protection and the repulsion of war. Thereupon, the winds shifted, and reinforcements arrived without incident. The deity’s manifest power demands our gratitude and repayment.

I personally visited the abbey to fulfill the vow. Perusing the steles, I learned that the Perfected Spirit is also titled the Supreme Emperor of the Vermilion Mound, Inspector of the Nine Heavens and Nine Earths, who determines the destinies, fortunes, and misfortunes of heaven and humanity. His dignity rivals that of the Heavenly Emperor. He governs the Nine Palaces, the Nine Provinces, and the celestial divisions of the Nine Stars. The cycles of 108 years are tied to the world’s fortunes, influencing its rise and fall—and our dynasty has received abundant blessings. When the rebel Zhang Yu of the Jianyan era attacked Jiangzhou, the city’s soldiers and civilians witnessed the Perfected Lord’s true form manifest in the clouds, assuming the shape of a dragon-horse. During the Kaixi era, when Wu Xi rebelled in Shu, General Jiang Jie of Kuizhou received a divine visitation, declaring that the Inspector had petitioned the Heavenly Emperor, and the rebels would face extermination. Now, as the reckless barbarians defy righteousness, we rely on unseen aid: the river’s surface is once more calm, and the southeast rests secure.

**Memorial on the Petition for the Conferral of an Augmented Honorific Title**

When Acting Prefect Yin Leirui was temporarily assigned to this post, he conducted sacrifices to the mountains and rivers within the prefecture’s bounds. Searching the ritual canons and consulting the elders, he learned that the *True Lord of the Nine Heavens Who Gathers Intelligence*, who appeared in a dream to the Radiant Emperor, established a shrine in this land—upright and unified, bestowing blessings upon the people below. For five hundred years, his presence has endured: in the Shaoxing era, clouds manifested and Zhang Yu was extinguished; in the Kaixi era, a divine brush descended and Hao Xi was executed. When barbarian scouts filled the riverbanks and the prefecture clung to its isolated walls in desperate defense, the enemy, upon nearing the borders, fled in panic and disarray. These are recent and undeniable proofs of his efficacy.

Upon examination, we find that successive sagely emperors of our dynasty have bestowed the highest honors with utmost sincerity. Though the god’s beneficence endures to this day, his title remains unchanged from old—perhaps this is not in accord with ritual propriety. Former prefects, Academician Shi and Academician Lu, both previously memorialized, petitioning for the conferral of an honorific to accord with the people’s wishes, yet no imperial response was received.

Now, as the era of Great Fortune unfolds and the earth mirrors the heavens, the hundred spirits receive their mandates, and their divine merits shine forth—how can their exaltation be delayed? It is hoped that the court will review and deliberate upon this matter.

**Fifth day of the fifth month, second year of Jingding (1261)**
*Memorandum from the Jiangzhou Provincial Surveillance Commission*
*To the Pacification Commissioner of Jiangxi and Prefect of Jiangzhou:*

On the fifth day of this month, we received a dispatch from the Ministry of Rites at the imperial court, transmitting a document dated the fourth day of the eighth month of the second year of Jingding, approved by the Secretariat and forwarded from the Court of Imperial Sacrifices. The document cites a memorial from Yin Leirui, newly appointed Gentleman for Thorough Service and concurrently Academician of the Hall of Illustrious Strategy, now Prefect of Jiangzhou.

Upon arriving in the prefecture, I found the local gentry and commoners united in petition, declaring that in the previous year, when the Tartar bandits secretly crossed the river and infiltrated Jiangxi, the entire prefecture was preserved in peace—all due to the blessings of the *True Lord of the Nine Heavens Who Gathers Intelligence, Responsive to the Dao, Guardian of Fortune, Wondrous Transformer*, whose shrine on Mount Lu bestows grace. They beseech that this be made known and that his honorific title be augmented. Furthermore, former officials, Grand Academician Shi and Academician Lu, had previously memorialized the throne; their original petitions are hereby resubmitted. It is hoped that the court will review these repeated appeals and deign to add two characters to the existing six-character title, while also consulting the ritual precedents of the Zhenghe era and conferring a jade register.

This matter has been forwarded for judgment. The Court of Imperial Sacrifices, upon investigation, notes that in the sixth month of the first year of Jingding, it received a memorial from Jiangzhou, petitioning for the *True Lord of the Nine Heavens Who Gathers Intelligence, Responsive to the Dao, Guardian of Fortune, Wondrous Transformer*, enshrined at the Taiping Xingguo Abbey in Jiangzhou, to have an eight-character honorific appended to his title. In that same month, this court proposed the title *True Lord of the Nine Heavens Who Gathers Intelligence, Responsive to the Dao, Guardian of Fortune, Wondrous Transformer, Assistant in Upholding Rightness*, to be honored with a jade register, in accordance with the previously issued imperial decree. The matter was duly memorialized to the Secretariat in the sixth month of that year. We now respectfully submit this to the Ministry of State Affairs, humbly requesting that the court issue instructions in accordance with the aforementioned memorial for implementation in this prefecture.

The matter was subsequently endorsed and forwarded to the Ministry of Rites, which issued orders to this prefecture for compliance. Accordingly, this directive is hereby transmitted to the prefecture. You are to carefully review the contents of this document and act in accordance with the instructions therein. The approved directives are to be presented to the prefectural authorities for deliberation. It is proposed that a notice be issued to the Taiping Abbey, and a copy be forwarded to the Surveillance Commission for record, to ensure proper execution.

**Eighteenth day of the eleventh month, second year of Jingding (1261)**
*Decree on the Conferral of an Augmented Honorific*

The essence of the Supreme Dao is profound and obscure, transcending all things and moving amidst the Nine Heavens. Its name and rank are exalted, its transformative power wondrous—it is simply called the True One. The Nine Heavens’ Investigator of Primordial Qi, Guardian of Fortune, and Wondrous Transformer of Jiangzhou’s Taiping Xingguo Abbey roams in serene harmony with the Creator and transforms in concert with yin and yang. Fortune and misfortune, regret and shame—all arise from the principle of silent resonance and response. When Heaven’s wrath fell upon the lawless foe, it was the True One who aided the royal army in purifying the Jiang’s surface.

Though named "Investigator," as if some entity presided over its domain, the True One is not bound by things, yet nothing can escape its influence. The conferral of its rank reaches the pinnacle, and its title spans eight characters—its honor is supreme. It is hereby specially enfeoffed as the Nine Heavens’ Investigator of Primordial Qi, Guardian of Fortune, Wondrous Transformer, and Assistant of Righteousness, True Lord.

This prefecture, in reverent observance of the enfeoffment decree, holds a jiao offering to celebrate the imperial intent.

In the year *jiwei* (1259), warhorses invaded the Jiang. Through the subtle efficacy of the Investigator’s power, the royal army secured victory. The barbarians were swept away, and the land was pacified. Rightly does such hidden merit warrant solemn recompense. Thus, the True Lord’s title is augmented by eight characters, bestowing blessings upon the Nine Rivers. The phoenix-edict is grandly proclaimed, and the jade palace takes on a new splendor.

I, unworthy as I am, serve as this region’s governor and have personally received the imperial grace, fortunate to rely upon the blessings of the Assistant of Righteousness. Therefore, I humbly perform the rites of reverence, praying for the eternal flourishing of the state and the enduring protection of the realm.

**Jiao Offering Prayer:**
O radiant and mighty spirit, who aided the royal army’s righteous cause—
With solemn proclamation, we manifest the splendor of the state’s rites.
Though the True One’s transcendence requires no praise,
The court must duly honor its debt of gratitude.

Looking back to those years of peril, when strife first arose—
The Jiang and Han rivers surged, startling the Tartar steeds as they forded;
The borders, once desolate, at last revived, like fish escaping a dried cauldron.
Through its subtle aid, the army’s might was strengthened, and the people’s lives preserved.
Thus, the eight-character title was bestowed, answering the grand favor of the Nine Heavens.
May it share the state’s prosperity, dispelling demonic vapors from the frontier;
May it, in its boundless benevolence, enhance the auspicious radiance of mountains and rivers.

By the Imperial Edict of the Emperor, under the power of the Eternal Heaven and the great fortune of the protective spirits:

An Imperial Edict to the *darughachi* officials, traveling envoys, military commanders, soldiers, masters of all teachings, and the common people in cities and villages:

The edicts of Genghis Khan and Qa’an the Emperor decree: Daoist monks, Christians (*Yelikewen*), masters (*xiansheng*), and Muslim clerics (*dashman*) shall be exempt from all corvée and taxes, that they may pray to Heaven and invoke blessings for Us. As before, let this be observed.

Thus, in accordance with the teachings of the Most High Lord Lao, Daoist monks, Christians, masters, and Muslim clerics shall remain free from all corvée and taxes, that they may pray to Heaven and invoke blessings for Us. By this decree, the Imperial Edict is hereby conferred upon Zhang the Heavenly Master, Abbot of the Supreme Clarity Orthodox Unity Abbey at Dragon-Tiger Mountain in Xinzhou. Furthermore, the Heavenly Master’s own household, the Yanshuaiguan, shall serve as the principal site for ritual practice.

In all abbeys and monasteries, envoys shall not be quartered. No one, regardless of status, may forcibly occupy them by force, adjudicate official matters within them, store grain, impose any levies, or demand post-horses and requisitions. No commercial taxes shall be collected. All lands, waters, bamboo groves, mills, boats, gardens, pawnshops, warehouses, bathhouses, inns, and breweries belonging to the abbeys shall be exempt from all corvée and taxes. Let no one evade this by citing other edicts.

From all categories of appanage holders, nothing shall be exacted from the masters, nor shall the masters yield to such demands. Furthermore, in all official matters, the masters shall adhere to the words of Zhang the Heavenly Master and the teachings of the Most High Lord Lao, acting in accordance with principle without deviation. They shall not adjudicate disputes among the laity.

If disputes arise between masters and the laity, the appointed leaders of the masters and the city officials shall jointly investigate and resolve them. Should any master violate the established norms—engaging in fraud, theft, or other misconduct—they shall be handed over to the *darughachi* officials of the city for disposition.

This Imperial Edict, held by Zhang the Heavenly Master, must be obeyed. Let no improper official matters be conducted. If any are, they shall be reported to Us. We shall recognize the truth of it.

Issued on the tenth day of the second month in the fourteenth year of the Zhiyuan era.

On the twenty-eighth day of this month, in observance of the Sacred Festival of the Emperor’s Longevity, we humbly commission officials to conduct a grand Golden Register Ritual at the blessed site of Taiping Xingguo Abbey. Preparations shall commence on the twenty-sixth day with the recitation of sacred scriptures, the establishment of the fasting altar, and the display of talismanic clouds. On the twenty-seventh day, morning, noon, and evening audiences shall be held, with rites of repentance and memorials presented. At dawn on the twenty-eighth day, the ritual banquet shall be prepared, and the Supreme Emperor of the Dao invoked, that the full offerings may be dispersed.

We reverently pray that His Imperial Majesty’s sacred longevity be boundless, the imperial domain secure, the people prosperous, all things abundant, and the seas and rivers tranquil.

*Scroll Five of the Veritable Records of the Investigating Perfected Lord of Mount Lu’s Taiping Xingguo Abbey*
*Category: Encounters with Immortals*

**Master Kang Meets Liu Yue**
During the Zhou dynasty, Master Kang and his six brothers cultivated true qi upon Mount Lu, delighting in reclusion among the forests and springs. One day, a youth dressed in flowing robes and a *zhangfu* cap came to visit. His discourse was refined, and he delighted in discussing antiquity, the present age, and the learning of immortals. Master Kang found him extraordinary and treated him with increasing warmth. Thus passed several years, yet his name remained unknown. After prolonged association, Master Kang remarked, “I have long been familiar with your noble bearing, yet dare not inquire your name, nor do I know your dwelling.”

The youth replied, “I am Liu Yue, residing to the left of this mountain. If you do not disdain my humble abode, I hope you will visit.” He added, “At the mountain’s base lies a stone about three feet high; knock upon it, and we shall meet.”

Master Kang followed his instructions and, arriving at the mountain’s base, saw the stone. Upon knocking, it suddenly opened, revealing double doors to a grotto. A young servant welcomed him, and after ten-odd steps, two azure-clad attendants bearing crimson staffs led the way. Gradually, pavilions and terraces came into view, their gold and jade hues intermingling, while rare birds and strange beasts, exotic flowers and trees, filled the scene. A Perfected One, crowned with a jade diadem and girded with a vermilion sash and sword, came forth to greet him.

Master Kang, realizing this was no mortal realm, wished to take up residence. The Perfected One, divining his intent, said, “Your hidden merits are not yet complete; a future meeting may be expected. One day, you shall follow me to the Turtle Palace of Penglai or the Crimson Towers of Red City—it will not be late.” They drank three cups of jade wine and a sip of the Elixir of Longevity before he departed. Turning back, the great stone appeared as before.

On another day, he knocked again, but there was no response. A pavilion was later built upon the stone, named “Immortal Stone.” The characters “Liu the Immortal” naturally appeared upon it, and the remains of the abbey’s triple gate may still be seen today.

*From the* Record of Liu’s Immortal Stone.

**Zhang Yunsou’s** *Southern Exile Record* **states:**
There was a Master Kang of the Zhou who built his hut upon this mountain, hence the name “Kang’s Hut.” Located thirty *li* south of the prefecture, one passes Sweet Pear Lake and follows the banks of the Mi River for about ten *li*, ascending and descending. A mountain stream flows north, emerging from the Qianxi Academy. After several more *li*, one reaches New Bridge, where forests flank both sides, the sound of water delightfully clear, and the peaks rise steeply. Crossing Snake Ridge, one arrives at Taiping Xingguo Abbey, the former temple of the Tang dynasty’s Nine Heavens’ Investigating Envoy. During the Xining era, the Perfected Lord Who Responds to the Origin and Preserves the Mandate was enfeoffed, and the temple was expanded into an abbey. Its scale is grand, stretching across valleys and streams, with kitchens, refectories, and blessings flowing in a circuit of water. The hall bears the imperial calligraphy of Emperor Yuan Zong, lacquered plaques, and ink inscriptions. There is also a life-sized bronze statue of the imperial visage, bestowed by the imperial brother Feng, with a hall plaque in gold characters and a vermilion inscription. The golden doors are sealed, and it is seldom seen. Additionally, three sets of golden-painted immortal robes were bestowed. Outside the hall, at the base of the steps, stands a stone called “Liu’s Immortal Stone,” where Master Kang knocked to keep his appointment with Liu the Immortal.

**Hu Chongzhen Meets Lü Dongbin**
The abbey’s Daoist Hu Yongzong, styled Chongzhenzi, renounced the world in his youth and devoted himself to cultivation. During the Xining era, a Daoist in tattered robes and worn shoes, who called himself Hui, abruptly entered the treasury hall as if no one were present. Other Daoists ignored him, but Hu alone bowed and seated him in a small chamber, treating him with courteous regard, astonished by his transcendent demeanor. After requesting wine and drinking twice, Hui invited Hu to drink at an inn, but Hu declined due to the lateness of the hour. Hui stroked his beard, laughed, and departed.

The next morning, Hu entered the city to pay respects to the prefect. Arriving at the gate before it opened, he saw the Daoist emerging from the city, smiling as he looked back. The gatekeepers remarked, “Before the third watch, a Daoist named Hui waited here for the gate to open—we know not who he is.” Hu found this strange.

Years later, a man with a hempen belt and two gourds, calling himself “Guest of the Great Song,” visited Hu at the abbey. Their conversation was refined. Hu asked, “What are these gourds for?” He replied, “My luggage.” Upon pouring them out, they contained gold and silver. He asked if Hu desired them, but Hu answered that he wished only for the Way of longevity. The guest took out fragments of silver to buy wine, and as they drank, he orally transmitted the supreme Dao.

At dusk, he cut into the earth with a knife, poured wine to rinse his mouth, mixed the spittle with soil, and exhaled upon it to form ink. Tossing it onto the table, it rang with a metallic sound. He told Hu, “Consuming this will cure illness and lead to immortality.” After drinking again, Hu became drunk and collapsed. When he awoke, an extraordinary fragrance filled the room, and where the earth had been cut, a spring welled forth. The guest had vanished.

Hu ground the ink into wine and drank it, and his chronic ailments were instantly cured. Though over seventy, his appearance was like a maiden’s, and his capacity for wine remained unchanged. Gradually, he grew weary of the mortal world. One day, he left a poem, shed his form, and departed.

Today, the abbey’s “Ink Immortal Spring” may be cupped and drunk; its taste is sweet, and it never runs dry in winter or summer. Minister Wang of the Left, Song, and Vice Minister Song, Boyou, along with other renowned scholars, all composed matching verses and left inscriptions, recorded in the *Collected Poems of the Abbey’s Eminent Worthies*.

**Qi Wuzhi’s Transcendence in Meditation**
The abbey’s Daoist Qi Wuzhi would, each morning after completing his audience with the Perfected, shut his door and sit in meditation, disengaged from worldly affairs. Excerpted from the *Old Records of the Abbey*.

**Bi Yangsu’s Encounter with a Mysterious Figure**
The abbey’s Daoist Bi Daoning, styled Kangshu, was precocious from childhood, his appearance refined and striking. He could recite any classic or scripture after a single reading. During the Shaosheng era, while traveling through Jiangsu and Zhejiang, he arrived at Mount Qian and met a fangshi of imposing bearing who refused to disclose his name. They roamed the mountains together. Bi sensed his extraordinary nature and wished to become his disciple. The fangshi silently understood his intent and said: “In cultivating the Dao, refining the spirit and nurturing qi is paramount; alchemical texts are but stepping stones to enter the Way. If you sever worldly distractions and refine your spirit and qi with precision, you will naturally commune with the Perfected and attain numinous insight.” He then stood by a stream, pointed at the water, and told Bi: “When water is still, its form is straight; when the mind is tranquil, the spirit is at peace. You must take this as your mirror.” He then bestowed upon Bi an elixir, saying: “One day, we shall meet again at the foot of Shengzhi Peak.” With a bow, he departed, vanishing without a trace. Bi returned to the mountain that very day and, by chance, found the position of vice-abbot vacant. The prefectural authorities appointed him to fill the post.

Each day, he shut his door to preserve spirit, reciting one fascicle of the *Scripture of Salvation*. A grain of golden elixir,

Bind the dragon and tiger to the west,
congeal the golden water,
choose the ground with utmost care.
Nine years without flaw,

Stealing the primal transformation,

The Daoist of this abbey, Wang Bingwen, styled Yanheng, journeyed to the capital after attaining the Dao. At that time, the imperial court was constructing the Divine Empyrean Longevity Abbey and bestowed upon him a purple robe, appointing him as Master of Ceremonies. Suddenly, a fangshi arrived for a visit and, seeing a copy of the *Zhouyi* on his desk, cast divinations, saying: "This place shall face military calamity. You are not among those fated for it—best to avoid it." Thereupon, he imparted the essentials of *storing the Three and guarding the One*, along with the secrets of the Yellow Emperor and Bian Que. Wang then resigned his post and returned to the mountains.

In the fourth year of the Jianyan era, this abbey was destroyed by rebel troops. The following year, after the bandits retreated, none took responsibility for its restoration. Wang thus assumed the vice-abbot’s duties and, amid the ashes, oversaw its reconstruction for several years. The halls were adorned in gold and azure, gleaming anew. He then resigned from abbey affairs and secluded himself at home for over thirty years. His residence was named the *Hall of the Three Ones*, and he styled himself *Master of the Three Ones*. Daily, he studied the Daoist canon, delved into esoteric secrets, and devoted himself to medicine, harboring no other passions.

On the night of the Lantern Festival in the bingxu year of the Qiandao era, he dreamed of a divine messenger who declared: "The Supreme Emperor commands you to preside over the Great Cleansing Grotto of Golden Flower. He bestows upon you a *returning-soul elixir* to restore your spirit and replenish your primordial qi. You shall be escorted into the grotto by divine radiance, a white steed, and all the officials of the celestial bureaus." With these words, he awoke.

The next morning, he told his disciples: "The mortal world is no longer fit to dwell in—I shall depart." He then entrusted his works—fourteen fascicles of the *Collected Manifestations of Sagely Rule*, the *Divine Resolutions of the Perfected Lord of West Mountain* (the very divinations now consulted in the Inquiry Hall, renowned for their extraordinary efficacy), the *Pulse Secrets of Perfect Wholeness*, and the *Purple Court Secrets of the Morning Star*—to his dharma-heirs, Qin Zhixiang and others.

On the first day of the second month, after burning incense and changing into fresh robes, he passed away in serene composure. The prefect of this prefecture, Tang Fuwen (styled Wenruo), composed a eulogy in his honor:

*"I have heard that true persons sleep without dreams.
Those who dream are suspect of false transmission.
Yet to dismiss dreams as mere delusion may not be so—
for in dreams, one may be charged to find a worthy minister,
or awaken to the strains of celestial music in the Emperor’s presence.
Human life is like a dream—truly, it defies words.
Within dreams, there are yet deeper dreams.
Master of the Three Ones, your celestial mandate was fulfilled.
As you departed, your dream dissolved into transformation,
silently aligning with the true essence.
The Emperor commanded, bestowing upon you
the golden grotto’s return to the origin.
I would ask you: what was the cause?
Truth and illusion converge—
a hundred years pass in the blink of an eye.
Transcendent, you departed,
a white steed soaring lightly."*

Lao Pu Qikuan praised his spirit in verse:

*"Unseen to the eye, unheard to the ear,
yet within, an image—strikingly like you.
Forced depictions, labored and strained,
fall short in capturing even a fraction.
Ever present at the brows and lashes,
bound yet unbound,
like still water, like drifting clouds."*

From the *Stele Record of This Abbey*
*Huang the Perfected One’s Release by Means of the Corpse*

chunks.original_text: 本宫道士黄知微，字明道。 禀性冲淡，赋形丰伟。 元丰问充知殿，奉香火。 一日，潜山体道先生崔君来访，因语泥丸万神、刀圭一粒之妙，遂授一九谷神之道、金液沦景之旨。 从此若佯若蹶，散诞靡常。 时人呼为黄风子。 遂自赋黄颠歌。 载本集。 性嗜酒，每醉则浩歌，歌罢颠狂。 常在宫前朝真桥上疾声大呼，若有所呵。 一袖百结，裸露不顾，隆冬盛夏，恬无寒暑。 士夫问有施惠者，随手散去。 或居山问，或游城市。 常挈两布囊，每遇饼饵药物之属，杂贮囊中，了无秽气，号曰锦香。 时有大雪，林壑变白，独先生所居之屋无雪。 常指室傍壁坛示人日：此吾游蜀之路也。 初不知书，所谈多史传，素不能文，而所出皆高妙之句。 猴溪蔡子高、司马知白、崔风子、高赤脚皆与交游。 先生每喜噫气，一噫，时不停声。 崇宁末，年余九十，貌若处子，肌肤如玉，狂态如初，酒量不臧。 宣和末，诏征不起，有司强之，至九江日：今二天子矣，我往何为？ 既而渊圣登极，赦至本宫。 未回禄日，先生於采访殿揭梵植蒿，歌日：明年了来，明年了来。 次年韩世清贼马果焚宫庭，乃植蒿之日也。 谈人祸福，历历皆验。 先生羽化座于宫侧。

The abbey’s Daoist Huang Zhiwei, styled Mingdao, was of a serene and unadorned nature, his form tall and imposing. During the Yuanfeng era, he served as an attendant in the Hall of Enlightenment, tending the incense and flame. One day, Master Cui of Mount Qian, the Embodied Dao, came to visit and spoke of the wonders of the Mud-Pill Palace of Ten Thousand Spirits and the single grain of the elixir knife. Thereupon, he transmitted to him the Way of the Nine Grains of Divine Nourishment and the principles of the Golden Liquid’s descent into the radiant realm. From that time onward, Huang wandered as if in a daze, his conduct unconstrained and erratic. The people of the time called him "Huang the Windblown." He then composed the *Song of Huang’s Madness*, which is recorded in his collected works.

By nature, he loved wine; whenever drunk, he would sing loudly, and after singing, he would fall into wild abandon. Often, he stood on the Bridge of Morning Audience before the abbey, shouting vehemently as if rebuking someone. His sleeves were patched a hundred times, and he paid no heed to modesty, remaining indifferent to the cold of deep winter or the heat of midsummer. When scholars or officials offered him gifts, he would scatter them at once. Sometimes he dwelled in the mountains, sometimes he wandered through the cities. He always carried two cloth sacks, into which he haphazardly stuffed cakes, medicines, and the like, yet they emitted no foul odor—he called them his "brocade fragrance."

Once, a great snow fell, turning the forests and valleys white, yet the roof of the master’s dwelling alone remained free of snow. He would often point to the altar by the wall of his chamber and tell people, "This is the path by which I traveled to Shu." Though he had never studied books, his conversations often touched upon historical records. Though untrained in literary arts, his utterances were always lofty and wondrous. He associated with Cai Zigao of Monkey Creek, Sima Zhibai, Cui Fengzi, and Gao Chijiao.

The master was fond of sighing deeply, and when he sighed, the sound would continue without pause. In the late Chongning era, though he was over ninety years old, his appearance was like that of a maiden, his skin smooth as jade, and his mad demeanor unchanged. His capacity for wine had not diminished. At the end of the Xuanhe era, an imperial summons was issued, but he refused to answer. When officials pressed him, he reached Jiujiang and said, "Now there are two emperors—why should I go?" Soon after, when Emperor Qinsheng ascended the throne, an amnesty was proclaimed, and the decree reached the abbey.

Before the day of the conflagration, the master, in the Hall of Visitation, planted mugwort and reeds, singing, *"Next year it will end, next year it will end."* The following year, when the rebel Han Shiqing’s cavalry indeed burned the abbey, it was on the very day he had planted the mugwort. His predictions of fortune and misfortune were all borne out with precision.

The master ascended in feathered transformation, seated beside the abbey.

chunks.original_text: 后数年，有自蜀中回者日：黄风子今在蜀，昨於成都相会，寄家书在此。 众疑之，开械，乃是丧乱后所存道士妣名。 於是发棺视之，惟衣履在。 出《黄真人传记》 刘虚谷坐化 本宫道士刘烈，号虚谷子。 初生时，母感异梦。 长而有超卓之志，肄业山中，交游不杂。 王公大人叹其貌有大古淳风，必异日之法器也。 绍兴六年，创草庵，扁日真一。 每日端坐检阅道藏经史，一览随记。 士大夫愿纳交焉，如晦庵朱文公与谈《易》，论还丹之旨。 诗云：细读还丹一百篇，先生信笔亦多言。 元机馒白经书觅，至理端於目睫存。 一马果能为我驭，五芽应自长家园。 明朝酒醒下山去，此话更从谁与论。 张于湖孝祥一见留诗而去。 福地偏藏小洞天，洞天幽处炼神仙。 个中得趣惟虚谷，火候参同妙自然。 罗枢密点、王参政炎、曹两府勋、周凤溪顺、岳吏部甫，诸名公皆往来谈《易》，畴唱佳什。 并载《本宫名贤诗#2集》。 至隆兴元年，注解《周易》正经、及《六壬》，总括机乎一部，诣京投进。 蒙宣见问道赐宴，应制三茅观诗，谢恩赐酒乞还山等诗，并见本集。 后居山十余载。 至乾道九年六月，不食四十余日，惟饮玲水。 至七月十四日，将亲书《登真隐诀》二十五卷、并《上经》九卷送入木言藏史。 次日中元节，亲笔留原真一首诗、颂等有云：虚谷子将欲遗形弃世，扫迩人问，趋烟霞广漠之乡，与道冥一焉。 十六夜，步月登庐山可牛洞绝顶端坐而化。 有《还丹百篇》、杂着、诗文、《周易解义》，山斋易尚书作序。 及《历代君臣括要图》，并行于世。 见江用设厅碑石，出《虚父子传》及《本宫记》 刘祖师立化 本官道士刘大彰，字开祖，江州湖口人，生于元丰癸亥岁。 幼肄业山中，徽庙朝试经为道士，礼杨公彝为师。 建炎兵变，避地鄱阳，后归乡省亲，传闻本宫悉罹兵焰，进退不能，遂与徒弟骆守明就潮邑东南隅得逃亡屋而居之，崇奉采访香火，泣而告之故，誓愿阐扬道教，重立玄功。 刘为人纯谨，奉身无长物，交游不杂，乡曲称之。 济人利物、其道甚#3行，遂撒茅居而鼎新，扁曰龙德庵。 即今西湖道院。 士民皈向，香火日隆。 时刘年已耄，貌若处子。

Several years later, a traveler returned from Shu and said: "Huang Fengzi is now in Shu. We met in Chengdu, and he entrusted me with this letter for his family." The assembly was skeptical. Upon opening the letter, it bore the name of a Daoist mother who had perished in the chaos of war. They then opened the coffin to inspect it, finding only his garments and shoes.

From *Records of the Yellow Perfected One*

**Liu Xugu’s Seated Transformation**
The abbey’s Daoist Liu Lie, styled Xuguzi, was born under an auspicious dream his mother had received. As he grew, he harbored lofty aspirations, studying in the mountains and keeping his associations pure. Nobles and officials marveled at his countenance, which bore the unspoiled air of high antiquity, and declared him a vessel of the Dao for future generations.

In the sixth year of the Shaoxing era, he built a thatched hermitage and named it *Zhenyi* ("True Unity"). Daily, he sat in meditation, perusing the Daoist canon and histories, committing all to memory at a glance. Scholars and officials sought his acquaintance. Master Zhu of Hui’an (Zhu Xi) discussed the *Book of Changes* with him, debating the principles of returning elixirs. A poem reads:

*Carefully reading the hundred chapters on returning elixirs,*
*The master’s brush, too, spoke at length.*
*The primal mechanism lies hidden in scriptures’ search,*
*Yet the supreme principle dwells in the space between eye and lash.*
*One horse may yet be harnessed for my journey,*
*Five sprouts should grow from my own garden.*
*Tomorrow, sober, I descend the mountain—*
*With whom shall I discuss these words again?*

Zhang Xiaoxiao (Zhang Jiucheng) left a poem upon their first meeting. Other verses praised his retreat:

*A blessed land conceals a lesser grotto-heaven,*
*Where immortals refine their spirits in seclusion.*
*Only Xugu finds delight in this realm,*
*Mastering the fire’s timing in perfect accord with nature.*

Ministers Luo Dian, Wang Yan, Cao Xun, Zhou Shun of Fengxi, and Yue Fu of the Ministry of Rites—all renowned figures—visited to discuss the *Book of Changes* and exchanged fine verses. These are recorded in *Anthology of Eminent Worthies of This Abbey, Vol. 2*.

By the first year of the Longxing era, he had completed commentaries on the *Zhouyi* and *Liuren*, distilling their mechanisms into a single work. He journeyed to the capital to present it. The emperor summoned him for audience, inquired about the Dao, and hosted a banquet in his honor. His poems—*At the Imperial Command at Sanmao Abbey*, *Giving Thanks for the Gift of Wine*, and *Petitioning to Return to the Mountains*—are preserved in his collected works.

Later, he dwelled in the mountains for over a decade. In the ninth year of the Qiandao era, in the sixth month, he abstained from food for over forty days, drinking only jade-like water. On the fourteenth day of the seventh month, he personally delivered twenty-five volumes of *Dengzhen Yinjue* and nine volumes of *Shangjing* to the wooden repository of the abbey’s records. The next day, on the Zhongyuan Festival, he left a final poem and ode in his own hand, which read:

*Xuguzi, about to shed his form and abandon the world,*
*Sweeps away worldly ties to hasten toward the vast expanse of mist and clouds,*
*There to merge with the Dao in profound unity.*

On the sixteenth night, he walked under the moon to the summit of Mount Lu’s Keniu Cave, sat in meditation, and transformed.

His works—*A Hundred Chapters on Returning Elixirs*, miscellaneous writings, poetry, *Exegesis of the Zhouyi*, and *Preface to the Mountain Studio’s Edition of the Book of Changes* by Shangshu—along with *Comprehensive Diagrams of Successive Dynasties’ Rulers and Ministers*—circulated widely. An inscription by Jiang Yongshe in the hall’s stele records this, drawn from *Biographies of the Xugu Father and Son* and *Records of This Abbey*.

---

**The Founding Master Liu’s Transformation**
The abbey’s Daoist Liu Dazhang, styled Kaizu, was a native of Hukou in Jiangzhou, born in the *guihai* year of the Yuanfeng era. From childhood, he studied in the mountains. During Emperor Huizong’s reign, he was tested on the scriptures and ordained as a Daoist, taking Yang Yiyi as his master.

When the Jianyan era’s warfare erupted, he fled to Poyang. Later, returning home to visit his parents, he heard that the abbey had been entirely consumed by flames. Unable to advance or retreat, he settled with his disciple Luo Shouming in a deserted house in the southeastern corner of Chaoyi. There, they reverently maintained the incense and offerings of the Visitation Hall, weeping as they recounted their plight and vowing to propagate the Daoist teachings and restore its profound merit.

Liu was a man of pure integrity, owning no excess possessions, and keeping his associations unsullied. The villagers praised him. His Way flourished as he aided others and benefited all things. He tore down the thatched hut and rebuilt it anew, naming it *Longde Hermitage*—the present-day Xihu Daoist Abbey. Scholars and commoners turned to him in devotion, and the incense offerings grew daily.

By then, Liu was already advanced in years, yet his appearance remained as youthful as a maiden’s.
