One morning, he rose at dawn, bathed, changed his robes, and recited the *Scripture of Salvation for All*. When he finished, he summoned his disciple to his side and spoke to him of the Dao of transcending life and death. Then, with composure, he said: "Tend to the incense and offerings." He stood, and in that moment, transformed. His countenance remained as though alive, and those who witnessed it gathered like a wall.

*From the Annals of the Original Abbey: The Seated Transcendence of Patriarch Luo*

Daoist Luo Shouming of the Original Abbey, styled Deguang, was the foremost disciple of Liu Dazhang. Born in the Jiawu year of the Zhenghe era in Pengze of Jiangzhou, he followed his master in fleeing to Poyang during the Jianyan period, returning with him to their hometown. Upon hearing that the Original Abbey had been reduced to ashes, he and his master took residence in Longde Hermitage. His Dao was the familial transmission of the robe and bowl. Daily, he purchased creatures of flight and fin to set them free, never faltering in this practice.

One day, gravely ill, he summoned his five disciples—Yu Huaide, Yang Huaiyu, Li Huaizhi, Pan Huaixin, and Liu Huainen—and took up his brush to write a verse. Continuing, he said: "When I am sick, it is not inauspicious; when I speak of death, it is not death. If you encounter the Perfected Lü, then it is my good fortune." The original manuscript remains preserved in the Original Abbey.

Before long, his illness abated, and he returned to the abbey. There, on the former site of the Yellow Perfected’s sanctuary, he established a new Daoist cloister, naming it *Yangzheng Hermitage*. Taking the Yellow Perfected’s Daoist title, it was later renamed *Yellow Immortal Abbey*.

Patriarch Luo lived to a great age. Each day, he burned incense and recited scriptures, never engaging in frivolous associations. One day, he entered the hall, arranged his robe, and sat in full-lotus posture. As the assembly began their meal, he remained motionless. Upon closer inspection, he had already transcended in seated meditation. Truly, this fulfilled his words of "inauspicious sickness and auspicious death." How extraordinary!

The following day, a resident of West Lake dreamed of the Patriarch clad in purple, preceded by two azure-clad attendants bearing ceremonial staffs. He recognized the inscription above: "Immortal Official of Huotong Grotto-Heaven." Patriarch Luo was interred to the left of the abbey. The abbey’s overseer, Hu Baoqing, lifted the coffin and declared: "Do not disturb his truth with chaos, nor obstruct his Dao with wealth and honor." Though he left no miraculous form to abide in the world, he achieved the merit of liberation through seated transcendence.

The former hermitage at West Lake flourished with incense offerings, surpassing all former days.

*From the Annals of the Original Abbey: Record of Facts Concerning the Visitation Perfected Lord of Mount Lu’s Taiping Xingguo Abbey, Scroll Five—End.*

chunks.original_text: ＃１『户』原作『尸』，据文义改。 ＃２『诗』原作『恃』，据文义改。 ＃３『甚』原作『其』，据文义改。 ＃４『坐』一原作『生』，据文义改。 庐山太平兴国宫采访真君事实卷之六 碑记类 九天使者庙碑并序 斩州黄梅县束山衡门之下草莽臣李沘撰 按，江州德安县抚州太守王阮录寄事实云：唐李沘有学不仕，至开元中，明皇梦神人称庐山使者，求立庙。 韶刺史独孤正营建，下诸州，令所在学士制使者碑文，凡作者六百八十一人，独此文入用，韶召不赴。 本宫旧记所刊，才五百五十一字。 淳佑乙巳，中书程沧洲於秘书省得全文，凡一干七百七十二字。 但沘此字异，今两存之，余见程中书跋文。 伏稽诸文易曰．．一阴一阳之谓道，阴阳不测之谓神。 惟道也，生三混成洞微於变化。 惟神也，得一而妙蓄秘於恬冥。 钦若太元，遐微妙有，运陶甄之极，不独尊欤。 后唐累圣，光华大明终始，陆曦阳之午，廓照瑶京； 操元命之符，铭昌鼎筹。 白云孤峙，时望高丘； 紫黑千龄，日飞函谷。 我开元神武皇帝，圆灵受卷，方舆龙秘，握玄珠之妙，捐可宝之珍，演至道於希夷，科杂法之凝滞，乃圣一也。 於穆祀典，清庙缴教，孝友光明，天地化仰，乃神二也。 剑戟之器，返於三农，弧矢之威，神断六合，乃武三也。 察时变者，观乎天文，人习凡庸，无阶测圣，乃文四也。 故冲精象外，高视鸿名，勖荐河图，灵朝海若，尧心摄照，顾言荃於几莲，轩目司明，屈旌乘於茨院。 所以虞环益地，夏玉从天。 纳殊尽於西王，展告成於束后。 五龙推纪，迈梁甫之高曾，八骏巡游，陋昆墟之彻疏。 昭回上转，山岳下腾，列圣攸居，通仙福会。 文皇质义，武帝佩图，至道之兴，其来尚矣。 自华封献寿，圣德殆年，金格传书，珠流味液，公主以天慈入道，抱化芙蓉，秘监以王子出家，调芳芝木。 北玄着列仙之想，南丹希至学之因，圣绪无为，斯其有作，乃卷群岳； 真君道府，光启祠室，幽赞神宗。 青城、庐岳二山者，佐命群峰之望也。 丈人仙录，秘谛真君，使者灵司，孔昭冥察。 名书五法，举亚三魔。 痛泄崇峦，异弗骞於物阜，寒暑穹谷，将必顺於人时。 开元十九年八月二十一日，降明旨日：青城山丈人庙，庐山使者庙，宜准五岳真君庙例。 抽德行道士五人焚修供养，仍委所管，拣择灼然道行者安置真年，名申所由，救置庙使，内供奉将使者真图建立祠庙，拜章醮，行道设斋，使大供道观。 法师张平公，粤自秦京，宣猷江服，焕丹青之饰，锡玄札之仪。 驷传光临，云岩皎色。 使持节江州项军事、守州刺史独孤正，重镇柴桑，孚谣积补，时观武库，代伏文确，经始干城，全摹益厉，崇规逸丽，壮思逾纷。 朝散大夫行长史杨楚玉、行司马皇甫楚玉、浔阳县令魏昌等，恭惟圣善，式议灵场，道俗虔精，冥休拥异。 爰初筑土，则雨霾烟蟑俄顷仲立，而色霁霞标。 宝龟奠臬之辰，金虹驿程之际，阴蒙疗密，黜晦遗交，注想玄空，肃思皇道，芬芳载洁，章醮翘襟，六虚窈冥，一夕融朗。 半空之上，忽吐神辉，缀灼九激，顺扬千仞，案寮率扑，人吏并观。 昔天灵降周，以云门舞奏； 神光烛汉，以大一登里。 然北陆气交，南州焕变，物委霜霰，人嗟冱寒。

**Stele Inscription for the Temple of the Nine Heavens Envoys, with Preface**

*Composed by Li Chi, a humble scholar of the Eastern Mountains of Huangmei County in Qizhou*

According to the *Record of Facts* sent by Wang Ruan, Prefect of Fuzhou and former resident of De’an County in Jiangzhou: During the Kaiyuan era, the Tang Emperor Minghuang dreamed of a divine being who called himself the "Envoy of Mount Lu" and requested the establishment of a temple. Imperial edicts were issued to prefectures, commanding local scholars to compose stele inscriptions for the Envoy. Of the 681 authors, only this text was selected for use. Yet when summoned, the author did not attend. The original inscription in the abbey’s records contained only 551 characters. In the fifth year of the Chunyou reign (1315), Minister Cheng Cangzhou of the Secretariat recovered the full text—1,772 characters in total. However, the character *chi* (沘) here differs from the original, so both versions are preserved. For further details, see Minister Cheng’s postscript.

We reverently examine the classics: The *Book of Changes* states, *"The interplay of yin and yang is called the Dao; the unfathomable workings of yin and yang are called the divine."* The Dao gives birth to the Three, blending and evolving in profound transformation. The divine, attaining unity, mysteriously abides in tranquil obscurity. How majestic is the Great Origin, its distant subtleties transcending all! It governs the utmost of creation and transformation—how could it not be supremely venerated?

In the Later Tang, successive sagely emperors radiated great brilliance from beginning to end. At the noon of Lu Xi’s yang, their light illuminated the jade capital; wielding the mandate of primal destiny, they inscribed prosperity upon the tripod’s tally. White clouds stood solitary in lofty peaks, while purple auroras spanned a thousand ages, and the sun soared through the Han Valley.

Our Emperor of Divine Martiality in the Kaiyuan era, encompassing the heavens and receiving the celestial mandate, held the profound mystery of the Dark Pearl and cast aside treasured riches. He expounded the supreme Dao in the realm of the formless and untraceable, dissolving the stagnation of miscellaneous doctrines—this is the first mark of sageliness. In the reverent rituals of the ancestral temple, he purified teachings, his filial piety and fraternal love shining brightly, so that heaven and earth looked up in emulation—this is the second mark of divinity. He returned the instruments of war to the three agricultural seasons, and with the might of bow and arrow, the divine judged the six directions—this is the third mark of martial prowess. Discerning the changes of the times through celestial patterns, while common people remained mired in mediocrity, none could ascend to his sagely insight—this is the fourth mark of civil wisdom.

Thus, his spirit soared beyond forms, his gaze fixed upon lofty renown. He exhorted offerings to the *River Chart*, and the numinous paid homage to the Sea Lord. The heart of Yao was illuminated, as if perceiving the subtle signs of the lotus stalk; the eyes of the Xuanyuan Emperor governed brightness, bending the banner to the thatched courtyard. Therefore, Yu expanded the land, and Xia received jade from heaven. He received the rare treasures of the Queen Mother of the West and presented his accomplishments to the Eastern Empress. The Five Dragons advanced the calendar, surpassing the lofty lineage of Liangfu; the Eight Steeds roamed in majesty, shaming the crudeness of Kunlun’s peaks. The celestial vault revolved above, mountains and hills surged below, while the successive sages dwelled in communion with the immortals, their blessings converging.

Emperor Wen embodied righteousness, Emperor Wu bore the celestial chart—the flourishing of the supreme Dao has a long and venerable history. Since the blessings of the Hua region were offered, sagely virtue has endured through the ages. Golden tablets transmitted scriptures, and pearls flowed with the essence of nectar. The princess, through heavenly compassion, entered the Dao, embracing transformation like the lotus; the imperial librarian, as a royal prince, left the household, cultivating the fragrant zhi and mu herbs. The Northern Mystery inspired thoughts of the immortal ranks, while the Southern Elixir sought the causes of supreme attainment. The sagely lineage, though devoted to non-action, found its expression here, gathering the sacred peaks. The abodes of the Perfected Lords and the palaces of the Dao shone forth, their temples established to secretly assist the divine lineage.

Among the two mountains, Qingcheng and Mount Lu, stand as the foremost of the peaks that aid the mandate. The *Records of the Immortal Elder* and the *Secret Teachings of the Perfected Lord*, the numinous offices of the Envoys, are clearly discerned in the unseen. Their names inscribed in the Five Methods, they rise above the Three Demons. Though the towering peaks may suffer erosion, they do not falter in their abundance; though the valleys endure cold and heat, they invariably align with the seasons of humanity.

On the twenty-first day of the eighth month in the nineteenth year of the Kaiyuan era (731), a resplendent edict was issued: *"The Temple of the Elder of Qingcheng Mountain and the Temple of the Envoy of Mount Lu shall follow the precedent of the Five Sacred Peaks’ Perfected Lords’ Temples. Five virtuous Daoist priests shall be selected to perform rituals and offerings. The local authorities shall choose those of evident Daoist attainment to serve in perpetuity. Their names shall be reported through the proper channels, and temple envoys shall be appointed. Within the temples, the true portraits of the Envoys shall be established, and rituals of memorial, jiao offerings, and fasting shall be conducted, ensuring grand observances in the Daoist abbeys."*

Master Zhang Pinggong, hailing from the Qin capital, proclaimed the Dao’s principles in the Jiang region. His temple was adorned with resplendent colors, and he was bestowed with the rites of dark tablets. Arriving in a four-horse carriage, his light illuminated the cloudy cliffs.

Du Hu Zheng, Military Commissioner of Jiangzhou and Prefect of the region, governed Chaisang with steadfast virtue, his reputation long established. Observing the armory of the times, he inherited the firmness of literary tradition. He began the construction of the fortress city, his efforts ever more vigorous, his grand designs surpassing all in elegance, his ambitions flourishing in abundance.

Yang Chuyu, Gentleman for Court Audiences and Acting Prefectural Administrator; Huangfu Chuyu, Acting Prefectural Marshal; and Wei Chang, Magistrate of Xunyang County—all revered the sagely goodness and deliberated upon the sacred precinct. Daoists and laypeople alike devoted themselves with utmost sincerity, their hidden blessings gathering in marvel.

At the outset of the earthworks, a rain of dust and haze arose, yet in an instant, the skies cleared, and rosy clouds adorned the horizon. When the auspicious tortoise was set to establish the foundation, and the golden rainbow spanned the journey, the gloom of yin dissipated, and the remnants of darkness were dispelled. Gazing into the mysterious void, they reverently contemplated the imperial Dao. Fragrance filled the air, purity prevailed, and the rituals of memorial and jiao offerings lifted their spirits. The six directions were profound and obscure, yet in a single night, all became radiant.

Suddenly, from the midst of the empty sky, a divine radiance burst forth, its brilliance adorning the ninefold streams and illuminating the thousand-fathom heights. The officials prostrated themselves, and the people and clerks all beheld the spectacle. In ancient times, when the celestial spirits descended upon Zhou, they were greeted with the *Cloud Gate* dance; when the divine light shone upon Han, the *Great Unity* ascended the inner chamber. Yet here, as the qi of the northern lands converged, the southern realm transformed in splendor. Though frost and sleet weighed upon the land, and the people lamented the bitter cold...

chunks.original_text: 使法师恬恳仙庭，凭威国命，故玄冬易暖，朱景晴晖，畅以幽明，优乎力没，并利攸往，咸欣子来。 便卜胜郊，遂辄灵域。 腾俯找岭，郁翠松岩。 召断郢门，倨材荆岫。 疏峻槭，缭长垣。 红壁列钱，丹楹绣础。 三问四表，炳绘文棍； 八维九隅，悬锂镂槛。 虹梁亘解，风牖承楣。 倒井叶藓，芳坛竹扫。 银铺月晓，瑶虞霜开。 至若神理全幽，真容罕测，夫其秘状，远降使司，盖考三仙之图，不於九牧之鼎。 激姿粉垩，备质光妍。 忽想冥标，灵伴瑞表，工徒罄想，殊思感通。 斋室盟祠，既优如在，电旌霞筛，时扬羽仪，列冠名山，礼均行潦，覃董紫极，供养黄冠，玉釜常煎，金炉永艺，牲栓草享，鸾凤于飞，露抱神翁，星临委女。 清吹洞唱，天渚匏瓜之津； 匹水仙宫，海曲蓬莱之岛。 龙酿鹤翕，飘颤净戒之庭； 师子辟邪，耀跃精思之地。 珠幡卫食，琼盖持舆。 法供天厨，六时朝念； 真经云帐，万劫修行。 弗前茅茨，明代久彰於克俭； 经营梓匠，神理邈尊於宠光。 圣渥堂闱，灵栖窟宅。 谒来提福，不亦宜乎。 冬十有二月，司存式命毕钩绳也。 玄门道士章冲寂等抱教五千，齐罐亿兆，历仙阶而仰止，攀睿算以驱诚。 天使愿奉於雕镌，心存魏阙； 法众希凭於瑰瑛，道在昊岑。 春水桃花，迷源遂远，幽林杏坞，胜地非遥。 伏贺天休，敢述颂日： 道秘重冥，神幽福庭。 三景运极，五岳栖灵。 其真有物，厥妙无形。 理则恍惚，功惟泰宁。 於赫皇极，照融亭造。 睿握玄珠，祥丕大宝。 苍垠集既，紫云宗道。 至享百神，探因五老。 乃卷崇山，岳灵之秘。 三象浮精，十华仙口#1。 威痛云雨，神存天地。 法象昭凝，真图炳粹。 幸明德之嘉运，降幽祠之宠章。 扈仙仪兮肃肃，晔瑞彩兮煌煌。 烁琳宫之夕照，拂琪木之神光。 雕辉兮翠辈，玉釜兮调香。 撷五芝於秀愕，搴八桂於飞梁。 龙吟凤舞天路长，青云衣兮白霓裳。 节空歌於瑶磬，臻羽谛於琼浆。 冥激兮福宇，彩眇兮神极。 牵匹水之布流，睨烟炉之绮色。 留鹤语於千载，翕鸾装兮一息。 绛河真毋将易逢，碧海仙姑森难测。 恭至道於三五，奉休符兮万亿。 纪真石於名山，壮洪规於帝力。 唐开元二十年壬申，正月乙巳朔，二十五己巳树。 跋唐九天使者庙碑 圆覆在上，苍苍正色，而一气之翕辟，万有之生化，莫知其然而然。 孰主张是，孰纲维是？ 即儒者之说，形体谓之天，主宰#2谓之帝，析理精矣。 道家书乃明言所以为主宰者，维皇上帝，高居宸极，统御三界，分职而理，犹世之帝王。 内有宰辅百执事，外有方岳候藩，丝牵绳联，生杀赏罚，各率其属，以为民极者。 幽显一道，斯固可以类推，两儒者不欲言之，难乎为言也q 青城、潜、庐三山真君，降灵显化，防有唐之开元。 而推原本始，盖与无极道祖同胚胛於太元，司生化於品汇，应运御世，保国卫民，可以世数之久近，后先之彰晦而臆度哉？ 绍兴问，九江通守叶义问纂《感应记》中有唐李毗庙碑。 近岁道流搜补放失，首载临川故守王阮录寄事实一纸，谓开元庙成，诏刺史独孤正访诸工丈辞者制碑以进，几六百八十一士，谓李妣文称旨，命召固辞。 阮说叉有据。 沘毗字异，岂旧记误耶？ 颂文葩藻可观，是必栖道不仕，尝窕心于真诠者。

Thus the Master of the Law, with earnest devotion, ascended the immortal courts, wielding the authority of the state’s mandate. Thereupon, the depths of winter grew mild, and the crimson sun shone bright in a cloudless sky, harmonizing the hidden and the manifest, and bestowing ease upon those who toiled unto exhaustion. All things turned to advantage, and all rejoiced in the advent of blessings.

They then divined a propitious site in the sacred outskirts and forthwith established a numinous precinct. The peaks rose and fell like undulating ridges, their verdant pines and cliffs steeped in emerald hues. They summoned timber from the gates of Ying and drew fine wood from the Jing Mountains’ ravines. They hewed the towering cliffs and encircled the grounds with long walls. Vermilion walls stood in ordered rows like strings of coins, while cinnabar pillars rested upon embroidered plinths. Three chambers and four boundaries were adorned with resplendent paintings and carved beams; the eight directions and nine corners bore suspended bells and intricately wrought balustrades. Rainbow beams spanned the halls, and wind-borne windows supported the lintels. Inverted well-tiles bore patterns of moss, and fragrant altars were swept clean by bamboo brooms. Silver knockers gleamed in the moonlight, and jade hooks opened with the frost. As for the divine principle in its full mystery and the true countenance rarely glimpsed—such secret forms, far removed from mortal governance, were transmitted to the officiating bureau. For even when consulting the charts of the Three Immortals, one finds no likeness in the Nine Cauldrons of the provinces. Their radiant forms, painted in white and powdered hues, embodied both substance and luminous beauty. Suddenly, as if in a vision of the unseen, the divine companions manifested auspicious signs, and the artisans, their thoughts exhausted, were moved by communion with the numinous. Within the oratory and the altar of covenant, the presence of the spirits was so vivid that it seemed they were truly there. Lightning banners and mist-sifted rays displayed their feathered regalia. Arrayed upon the sacred mountains, their rites equaled those of the wandering streams. Extending their reverence to the Purple Ultimate, they made offerings to the Yellow-Crowned. Jade cauldrons ever simmered, and golden censers perpetually burned. Sacrificial beasts were tethered, and grass offerings prepared, while simurghs and phoenixes took flight. Dew embraced the divine elders, and stars shone upon the Weaving Maiden. Pure flutes and resonant chants echoed across the celestial isles of the gourd’s ford; the waters of the divine palace mirrored the isles of Penglai in the sea’s curve. Dragon-brewed nectar and crane-harmonized drafts wafted through the courtyards of pure precepts; lions and apotropaic beasts danced and leapt in the realms of concentrated devotion. Pearl banners guarded the repasts, and jade canopies sheltered the palanquins. The offerings of the celestial kitchens were presented in the six periods of the day; the true scriptures within cloud-like canopies were recited through ten thousand kalpas of cultivation. Unlike the thatched huts of old, whose frugality long shone in the illustrious age, the craftsmanship of carpenters and artisans exalted the divine principle, far surpassing the splendor of mere favor. The sacred grace filled the halls, and the spirits dwelled in their cavernous abodes. To come before them and invoke blessings—was this not most fitting?

In the twelfth month of winter, the overseers completed their measurements with plumb lines and cords. The Daoist adepts Zhang Chongji and others, embracing the Five Thousand Characters of the Teachings, united the multitudes in countless numbers. Ascending the immortal ranks, they gazed upward in reverence, and grasping the sagely calculations, they drove forth their sincerity. The celestial envoys wished to honor the carved and chiseled work, their hearts dwelling upon the imperial court; the assembly of the Law hoped to rely upon the splendor of the jade-like edifice, their Dao resting upon the august peaks. Peach blossoms upon spring waters obscured the source, leading one ever farther, while the secluded groves and apricot dells lay not far from this blessed site. Prostrating in celebration of the celestial favor, they dared to compose this eulogy:

The Dao is profound and deeply mysterious,
The divine abides in the court of blessings.
The Three Luminaries govern the extremes,
The Five Peaks cradle the spirits.
Its truth is a thing unto itself,
Its subtlety formless.
Its principle is elusive,
Its merit supreme tranquility.
O majestic imperial ultimate,
Illuminating and harmonizing creation!
The sagely grasp the Dark Pearl,
Auspicious and grand, the Great Treasure.
The azure expanse gathers in completion,
The purple clouds honor the Dao.
Offering to the hundred spirits,
Delving into the origins of the Five Elders.
Thus they unrolled the sacred mountains,
The secrets of the mountain spirits.
The Three Images float in essence,
The Ten Flowers speak from immortal mouths.
Their might shakes the clouds and rain,
Their spirit pervades heaven and earth.
The dharma-image shines in clarity,
The true chart gleams in purity.
Fortunate in the auspicious era of bright virtue,
They descend in honor upon the hidden shrine.
Escorting the immortal rites with solemnity,
Resplendent in auspicious splendor!
The evening glow of the jade palace glows,
The divine light of the gem trees brushes.
Carved radiance in emerald ranks,
Jade cauldrons blend their fragrance.
Plucking the five sacred herbs from verdant peaks,
Gathering the eight cassia boughs from soaring beams.
Dragons chant and phoenixes dance along the long celestial path,
Clad in robes of azure clouds and white rainbows.
Striking the jade chimes in empty song,
Arriving at the feathered truths with nectar fine.
Mysteriously stirring the abode of blessings,
In subtle hues ascending the divine ultimate.
Drawing the flowing waters of the Matching Stream,
Gazing upon the brocade colors of the incense burners.
Leaving the cranes’ words for a thousand years,
The simurghs’ adornments gathered in a single breath.
The True Mother of the Crimson River is seldom met,
The Immortal Maidens of the Azure Sea are fathomless in their majesty.
Revering the perfect Dao of the Three and Five,
Offering the symbols of fortune in countless myriads.
Inscribing the true stone upon the famous mountains,
Magnifying the grand design through imperial power.

In the twentieth year of the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, the cyclical year *renshen*, on the twenty-fifth day of the first month, the first day of which was *yisi*, the stele was erected.

**Postscript to the Stele of the Tang Envoys of the Nine Heavens**

Above, the vault of heaven arches in its true azure hue, and through the gathering and dispersing of the single *qi*, the myriad beings are born and transformed, none knowing how or why. Who governs this? Who binds it together? According to the Confucians, the physical form is called "Heaven," and the ruling power is called "Emperor," a distinction finely parsed. The Daoist texts, however, explicitly declare that the sovereign power is the August Thearch, who dwells on high in the celestial pole, governing the Three Realms, apportioning duties, and ruling—much like the emperors and kings of the world. Within, they have ministers and a hundred officials; without, they have regional lords and feudal vassals. Bound by silken threads and corded ties, they wield life and death, reward and punishment, each leading their subordinates to establish the ultimate standard for the people. The hidden and the manifest follow a single Dao, and this can indeed be inferred by analogy. Yet the Confucians, reluctant to speak of it, find it difficult to articulate.

The True Lords of Mount Qingcheng, Mount Qian, and Mount Lu descended in numinous manifestations during the Kaiyuan era of the Tang. Tracing their origins, they share the same primordial essence with the Limitless Dao Ancestor, governing the transformations of the myriad beings, responding to the times to rule the world, and protecting the state and its people. Can one truly gauge their duration by the length of dynasties, or their prominence by the obscurity or clarity of their appearances?

During the Shaoxing era, Ye Yiwen, the Prefect of Jiujiang, compiled the *Records of Responses*, which included the Tang stele of Li Pi’s temple. In recent years, Daoist adepts have sought to restore lost texts, beginning with a single sheet of recorded facts sent by Wang Ruan, the former Prefect of Linchuan. It states that upon the completion of the Kaiyuan temple, an edict was issued to the Prefect Du Guzheng to seek out the artisans and record their measurements for the inscription of a stele, which was then presented to the throne. Among the 681 scholars, Li Pi’s text was deemed most fitting, and he was summoned, though he firmly declined. Wang Ruan’s account seems well-founded. Yet Li Pi’s courtesy name was *Yi*—could the old records be in error? The eulogy’s florid prose is indeed impressive, suggesting that its author, though dwelling in the Dao and not in office, once delved deeply into the true teachings.

chunks.original_text: 我国家肇开景运，跻世隆平，易庙扁为观、为官，若节春秋，有严典祀。 逮中兴南渡，真君之助顺福善，灵响交着。 上御极，文明稽古，躬宝慈俭，属运度参，会边尘绎骚，用震于渊衷，为生灵请命，秘祝书名，惟谨是至。 前管辖上清法师熊守中，既承诏祇厥事，乃簪质伏阙下，丐为真君加徽号，上乃亲书三清阁三大字以赐。 有旨，即九天探访应元保运之下加二字日妙化。 臣公许秉笔直西省，演纶非村，惧无以发扬圣意。 守中属书李沘之文，拜识本末，庸侈上赐．o狄难孔难，岷潜二福地氛视惨结，独康庐穹爽屹峙，此固圣上所以恳恳乎钦崇之典、桧攘之供，于以宁国步、拯民痪。 与夫楼居甲帐之蛉瞻、露台仙掌之崇侈、穷人欲而妄希仙事者，可同日语哉？ 呜呼，阳九百六，运度有常，虽帝王盛时所不能免。 然天道好生，岂忍其赤子之刘於锋镝？ 而人君者代天以子万姓，体天之生育长养为心，则兵祸可得而戢，和气可得而致也。 不然，保制劫运，开度群品，何以见于龙汉、赤明之宝篆玉章，而近续乃命于天，用析天永命，圣经垂训，何乃冥契若此乎？ 今圣上忧勤思治，心与天通。 否倾叉亨，春顾有属。 岂惟丹梯、天柱尽扫退於搀拾，五老、崇山长屏蔽於江游？ 将际天所覆，悉主悉臣，环岳镇於四维中央，奠神鼎於荣河温洛； 车书万里，冠带百蛮，祀宋配#3天，绵载千亿。 小臣庸鄙，职在词翰，《赓车攻》、《嵩高》之雅#4，勒元和平淮之碑。 揆才非宜，尚能沘笔以俟。 淳佑元年#5，岁在辛丑，重阳节，朝奉大夫守太常少卿兼直学士院臣程公许拜手馑跋。 皇朝景德二年重修本观碑铭 周起撰
chunks.translated_text:
In the founding of Our August Dynasty, as the celestial mandate unfolded and the realm ascended to profound peace, the ancestral temples were transformed into Daoist abbeys and halls, where seasonal rites were solemnly observed with reverence. Since the restoration and southward crossing, the divine aid of the Perfected Lord in upholding righteousness and blessing the virtuous has manifested in wondrous responses. Upon ascending the throne, His Majesty has emulated the wisdom of antiquity, embodying sacred frugality and diligence. When the cosmic cycles converged and border disturbances arose, his heart was deeply moved, and for the sake of the people’s salvation, he secretly inscribed his name in supplication with utmost sincerity.

The former overseer of the Supreme Clarity, Master Xiong Shouzhong, having received the imperial decree to attend to these matters, prostrated himself at the palace gates, entreating that an honorific title be bestowed upon the Perfected Lord. Thereupon, His Majesty personally inscribed the three characters *Three Clarities Pavilion* as a gift. An edict was issued, adding the two characters *Wondrous Transformation* beneath *Exploring the Nine Heavens, Responding to the Primordial, Preserving the Mandate*.

Your servant, Xu, entrusted with the brush in the Western Bureau, though unworthy of such a task, feared he could not adequately convey the imperial intent. Master Shouzhong then presented Li Pi’s text, and upon examining its origins, I have humbly expanded upon the imperial bestowal. Amid the dire calamities of the Rong and Di rebellions, when the two blessed lands of Min and Qian were shrouded in ominous vapors, only Mount Lu stood majestic and serene—this is why His Majesty has so earnestly upheld the rites of veneration and the offerings of exorcism, thereby securing the nation’s stability and relieving the people’s suffering. How can this be compared to the extravagant displays of those who dwell in towering pavilions or erect palatial halls, vainly seeking transcendence while indulging their desires?

Alas! The cycles of fortune—nine calamities in a hundred and six—are ordained by destiny, even the most prosperous of emperors cannot escape them. Yet the Dao of Heaven cherishes life; how could it bear to see its children slaughtered by the sword? The sovereign, acting as Heaven’s deputy to nurture the myriad people, must embody Heaven’s generative, nourishing, and sustaining virtues. Thus, the scourge of war may be quelled, and harmonious qi may be summoned. Otherwise, how could the preservation of the kalpa’s destiny and the salvation of all beings be revealed in the sacred scriptures of the Dragon Han and Crimson Brilliance eras? Yet in recent times, such decrees have emanated from Heaven itself, seeking to prolong the celestial mandate. The sacred teachings have been transmitted—how could they align so perfectly with the unseen will of Heaven?

Now, His Majesty, diligent in governance and ever mindful of order, communes with the mind of Heaven. As adversity gives way to prosperity, the signs of renewal are manifest. Shall not the celestial ladders and towering peaks be swept clean of all obstructions? Shall not the Five Elders and Mount Song stand as eternal guardians along the river’s course? Under the vast canopy of Heaven, all—whether ruler or subject—shall be encompassed, with the sacred mountains anchoring the four directions and the central realm. The divine tripod shall be established upon the Rong and Wen rivers; the chariots and script shall extend for ten thousand li, and the hundred barbarians shall be adorned in courtly attire. The sacrifices to the Zhou shall be matched with those to Heaven, and the dynasty’s legacy shall endure for a thousand myriad generations.

This humble servant, though unworthy, holds office in the realm of letters. Following the elegance of *The Chariot’s Advance* and *Lofty Mount Song*, I have inscribed this stele to commemorate the era of primordial peace. Though my talents are ill-suited to the task, I have taken up the brush in emulation of Li Pi, awaiting further instruction.

In the first year of the Chunyou reign, the year *xinchou*, on the Double Ninth Festival, Cheng Xu, Gentleman for Court Audiences, Guardian of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, and Academician of the Institute of Academicians, bows in reverence and respectfully appends this postscript.

*Stele Inscription for the Renovation of This Abbey in the Second Year of the Jingde Reign of the August Dynasty*
Composed by Zhou Qi

chunks.original_text: 臣闻两仪既分，三才定位。 高明广运，象纬列於次缠； 博厚无疆，岳读限於方域。 寒暑错综而岁功序，阴阳涎坛而神明生，式是化权，必有司牧，所以协宣上帝，垂佑下民。 粤若圣人，乃建皇极，於是陈祀典，考灵文，禳桧科教以致其诚，车服采章以辩其数。 复无方而设教，迪妙用以为宗。 崇德报功，其来尚矣。 庐山太平兴国观者，即九天使者之庙焉。 昔在有唐，开元御历，肇肝蜜於冥感，荷昭锡於至真，将叩寂於清都，乃旁询於方士。 凭兹灵岳，始建仙居。 洎上运载移，四方云扰，信灵心之有待，协冥数於昌朝。 我太祖皇帝，乘五运以天飞，抚万邦而御极。 声教覃於无外，临照被於有截。 蚓兹灵壤，实惟奥区，当九服之会同，眷百神而受职。 我太宗皇帝，握乾符，登大宝，丕变风俗，惠绥黎元。 坠典必兴，无文咸秩，总帝王之能事，推覆育之深仁。 乃眷集灵之宫，洪惟祈福之地。 特颁紫诏，爰授正名，申严如在之仪，乃锡纪年之号。 今上皇帝，诞膺真录，抚育苍黔，奉列圣之洪猷，启无疆之宝祚。 若乃自家刑国，敦厚於素风； 一日万机，忧勤於庶政。 况乎日新圣德，天纵多能，宸章焕烂於昭回，睿略怀来於寓县。 吁具每虚於听纳，需尝肃奉於孝思。 至於灵瑞纷纷，鸿禧累洽，考前编而莫纪，访博识以未闻。 斯皆掩在民谣，稔熟舆听。 凿井耕田者焉知帝力，瞻云望阙者史不绝书。 是以中外云趋，华夷麋至，率诣天阙，迭献方闻，以为奉元符，答灵命，允兹大典，天既难籍。 虽本锡於帝俞，终俯从於民欲。 於是陈法从，俨文卫，封峦肆观，方展於鸿仪； 座玉演汾，载陈於大报。 耀祖宗之丕烈，荐天地以至诚； 掩历代之宏纲，昭勒成之盛礼。 岂直竹宫望拜，方集於荣光； 桐岭顺风，始抱其颢素而巳乎。 天庆既已成矣，洪恩既已洽矣。 至於岩壑丛祠、史传遗烈，犹乃褊申杞享，特禁樵苏，况上帝之元肱、会列真之别绾。 揆日非谋於改筑，尼徒不易於前修。 爰诏侍臣，精求匠石，费从官给，事以乐成。 轩楹特启於宏规，藻绘重新於壮观； 蚬旌宝座，照耀於中围，霞被星冠，周旋於列侍。 若乃飕输戾止，羽客朝修，星坛夜烛於绛光，云驭遥闻於众圣。 当三元之令序，问六气以雍和，莫不寅奉科仪，肃陈醮席，祝皇图之睿算，祈民福於嘉生，允集棋祥，咸跻富寿。 宜兹华宇，申启灵扬，江山回抱於四封，襟带交冲於八达。 信乎神仙之窟宅，乾坤之户牖者也q 若然，则纪灵迹，刻贞泯，昭示信书，抑惟旧式。 臣滥尘近列，莫有寸长，幸奉明恩，谨为铭曰： 元后膺图，受天明命。 统御八弦，裁成庶政。 泽浸含灵，风行号令。 奉若天道，惠兹万姓。 乃见庶官，乃立民极。 修崇明杞，光昭令德。 为民祈福，俾民不戒。 官既居方，神亦受职。 蚓兹灵岳，巉．巉太虚，上真所相，仙馆攸居，江山回抱，水木扶疏，札正阴慝，此马惨舒。 道有污隆，运逢开泰。 庆浃寰中，教尊方外。 栖羽客兮精修，奉真文兮禳桧。 虽冥数之有期，示神人之交会。 占使星兮南驰，爰尼徒兮江湄。 藻绘增严兮像设，彤缕焜煌兮层墀。 瞰飞甍兮临大道，揭迭嗽兮荫华禳。 既成之兮不日，顾民力兮何知。 肃肃兮上真，盼玉宇兮重新。
chunks.translated_text:
When the Two Modes first divided and the Three Powers took their places, the vast and luminous expanse unfolded with celestial bodies arrayed in their celestial paths, while the boundless and profound earth set its mountains and rivers within their bounds. Cold and heat interwove to order the year’s labors, yin and yang intermingled to give rise to the numinous. Such is the authority of transformation, and thus there must be those who govern, to harmonize the decrees of the Supreme Emperor and bestow blessings upon the people below.

Of old, the sages established the imperial standard, instituting sacrificial rites, examining the sacred texts, exorcising misfortune through ritual and teaching to manifest sincerity, and distinguishing ranks through chariots, robes, and emblems. They spread instruction without limit and guided with wondrous efficacy as their foundation. The veneration of virtue and the repayment of merit have ever been esteemed.

The Abbey of Great Peace Flourishing Under Heaven on Mount Lu is the temple of the Messenger of the Nine Heavens. In the Tang dynasty, during the Kaiyuan reign, the throne first received mysterious inspiration and was favored with the bestowal of the Most Real. Seeking to commune with the silence of the Pure Capital, the emperor consulted the masters of the esoteric arts. Relying on this sacred mountain, they first established the abode of immortals.

As the celestial mandate shifted and the realm was thrown into turmoil, the abbey’s numinous heart awaited its time, aligning with the hidden destiny of a flourishing dynasty. Our August Ancestor, the Emperor, soared to the heavens upon the Five Movements, governing the myriad states and ascending the throne. His civilizing influence extended beyond all bounds, and his radiant governance reached to the farthest limits. This sacred land, a profound and secluded realm, stood at the convergence of the Nine Provinces, where the hundred spirits received their offices.

Our Emperor Taizong, grasping the celestial tally and ascending the great treasure, transformed customs and brought peace to the people. He revived neglected rites, ordered all matters without omission, fulfilled the duties of emperors and kings, and extended his profound benevolence in nurturing all life. Turning his gaze to this abbey of assembled spirits, a place of grand supplication for blessings, he specially issued a rescript in purple, bestowing its rightful name, reaffirming the solemnity of the rites as if the spirits were present, and granting it an era name.

Our present Emperor, having received the true record, nurtures the black-haired masses, upholds the grand designs of his sagely predecessors, and inaugurates an everlasting imperial legacy. In governing the state and the family, he reverts to the unadorned virtues of antiquity; amidst the myriad affairs of state, he labors diligently for the people’s welfare. Moreover, his sagely virtue daily renews, endowed by heaven with manifold talents. His imperial compositions shine brilliantly in the heavens, and his sagacious strategies embrace even distant lands. He humbly remains receptive to counsel and solemnly fulfills his filial piety.

As for the manifold auspicious signs and the abundant blessings that have accrued—though unrecorded in earlier annals and unknown even to the most learned—these have long been embedded in the people’s songs and familiar to all ears. Those who dig wells and till fields know not the emperor’s power, yet those who gaze at the clouds and look toward the palace gates find their deeds ceaselessly inscribed in history. Thus, from within and without, the realm hastens to the celestial court, and peoples from afar gather to present their local marvels, offering them as tokens of the Primordial Mandate and responses to the numinous decree. This is indeed a great ritual, one that heaven itself can scarcely match. Though it originates in the emperor’s assent, it ultimately defers to the people’s desires.

Thereupon, the procession of laws and the solemnity of the guards were arrayed; the sealed peaks were opened for inspection, and the grand rites were fully displayed. Jade seats were set upon the Fen River, and the great repayment to heaven and earth was solemnly performed. The glorious achievements of the ancestral emperors were illuminated, and the utmost sincerity was offered to heaven and earth. The grand principles of past ages were surpassed, and the splendor of this accomplished ritual was made manifest. Was this merely the gathering of auspicious light at the bamboo palace or the embrace of the pure and vast at the paulownia ridge? The celestial celebration was already complete, and the vast grace already pervasive.

As for the shrines nestled in cliffs and valleys and the heroic deeds left by history, offerings were still made and firewood-gathering was forbidden. How much more so for the chief ministers of the Supreme Emperor and the separate retinues of the assembled perfected? Calculating the days, there was no need for reconstruction, nor was there any reason to alter what had been done before. Thus, the emperor commanded his attendants to seek skilled artisans and stoneworkers, with expenses provided by the court, so that the work might be joyfully completed.

Pillars and beams were raised in grand design, and paintings and decorations were renewed in splendor. Banners and sacred seats gleamed within the inner precincts, while rosy clouds and starry crowns circled among the attendants. When the wind ceased and the feathered guests arrived for their morning devotions, the star altars were illuminated by crimson light at night, and the cloud chariots of the many sages were heard from afar.

During the auspicious seasons of the Three Primes, when the Six Qi harmonized, all reverently upheld the ritual codes, solemnly arraying the offerings. They prayed for the sagacious longevity of the imperial enterprise and for the people’s blessings in abundant life. Auspicious omens gathered like chess pieces, and all attained wealth and longevity.

This splendid edifice, now reopened to manifest its numinous power, is embraced by mountains and rivers on all sides, its sashes and belts intersecting at the eight thoroughfares. Truly, it is the dwelling of immortals and the gateway of heaven and earth.

Thus, to record its numinous traces and inscribe its steadfast stone, to make manifest the trustworthy record—this follows the old model. I, though unworthy, have been allowed to linger among the near ranks, possessing not an inch of talent. Yet, favored by the radiant grace, I respectfully compose this inscription:

The August Emperor receives the chart,
And heaven’s bright mandate is bestowed.
He governs the eight directions,
And orders all affairs of state.
His grace soaks all living things,
His commands spread like the wind.
He follows the Dao of heaven,
And brings blessings to the myriad people.

He appoints the many officials,
And establishes the people’s standard.
He venerates and exalts the bright sacrifices,
Illuminating his illustrious virtue.
For the people he prays for blessings,
That they may live without harm.

The officials hold their posts,
And the spirits too receive their offices.
Here upon this sacred peak,
Towering in the great void,
The perfected ones gather,
And immortals make their abode.
Mountains and rivers embrace,
Waters and trees flourish.
Rites expel yin’s darkness,
And the seasons turn in harmony.

The Dao has its rises and falls,
But the era meets with flourishing.
Blessings fill the realm,
And teachings are honored beyond its borders.
The feathered guests refine their practice,
Revering the true texts and exorcising misfortune.
Though the hidden destiny has its time,
It reveals the communion of spirits and men.

The star of the envoy hastens south,
And the river’s edge is marked by the traces of the perfected.
Ornamentation enhances the solemnity of the images,
And vermilion steps glow with layered brilliance.
Overlooking the great road from soaring eaves,
The layered towers cast shade upon the splendid halls.

Completed in no time,
Yet how could the people’s labor be known?
Solemn are the perfected ones above,
As the jade halls are renewed.

chunks.original_text: 彤霞兮转筛，皓月兮停轮。 宅灵心兮昭格，阜风俗兮和淳。 祝皇图兮万祀，熙品物兮常春。 采访殿记 朝散郎提举太平兴国观轻草 都尉赐紫金鱼袋臣熊本撰文 朝请郎充龙图阁待制知 洪州充江西铃辖南阳县 开国伯臣蔡延庆篆额 元丰四年正月乙卯，制诏中书门下：江州庐山太平兴国观九天采访使者，可进号九天采访应元保运真君。 即日中书班命于有司。 粤三日己亥权发遣江南东路转运判官臣郊直奉御香祝辞来告。 四月戊辰，入内内侍省束头供奉官臣廖维护劲书、殿榜、仙衣、幢节，即其祠奉安，又降绿章、黄素，醮於坛殿，凡二昼夜。 劝书、仙衣皆藏以宝匣，藉以文绣，绛袍裙被，以泥金云鹤为章。 榜字用金，旁有龙鸾葩花飞动之象，彩幢、瑞节、致饰蕃丽，皆出於中禁，而世所未尝见也。 於是太平冠褐之．众，与夫九江内外小大官吏，缁黄稚耋，莫不踊跃奔走，动色相贺。 乃相与涓洁，致庆成之醮于祠下，又八昼夜。 而相与言日：兹山自唐开元辛未肇建庙宇，距今三百五十有一年矣。 储休锡羡，应验昭晰。 国朝着令，春秋长吏侍祠，三岁郊礼，亦遣使告飨。 问尝有宝冠、霞衣、命圭、履袜之赐，所以答赛神既，恩亦厚矣。 今也天启嘉会，幽赞圣意，讲阔典，加隆号，礼盛文褥，盖历世所未遑者。 褒表之旨，固具载於诏书。 至於锡予之名数，告享之秩序，非刻之金石，惧无以耀四海之观而永万世之传。 谓臣尝备词掖，适莅真馆，宜有以纪一时之盛者。 窃惟圣上以鸿烈光祖宗，以达孝通神明，夤畏夙夜，思所以对三灵之休，故考礼文，正祀典，总公卿博士之议，而制旨临央焉。 至於山川神祇降依兹人者，无昔今遐迩，罔不登秩，坛场珪币，罔不盼饰。 况夫咏真之都，厘福之庭，正名於轩后，受职於太上，懿铄徽称，久郁而未章。 宜乎上心霖然发德音，下明诏而旌显之异也。 故精诚所乡，符应既至，使节南指则灵光属霄，仙殿夜闷而神乐骇听，诸福之物，可致之祥，当自此而婵见矣。 方将封泰山，勒中岳，诗大泽之广博，婵闲休於无前。 臣虽远迹于外，犹能追击壤之民，歌盛德之美蚓。 今获奉熙事，而文字颂述，固其职也，臣其敢辞。 谨拜手稽首而献诗日： 於昭颢穹卷中国兮，维宋世世迪明德兮。 丕铄睿圣绍尊极兮，文武勇智实天锡兮。 从容法宫考图籍兮，振饬万事扬幽侧兮。 风行雷动酿惠泽兮，森飞景附走夷貊兮。 气调时豫民滋殖兮，神腾鬼魅皆受职兮。 岩岩高山敞仙宅兮，总统灵官凡五百兮。 游衍陆降穷杳默兮，福善祸淫渊莫测兮。 煌煌玉书发奎画兮，进以显号冠今昔兮。 椒浆桂酒列瑶席兮，蕾买车风马来络绎兮。 上真嘉娱百神择兮，瑞福禳禳与山积兮。 天子万年庆平格兮，登封勒成耀金石兮。 子孙绳绳保千亿兮，元元何知安寿域兮。 奉安玉册记 元丰四年，神宗皇帝若日：惟江州庐山太平兴国宫九天采访使者，盖天之贵神，与世为福，而隆名徽称，历代置而不讲，甚非所以答赛神明之意，其进号应元保运真君。 遣入内内侍省束头供奉官廖维，护送金书。 殿榜拜劝文即赐焉。
chunks.translated_text:
Vermilion clouds drift like sifted silk,
And the bright moon halts its wheel.

The abode of the numinous heart shines in response,
And customs flourish in harmony and purity.
May the imperial reign endure ten thousand years,
And all beings bask in eternal spring.

*Record of the Hall of Imperial Visitation*
Composed by Gentleman for Court Audiences, Supervisor of the Temple of Great Peace and National Revival, Commandant, and Purple-Gold Fish-Bag Bearer, Your Servant Xiong Ben
Inscribed by Gentleman for Court Audiences, Drafter of the Dragon Diagram Pavilion, Prefect of Hongzhou, Commissioner of Jiangxi, and Baron of Nanyang County, Your Servant Cai Yanqing

In the first month of the fourth Yuanfeng year, on the day *yimao*, an edict was issued to the Central Secretariat and Chancellery: The Nine Heavens Imperial Visitor of the Temple of Great Peace and National Revival on Mount Lu in Jiangzhou may be advanced in title to *Nine Heavens Imperial Visitor, Responding to the Origin and Preserving the Destiny, Perfected Lord*.

On the same day, the Central Secretariat issued the decree to the relevant authorities. On the third day, *jihai*, Your Servant Jiao Zhi, Provisional Administrator of the Jiangnan Eastern Circuit Transport Bureau, reverently presented imperial incense and sacrificial prayers to make the announcement. On the day *wuchen* of the fourth month, Your Servant Liao Wei, Gentleman of the Interior for Court Service in the Palace Domestic Service, escorted the imperial calligraphy, hall plaque, immortal robes, and ritual banners and staffs to their shrine for installation. Furthermore, green memorials and yellow silk petitions were bestowed, and a jiao offering was conducted at the altar hall for two days and nights. The imperial edict and immortal robes were stored in jeweled caskets, lined with embroidered silk, and wrapped in crimson robes adorned with cloud-cranes in gold leaf. The plaque’s characters were gilded, flanked by dragons, simurghs, and blossoming flowers in flight, while the colored banners, auspicious staffs, and ornaments—all of unparalleled splendor—were bestowed from the imperial treasury, the likes of which the world had never seen.

Thereupon, the assembled multitude of the Temple of Great Peace, along with officials great and small from within and beyond Jiujiang, monks and Daoists, young and old, all leapt and hastened forth, their faces alight with joy. Together, they purified themselves and conducted a jiao ceremony of celebration beneath the shrine, lasting eight days and nights. And they spoke among themselves, saying: "This mountain’s temples were first established in the *xinshi* year of the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, three hundred and fifty-one years ago. Since then, blessings have overflowed, and responses have been clear and manifest. In our dynasty’s statutes, local officials have offered sacrifices in spring and autumn, and every three years at the suburban rites, envoys have been dispatched to announce and offer sacrifices. Yet never before have there been gifts of jeweled crowns, cloud robes, ceremonial tablets, shoes, or stockings—such bounty in gratitude for the gods’ favor is already profound. Now, however, heaven has initiated this auspicious convergence, subtly aiding the sagely will, reviving ancient rites, elevating titles, and enriching ceremonies with splendid adornments—surpassing all that has come before in generations. The intent of this exaltation is fully set forth in the imperial edict. As for the specifics of the bestowed gifts and the order of the sacrificial rites, if not engraved in metal and stone, we fear they will not dazzle the eyes of the realm or endure for ten thousand generations. Your servant, having once served in the imperial secretariat and now overseeing this sacred temple, ought to record this momentous occasion."

I humbly reflect that our sagely emperor, with great virtue, illuminates his ancestors and, with filial piety, communes with the divine. Reverent and diligent day and night, he seeks to respond to the blessings of the Three Spirits. Thus, he examines ritual texts, rectifies sacrificial canons, and consults the deliberations of ministers and scholars before issuing his decrees. As for the mountain and river spirits who descend to dwell among men, regardless of past or present, near or far, none are not accorded their proper rank, and their altars and jade offerings are all adorned with care. How much more so for this capital of the perfected, this court of fortune’s dispensation, whose name was established by the Yellow Emperor and whose office was conferred by the Most High? Its illustrious and resplendent titles have long awaited their full manifestation. It is fitting that the emperor’s heart, like timely rain, has issued this virtuous decree, and that the imperial edict below has proclaimed its extraordinary distinction. Thus, where sincerity is directed, responses duly arrive: when the imperial envoy turned south, numinous radiance touched the heavens; when the immortal hall was lit at night, divine music startled the ear. All felicitous omens and auspicious signs shall henceforth unfold in succession. Soon, the emperor will ascend Mount Tai, inscribe the Central Peak, and compose odes to the vastness of the great marshes, celebrating boundless blessings without precedent.

Though I dwell far from the capital, I am like the farmer of old, singing the praises of great virtue. Now, having been honored to partake in this glorious occasion, it is my duty to compose this text in eulogy—I dare not refuse.

With bowed head and reverent obeisance, I offer this poem:

O radiant and boundless heavens above the Middle Kingdom,
The Song dynasty perpetuates its luminous virtue.
Resplendent in sagely wisdom, it inherits the supreme throne,
Endowed by heaven with civil and martial prowess, courage and insight.
Serene in the Hall of Law, it consults the charts and records,
Rectifying all affairs and illuminating the obscure.
Like wind and thunder, its beneficent influence spreads,
And distant barbarians hasten to submit.
The qi harmonizes, the seasons prosper, and the people multiply,
While gods and spirits all receive their offices.
Majestic mountains house the immortal abodes,
Where five hundred numinous officials hold sway.
Roaming and descending through the profound and silent,
They reward the good and punish the wicked, their depths unfathomable.
Resplendent jade texts emerge from the celestial brush,
Advancing its illustrious title to surpass past and present.
Libations of peppered wine and cassia ale array the jade mats,
Phoenix carriages and wind-drawn steeds arrive in endless procession.
The perfected ones rejoice, and the hundred spirits gather,
Auspicious blessings pile high like mountains.
May the Son of Heaven live ten thousand years in blessed peace,
And his inscriptions on Mount Tai gleam upon metal and stone.
May his descendants flourish in unbroken succession,
And the common people dwell in peace and longevity.

*Installation of the Jade Register*
In the fourth year of Yuanfeng, the Emperor Shenzong decreed: "The Nine Heavens Imperial Visitor of the Temple of Great Peace and National Revival on Mount Lu in Jiangzhou is a noble spirit of heaven, bestowing blessings upon the world. Yet its exalted name and illustrious titles have been neglected through the ages, which is no way to repay the gods’ favor. Let it be advanced in title to *Nine Heavens Imperial Visitor, Responding to the Origin and Preserving the Destiny, Perfected Lord*." The Gentleman of the Interior for Court Service in the Palace Domestic Service, Liao Wei, was dispatched to escort the golden calligraphy. The hall plaque and edict of commendation were bestowed accordingly.

chunks.original_text: 先是，本观道士陶智仙诛茅创宇，发地得殖领一，破之，以土实，厥土五色，获铜泉一，其文日应元保运。 初不知其何祥也。 后二年而明诏宠加，与泉文符。 廖维即取其泉以献。 恭惟皇上南面，百神受职，天启其衷，幽冥同符，不其伟欤。 粤政和五年，今上皇帝临莅天下之十六载，以意承考，以道交神，而神祇祖考安乐之，式瞻四方，靡神不宗，乃眷南顾，惟应元保运真君陆降庭止，在帝左右，惟我神考，肇建鸿号，而典册未备，适追继承，其在我后之人，乃命有司备礼册命焉。 遣入内内侍省敦武郎黄京，奉玉册以至。 册文有日皇帝名，且日谨再拜言，其恭如是。 守土之臣与县令、祠官，跪起荐进惟谨。 厥册刻以嘉玉，贯以金滕，藉以文锦，外匣下林，彤胡扣饰，光彩焜耀，穷工极丽，不可名字。 冠褐之徒，拭目荣观，欢呼鼓舞，动色相趋。 既而奉安於别殿。

Previously, the Daoist priest Tao Zhixian of this abbey had cleared the brambles and raised its halls. Upon breaking ground, he unearthed a single vertebra, which he split open and filled with earth—there, the soil bore five colors. He also discovered a bronze spring, its inscription reading *Responding to the Origin and Preserving the Destiny*. At the time, none knew what auspicious sign this portended. Two years later, the imperial edict conferred honor, matching the inscription on the spring. Liao Wei then retrieved the spring and presented it to the court.

With reverence, we reflect: as the August Emperor faces south, the hundred spirits receive their offices. Heaven stirs his heart, and the unseen world aligns in harmony—is this not magnificent? In the fifth year of Zhenghe, the present Emperor, in his sixteenth year upon the throne, inherited the will of his predecessor and communed with the Dao to honor the gods. The divine ancestors and forebears rejoiced, gazing upon the four directions, where no spirit failed to pay homage. Turning his gaze southward, he beheld the Perfected Lord *Responding to the Origin and Preserving the Destiny* descending to the palace courtyard, standing at the Emperor’s side. It was our divine predecessor who first established this grand title, yet the ritual registers remained incomplete. Now, in succession, those who follow are commanded to prepare the rites and confer the jade register.

The court dispatched Huang Jing, Gentleman of Valor of the Palace Domestic Service, to deliver the jade register. The register’s text bore the Emperor’s name, and it read: *"With utmost reverence, we bow twice and declare..."*—such was its solemnity. The local officials, magistrates, and temple officers knelt and rose in presentation with the utmost care. The register was carved from fine jade, bound with golden clasps, wrapped in brocade, and encased in a vermilion chest adorned with forest patterns and gilded fittings, its radiance dazzling, its craftsmanship exquisite beyond description. The assembled Daoists, their eyes gleaming with pride, cheered and danced, their faces alight with joy. Thereafter, the register was enshrined in a separate hall.

chunks.original_text: 之后一年，而祠吏臣刍实来奉香火。 黄冠羽衣无虑二百辈，马行而进日：主上原道德之意，崇黄老之学，寅奉明神，聿修阔典，礼重文蔚，绝后光前。 而金石之刻不刊，无以铺张王灵，昭示来世。 非老於文学者，其谁宜为？ 臣刍曰：道士言是。 谨按《录异记》，唐开元十九年，明皇帝梦神人朱衣金冠，乘车而下日：我九天采访使者，当馆我於庐山西北隅。 明日又降於庭，命昊道子写之。 遣内供奉持使者真图，建立祠庙於山之阴，明皇帝亲书缪篆殿额以赐之，其文日：九天使者之殿。 而无采访之称，其榜固在也。 建庙之初，祥异甚伙，事见李妣庙碑、潘观《祥验记》、张景述《续得阳记》、陈舜《俞庐山记》。 故世谓使者之号。 庐山之祠，皆权舆於有唐，发祥於明帝也。 臣刍玫之不然。 按《五岳真形图》，其说日：五岳皆有佐命之山：嵩岱、华、恒以少室、武当、罗浮、括苍、地肺、女凡、河逢、抱犊为佐命，分治四岳。 惟衡岳孤峙而无辅。 故黄帝省方，南至于江，请命上帝，乃建潜、霍二山为南岳储君。 又拜青城山为丈人、庐山为使者。 则使者之名尚觅。 《真形图》虽兴於中古，然历世方士祖袭授受，束晋之世辑而成书，不可诬也。 开元中，天台司马子微谓五岳皆有上清真人降任其职，因劝五岳各立真君祠，其说盖出於《真形图》。 而开元诏书青城丈人庙、庐山使者庙，选道士奉香火，视五岳真君祠，则庐山房祀意自司马子微发之。 其肝蜜昭晰，见於梦寐，不可知也。 详玫传记，使者之神，盖德镇之高真、祝融之夹辅云。 其说见於束晋之前，而九天采访之名盖后世所加，其庙於庐山之北则自唐明皇帝始。 至南唐改号通元府，本朝太平兴国二年始以纪元赐今名。 世惑於俚俗肤浅之碑，齐诸志怪之说，弗加深考，以失事实。 故并论其本末，以桔来者之惑焉。 重和元年十一月十日建。 朝散郎提点太平兴国宫赐排鱼袋臣洪刍撰，草莽臣侍其悼篆额。 重和元年十一月十日，道士臣陈思恭、臣陶知常、臣章安主、臣沈继彬，臣李仲恭、臣萧敏修、臣高至道建。 三清阁记 大中大夫守尚书兵部侍郎

The following year, the temple officer Chai Chu arrived bearing incense and offerings. Some two hundred Daoists in feathered robes and yellow crowns advanced on horseback, declaring: *"The sovereign cherishes the intent of the Dao and virtue, venerates the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, reverently serves the radiant deities, and diligently upholds the grand rites—honoring the flourishing of culture, surpassing the past and illuminating the future. Yet the inscriptions on metal and stone, being indelible, must proclaim the majesty of the imperial spirit and manifest it for posterity. Who, if not one well-versed in literature, is fit for this task?"*

Officer Chai replied: *"The Daoists speak truly."*

*"Carefully consulting the* Record of Marvels*, in the nineteenth year of the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, the August Emperor dreamed of a divine being clad in crimson robes and a golden crown, descending in a chariot and saying: ‘I am the Nine Heavens’ Envoy of Investigation; lodge me on the northwest slope of Mount Lu.’ The next day, the deity appeared again in the palace courtyard, and the emperor commanded Wu Daozi to paint his likeness. An inner palace attendant was dispatched bearing the true portrait of the envoy, and a temple was erected on the northern side of the mountain. The August Emperor personally inscribed the殿额 in seal script and bestowed it, its text reading: ‘Hall of the Nine Heavens’ Envoy.’ Yet the title ‘Envoy of Investigation’ was omitted, though the plaque itself remains. When the temple was first built, auspicious omens abounded, as recorded in the stele of Li Bi’s temple, Pan Guan’s* Record of Auspicious Verifications*, Zhang Jing’s* Continuation of Deyang Records*, and Chen Shun’s* Yu’s Record of Mount Lu*. Thus, the world came to know the envoy’s title. The temple on Mount Lu traces its origins to the Tang and its flourishing to the August Emperor."*

Officer Chai demurred: *"This is not so. According to the* True Forms of the Five Peaks*, it is said: ‘The Five Peaks each have auxiliary mountains: Mount Song, Mount Tai, Mount Hua, Mount Heng, and Mount Heng are assisted by Shaoshi, Wudang, Luofu, Kuocang, Difei, Nüfan, Hefeng, and Baodu, which govern the four sacred peaks. Only Mount Heng stands solitary, without support.’ Thus, when the Yellow Emperor toured the realm and reached the south by the Yangtze, he petitioned the Supreme Emperor to establish Mount Qian and Mount Huo as the reserve lords of the Southern Peak. He further honored Mount Qingcheng as the ‘Elder’ and Mount Lu as the ‘Envoy.’ The title ‘Envoy’ thus predates the Tang. Though the* True Forms *emerged in the middle ages, it was compiled in the Eastern Jin from a lineage of transmitted teachings by generations of fangshi; it cannot be dismissed as false. During the Kaiyuan era, Sima Zimei of Tiantai asserted that the Five Peaks each had an Upper Clarity Perfected One appointed to their office, and he urged that each peak establish a shrine to its True Lord—this doctrine derived from the* True Forms*. The Kaiyuan edicts then designated the Elder Temple of Qingcheng and the Envoy Temple of Mount Lu, selecting Daoists to tend the incense and offerings, treating them on par with the True Lord shrines of the Five Peaks. Thus, the intent to honor the temple on Mount Lu originated with Sima Zimei. Whether the deity’s appearance in dreams was a divine revelation or mere illusion remains unknowable. Examining the records in detail, the Envoy’s spirit is likely a lofty Perfected One who stabilizes virtue, an auxiliary to Zhu Rong. This account predates the Eastern Jin, while the title ‘Nine Heavens’ Envoy of Investigation’ was a later addition. The temple on the northern slope of Mount Lu, however, began with the Tang’s August Emperor. In the Southern Tang, it was renamed the ‘Tongyuan Prefecture,’ and in the second year of the Taiping Xingguo era of our dynasty, it received its present name by imperial favor. The world, misled by vulgar and superficial steles and tales of the strange, has failed to investigate deeply, losing sight of the facts. Thus, I have set forth its origins and developments to dispel the confusion of future generations."*

Erected on the tenth day of the eleventh month of the first year of the Chonghe era.

Composed by Hong Chu, Gentleman for Court Audiences and Supervisor of the Taiping Xingguo Palace, granted the rank of *Paiyu Dai*.
The plaque inscription was written by the humble scholar Shi Qidao.
Erected on the tenth day of the eleventh month of the first year of the Chonghe era by the Daoist disciples Chen Sigong, Tao Zhichang, Zhang Anzhu, Shen Jibin, Li Zhonggong, Xiao Minxiu, and Gao Zhidao.

*Record of the Three Clarities Hall*
By the Grand Master for Court Audiences, concurrently Vice Minister of the Ministry of War, Da Zhong Dafu

The assembled Daoists, their eyes gleaming with pride, cheered and danced, their faces alight with joy. Thereafter, the register was enshrined in a separate hall.

chunks.original_text: 兼直学士院德安郡开国伯· 食邑九伯户臣吴愈撰 皇侄庆远军承官使天水郡 开国公食邑二千户实封二 伯　户　臣　裕　书 惟皇上帝弼我宋丕基。 圣天子嗣大历服，寅畏天命，宫筑敬天之台，坐列钦天之图，陆降左右，无适非天，而揭处寓敬之地，凡可以为民祈天者，亦罔不留圣心，明德恤祀，百神受职。 先是，江州太平兴国官九天采访使者灵应彰灼，列圣褒嘉，册号应元保运真君。 至是有诏，增以二字曰妙化，且亲洒三大字曰三清阁以赐之。 龙文丽空，凤诏炳世，瞻仰传诵，震于四海，於戏茂哉。 夫天得一以清，无声无臭至矣。 道家者说，上宫玉清，中宫上清，下宫太清，意者道本一元，气分三境，恍惚之中有是象耶？ 凡天下道宇，不忠面二清而事之。 宫在庐山之阴，梼焉，盗贼灾异之变咸梼焉。 责香命官，其礼逾重，无谒不获，其受命如响。 盖尝思之，惟天聪明，临下有赫，福善祸淫，亏盈益谦，要必有代天之耳目者，其殆采访之职欤。 · 上帝命之以稽察四方，亦犹人主命臣以课访天下，四时行而万物成，凡皆以佑我民耳。 惟天佑民罔极，惟后为民祈天亦无所不用其极d 此三大字之所以赐也。 阁之成以绍定壬辰夏六月甲子，上赐之以嘉熙庚子冬闰十二月甲子。 凡州之为采访使者庙。 由唐开元迄于我宋，自庙而观，自观而宫，琳馆琼房，霞集星列，徽称美号，先甲后庚，卓为天下伟观。 独三清未有殿，管辖宫事臣熊守中谓非报本返始之义也，乃即真君殿之前，建巨阁以奉焉，盖经茸八年而始成。 闳丽穹峻，称其教法，前帝后臣，神位严恤，礼备而道顺矣。 真君之灵闻天下。 我国家自六飞南渡，视庐山同五岳，凡二疆场之事梼焉，岁之水旱，莫不蹈舞，愿刻金石，丕阐上帝之，对扬天子之休，永诏万世。 臣家世于庐山下，今幸待罪禁林，执笔歌颂，职也。 谨拜手稽首，叔其事而献诗日： 庐山之胜，秀出斗旁，参于衡岳，镇束南方。 民人所瞻，神天攸宅。 责梦之祥，乃兴自昔。 惟天聪明，矜此下民。 监求其莫，恐有不闻。 惟神司之，云辖风马。 乃课乃访，周游天下。 不疾而速，不察而明。 天何言哉，民无吨呻，是为福庭。 列圣祇敬，锡羡绩祉。 有感斯应，明明我圣。 惟一乃心，不显亦临。 敢有弗钦，宝画金扁，徽称明诏。 日月之揭．’山川有耀。 邃殿在后，新阁在前，如君当御而臣仰焉。 时节冠佩，会朝帝所。 达民之情，佑我圣主。 民戴我圣，与天无极。 天佑我宋，子孙千亿。 民拜稽首，愿垂表经。 从臣刻辞，永锡休声。 宫记 岁在嘉定，戊寅清明，福州灵霍童景洞天羽人白玉蟾袂香趁敬九天御史台下。 顷焉，官牧陈至和饮以醴。 逮予之玉华也，醉屦飘忽，弗违而迈。 承遣道士陈守默、陈如一约为文以记其宫。 岂容逊也？ 其文曰：九江故郡，千古庐山，乃仙灵咏真之洞天，实紫元景曜之神府。 琅庭琛馆，隐於丹崖翠壁之问； 羽衣霓裳，混於青牛白鹿之际。 猿啼玉涧，鹤唳芝田。 地接炎衡，云连潜皖。 金童戴月，传麻姑、合早之书； 宝仗托风，赴委羽、括苍之宴。 琪花开尽，朱凤飞来五老峰； 玉井寒深，白龙涌出三峡水。 松苍石怪，襟九曲而带罗浮； 竹老草灵，辐三茅而毂大涤。
chunks.translated_text:
Herein lies the composition of Minister Wu Yu, Concurrent Academician of the Institute of Scholarly Worthies, Earl of De’an Prefecture with a fief of nine hundred households. The imperial nephew, Bearer of the Office of the Military Commissioner of Qingyuan, Duke of Tianshui Prefecture with a fief of two thousand households and a true seal of two hundred, Minister Yu, inscribed the calligraphy.

Solemn is the August Supreme Thearch, who has established the great foundation of our Song. The sagely Son of Heaven, inheriting the grand calendar, reveres the Mandate of Heaven with awe. He has erected a terrace for worshipping Heaven, arrayed the celestial charts in due order, and stationed attendants on all sides—nowhere is Heaven not present. Yet, in this hallowed place of reverence, he has not failed to turn his sagely mind to all that may serve the people in beseeching Heaven. His luminous virtue and compassionate sacrifices have caused the hundred spirits to receive their offices.

Formerly, the Nine Heavens’ Investigator of the Taiping Xingguo Abbey in Jiangzhou manifested numinous efficacy so resplendent that successive sages bestowed praise, ennobling him as the Perfected Lord of Response and Protection of the Mandate. Now, an edict has augmented his title with two more characters, calling him the Perfected Lord of Wondrous Transformation, and the Emperor himself has brushed three grand characters—*Three Clarities Hall*—to bestow upon him. Dragon-script adorns the void; phoenix-edicts illumine the age. Gazing upon them, reciting them, their renown resounds across the four seas. Ah, how splendid!

For Heaven attains clarity through the One—soundless, scentless, utterly transcendent. The teachings of the Daoist school speak of the Jade Clarity of the Upper Palace, the Supreme Clarity of the Middle Palace, and the Grand Clarity of the Lower Palace. Is it not that the Dao, originally of one origin, divides its qi into three realms, and within the nebulous and indistinct, this image arises? All Daoist temples throughout the world revere and serve these Two Clarities. The abbey lies on the northern slope of Mount Lu, where prayers are offered for deliverance from banditry, calamities, and portents. The rites of incense and official appointment grow ever more solemn; no petition goes unanswered, and its responses are as swift as an echo.

I have long pondered this: Heaven is all-hearing and all-seeing, its majesty ever manifest below. It blesses the good and punishes the licentious, diminishes the full and augments the modest. There must be those who serve as Heaven’s eyes and ears—surely this is the office of the Investigator. The Supreme Thearch commands them to scrutinize the four quarters, just as the sovereign commands his ministers to survey the realm. The four seasons proceed, and the myriad things come to fruition—all to succor our people. Heaven’s succor of the people is boundless, and the sovereign’s prayers for them spare no effort. This is why the three grand characters were bestowed.

The hall was completed in the summer, the sixth month, the *jiazi* day of the Shaoding *renchen* year. The imperial gift was conferred in the winter, the intercalary twelfth month, the *jiazi* day of the Jiaxi *gengzi* year. From the era of Kaiyuan in the Tang to our Song, all abbeys serving as Investigator temples have evolved from shrines to monasteries, from monasteries to palaces—jade halls and gem chambers arrayed like clouds and stars. Their illustrious names and honorific titles, bestowed in due order, have made them the grandest sights under Heaven. Yet, the Three Clarities had no hall of their own. Minister Xiong Shouzhong, who oversees the abbey’s affairs, deemed this contrary to the principle of repaying the origin and returning to the beginning. Thus, before the Perfected Lord’s hall, he erected a grand pavilion to enshrine them. The project spanned eight years before its completion. Magnificent and towering, it befits the teachings and laws. The Thearch precedes, the ministers follow; the divine ranks are solemn and reverent. The rites are complete, and the Dao is in harmony.

The Perfected Lord’s numinous power is renowned throughout the world. Since our imperial house crossed the river southward, Mount Lu has been esteemed alongside the Five Peaks. For all matters of the two frontiers, prayers are offered here; in years of flood or drought, none fail to dance in supplication. We wish to inscribe this in metal and stone, to exalt the Supreme Thearch’s glory, to extol the Son of Heaven’s beneficence, and to proclaim it for ten thousand generations.

My family has dwelt at the foot of Mount Lu for generations. Now, by fortune, I serve in the forbidden forest, and it is my duty to take up my brush in song and praise. With bowed head and reverent obeisance, I record these events and offer a poem:

The splendor of Mount Lu,
Rises beside the Dipper,
Vies with Mount Heng,
And guards the southeast.
The people gaze upon it,
The gods and Heaven dwell there.
Auspicious dreams of old,
Arose in ancient days.

Solemn is Heaven, all-hearing,
Compassionate to the people below.
Fearing some may go unheard,
It seeks those who serve as its ears.
The gods govern this,
Clouds harnessed, winds bridled.
They survey and investigate,
Traversing the world.
Swift without haste,
Clear without scrutiny.
Heaven speaks not,
Yet the people groan not—
This is the court of blessings.

Successive sages revered and worshipped,
Bestowing abundant grace.
Response follows feeling,
Our sagely lord shines bright.
With one heart,
He is present though unseen.
Who dares not revere?
The precious painting, the golden plaque,
The illustrious title, the luminous edict.
Sun and moon are its banners,
Mountains and rivers gleam.

The profound hall stands behind,
The new pavilion before,
As the lord presides and ministers look up.
With timely robes and sashes,
They gather at the imperial court.
Conveying the people’s sentiments,
They succor our sagely lord.
The people revere our lord,
Boundless as Heaven.
Heaven protects our Song,
With descendants a thousandfold.
The people bow in reverence,
Wishing the canon to endure.
The attending ministers inscribe these words,
To perpetuate its glorious renown.

*Record of the Abbey*
In the year *jiayin* of the Jiading era, on the Clear and Bright Festival, the Feathered Being Bai Yuchan of the Linghuo Cave Heaven in Fuzhou, having burned incense, respectfully presented himself beneath the Terrace of the Nine Heavens’ Censorate. Shortly after, Prefect Chen Zhihe offered him sweet wine. When I arrived at Yuhua, drunk and disheveled, I departed without delay. The Daoist ministers Chen Shoumo and Chen Ruyi were dispatched to request a composition to record the abbey. How could I refuse?

The text reads:
Jiangzhou, an ancient prefecture,
Mount Lu, eternal,
Is a grotto-heaven where immortals chant truths,
A divine palace where purple radiance shines.
Jade courts and gem chambers
Lie hidden amid crimson cliffs and emerald walls;
Feathered robes and rainbow skirts
Blend with the black ox and white deer.
Gibbons cry in jade ravines,
Cranes call in herb fields.
The land borders fiery Heng,
Clouds link to hidden Wan.
Golden lads bear the moon,
Delivering the scriptures of Magu and Hezao;
Jewel-staffed envoys ride the wind,
Attending the banquets of Weiyu and Kuocang.
Jade flowers bloom in full,
Crimson phoenixes alight on the Five Elders’ Peak;
The jade well runs deep and cold,
White dragons surge from the Three Gorges’ waters.
Pines are ancient, stones strange,
Girding the Nine Bends and embracing Luofou;
Bamboo is old, grasses numinous,
Hub to the Three Maos and nave to Great Di.

chunks.original_text: 北顾#6紫极，西娣青城。 域会楚昊，星分翰角。 神利鬼划，诸峰三百六十岩； 山瘦溪寒，一夜八万四千愒。 周时康子孝佩雷玺於林问，晋代许旌阳飞铁舟於木杪。 刘越掩赤城於石裹，双户凝紫金； 董奉种红杏於溪东，千朝腾碧落。 蔡李举玉棺而冲去，锺吕启金匮以相传。 马瀑溅湿刘混成之衣，虎溪淘碎陆简寂之句。 靖节酒醒，佛社亲植西天莲； 义之书忙，谷雨惜羹白露笋。 陆崇岗之胜盘，采先哲之遗踪。 剔蜗银朱网之幽，玫草碣苔碑之旧。 欲挥橡笔，以纪琳宫。 明皇开元十九年，仲秋二旬有一日，特遣殷勤之使，俾新采访之祠。 爰究其原，实基所始。 昭阳宝禁，金余惊醒梦初回； 神霄天君，玉骑迎归天欲晓。 灵符宫裹，早朝凭几谕群臣； 含元殿前，云鹤盘空辉八极。 千幢万蠢，霓旌凤盖扬晴霞； 三冕九旎，风马云车散花雨。 上清五百珠吏，握苍龙监兵之符； 太微四六瑶仙，掌金虎飞云之印。 十二溪女骑玉鳖而跨金鲸，二九江神御锦蛟而坐翠蜃。 三官执籍，校天地山海之图； 六丁操戈，守日月星辰之录。 左防观而右护法，金铁横霜； 前飞辽而后延精，锦牙耀日。 四帅麾节，驱雷公电母之群； 五岳旌旗，奋风伯雨师之阵。 九州社令把社稷城隍之书，八海龙君捧龙蛇鱼鳌之典。 司命翼驾，典禁侍轩。 箫鼓呜空，髻鬃钓天之九奏； 笙竿菩翠，阴沈禁漏之三更。 风递琵琶，宫女倚芙蓉而侧耳； 露赓声栗，仙嫔舞芍药以荐觞。 漂渺烟霞，谱出奇冥之上； 依稀纶脖，声传翠葆之前。 比登太清混元之天，亲禀五灵皇帝之劫。 丈人镇蜀，玄命治舒。 吾於康庐西北之隅，盍建九天廉访之治。 十七世之后，覃戮谷於生灵； 一二日之间，运板楠於基址。
chunks.translated_text:
Gazing northward to Purple Ultimate,
Westward twining with Green City.
This realm converges Chu and Hao,
Its stars aligned with Han and Jiao.
Spirits profit, ghosts carve—
Three hundred sixty peaks in all;
Mountains gaunt, streams chill—
Eighty-four thousand sighs in one night.

In Zhou times, Kangzi wore the thunder-seal amid the woods;
In Jin dynasty, Xu Jingyang sailed his iron boat atop the trees.
Liu Yue concealed Red City within stone,
Its double gates congealing purple gold;
Dong Feng planted crimson apricots east of the stream,
A thousand dawns ascending to the azure vault.
Cai and Li raised the jade coffin and soared away;
Zhong and Lü opened the golden casket to transmit the Way.
Ma’s waterfall drenched Liu Hunchen’s robes;
Tiger Creek eroded Lu Jianji’s verses.

Jieyuan woke from wine,
The Buddha’s community nurturing Western Heaven’s lotus;
Yizhi’s brush hastened,
Valley rain cherishing white-dew bamboo shoots.
Lu Chonggang’s peaks coil in splendor,
Tracing the traces of ancient sages.
Clearing silver-cinnabar webs of snails,
Gathering moss-covered steles of grass and stone.

I long to wield the oak-branch brush,
To inscribe the jade palace’s chronicle.

In the nineteenth year of Kaiyuan under Illustrious August,
On the twenty-first day of mid-autumn,
A specially dispatched envoy of earnest devotion
Renewed the temple of visitation and inquiry.
Tracing its origins,
He laid its true foundation.

The Zhaoyang Treasure Precinct—
Golden echoes startled the waking dream;
The Divine Empyrean Heavenly Lord—
Jade steeds bore him home as dawn neared.
Within the Numinous Talisman Palace,
At early court he leaned on his desk to address the ministers;
Before the Hanyuan Hall,
Cloud-cranes wheeled in the sky, illuminating the eight directions.

A thousand banners, ten thousand pennants—
Rainbow standards and phoenix canopies unfurled in crystalline mist;
Three crowns, nine streamers—
Wind-horses and cloud-chariots scattered flower-rain.
The Five Hundred Pearl Clerks of Supreme Clarity
Grasped the Azure Dragon’s tally of martial oversight;
The Four-Six Jade Immortals of Grand Tenuity
Held the Golden Tiger’s seal of flying clouds.

Twelve Stream Maidens rode jade turtles and mounted golden whales;
Eighteen River Spirits guided brocade dragons and sat on emerald conches.
The Three Officials wielded registers,
Collating the charts of heaven, earth, mountains, and seas;
The Six Dings brandished halberds,
Guarding the records of sun, moon, and stars.

To the left, the Dharma-Protecting Abbey; to the right, the Law-Guarding Hall—
Frost-crossed blades of gold and iron;
Before, flying Liaos; behind, extending essences—
Sun-glinting tusked banners.
The Four Marshals flourished their batons,
Driving the hosts of Thunder Lords and Lightning Mothers;
The Five Peaks unfurled their standards,
Rousing the ranks of Wind Earls and Rain Masters.

The Nine Provinces’ Community Lords bore the books of altars and city gods;
The Eight Seas’ Dragon Lords presented the canons of dragons, serpents, fish, and turtles.
The Registrar of Destiny flanked the imperial carriage,
Attending the forbidden chariot.
Flutes and drums resounded in the void—
Nine suites of the Celestial Hook’s coiffed maidens;
Reed pipes and jade flutes, kingfisher plumes—
The third watch of the palace’s sinking clepsydra.

Wind carried the pipa’s notes—
Palace maidens leaned by hibiscus, straining to hear;
Dew chilled the chestnut’s rustle—
Immortal consorts danced with peonies, offering toasts.
Drifting mists and rosy clouds
Composed melodies beyond the strange and dark;
Faintly, the imperial sash’s tassels—
Voices carried before the kingfisher canopies.

Compared to ascending the Great Clarity’s Primal Heaven,
To receive the kalpa from the Five Numinous Emperors in person—
The Elder stabilizes Shu,
The Dark Mandate governs its unfolding.

Here, at the northwest corner of Kanglu,
I establish the Court of the Nine Heavens’ Investigation.
After seventeen generations,
The valley’s slaughter will be profound;
Within a day or two,
The foundation’s nanmu will be set.

chunks.original_text: 但须斤斧，庸治宫墙。 斜察万灵，签书四府。 应阴六元一之运，司阳九百六之经。 言将讫而昊岑善丹青，事尚新而李玼#7入竹帛。 麟舆倏已去，扬驭不可追。 一念感通，千官瞻礼。 今浔阳刺史独人连军群僚而营创祠坛，遣神都道士孟仙真凡五人而焚修香火。 不雨而暴涨，运水神作殿之材； 正昼而反风，移地主所居之屋。 粉垩丹绿，掘地而寻□ ； 砖瓦石泥，非人而至。 仙灯夜现，众真隐约於阴霾； 楮襁晓飞，万鬼往来於野渡。 木像入庙而流汗，粉楹外地以发光。 龙跳朱楼，楼影高浮云影乱； 鸳铺翠瓦，瓦痕玲织月痕花。 期岁工夫梧叶秋，万邦香火莲花会。 梯山航海，无远不来； 星烛云坛，迄今尤盛。 江淮贡金贝，人如织而日如梭； 闽浙走香花，袂成帷而汗成雨。 再瞻仙躅，适当圣治之峰前； 爰相案山，远及薪黄之界外。 负仙鹤冲天之势，对游鱼上水之形。 自艮临震属贪狼，正天医玉兔之位； 折巽归乾入姑洗，乃鹑首金龙之乡。 霜剑铁狮，更蜿蜓於西嗽； 香炉石鼎，并盘确於东峰。 控御两三州，环望数百里。 天宝为庙而升元为府，太平改观而宣和改宫。 虽亘古以昭灵，亦历代而沿革。 太宗登大宝，新翠辈玉釜之荣； 真庙握元图，特紫札金牌之赐。 粤从兴国，春秋责两醮於守臣； 逮至政和，位号已三登於玉册。 祥符降镯税之令，天禧赐度牒之恩。 月破御香三百斤，岁设国醮五六会。 金虹玉牒，荐有宠光； 凤画奎文，益增镂志。 铭昌鼎算，腾景瑶京。 星使护船，玉鬣盘花枝而现瑞； 皇华投币，彩云带华盖以呜鞭。 元丰束师获铜钱於土缶，神宗明诏上宝号於金庭。 四字相符，一时咸异。 建炎戮张遇，显龙马於碧空； 开禧域昊曦，奏犬羊於紫阙。 炳灵愈焕，降祉弥繁。 盖玉虚朱帝之尊，亦金阙赤皇之化。 灵姿妙粹，秉太元碧琳之圭； 瑞相端妍，衣九光红霄之被。 丹盈羽调，琼华碧簪。 冠偃月金晨之冠，履天风朱光之履。 曳玉铢之袂，服海岳之裳。 五印凝丹，一剑横素。 分景作玉炼火帝，化形为南上真君。 其为炎极之皇，或直太阳之政。 巡游三界，监御万真。 初皇之九龙，中皇之九都，下皇之元都，化为使者； 黄帝之真元，尧帝之元一，舜帝之太一，皆乃真形。 夏禹朝谓苍水之神，周穆世日天灵之使。 ．唐朝肇迹，宋代隆禧。 琪木晨光，撷五枝於秀愕； 珠宫夕照，搴八桂於飞梁。 高云举读洞经於钱塘，亲承降顾； 龚庆长板名籍於向氏，备谕威灵。 昊大和而增丹膜之光，唐保大而茸黝赤之弊。 中厄兵焰，半为草墟。 运星锤月斧之劳，复烟桶霞甍之胜。 内而方丈，外以三门。 轮奂峥嵘，金碧绚烂。 三官殿、四圣殿，辅弼正宫，道纪堂、抱一堂，掩映虚室。 山光轩与擢秀轩而争爽，朱陵阁共景阳阁以相高。 宝藏储经，开天上图书之府； 华庭申福，灿人问箕翼之踱。 榜扁云无心，泉呜人听雨。 雨廊彩壁，绘绛衣碧弁之灵； 四面粉墙，闭紫木黄芝之茂。 仓院粟红而贯朽，库堂茶绿而水香。 崇凛齐山，河伯转轮而春谷； 香厨蒸雾，原夫妪饭以担薪。 霞被星冠，万指之张颐待哺； 月坛风峙，几代之栖仙宅灵。 面乎覆船山，背彼飞云洞。 门外古石，树为刘仙之亭； 官后峨单； 聿建灵泽之庙。 道院十九所，居呜琴啸剑之流；
chunks.translated_text:
Only axes and adzes were needed—
common labor sufficed for palace walls.
Slanting his gaze across the myriad spirits,
he signed decrees for the Four Ministries.
Attending to the yin cycle of the Six Primes’ unity,
overseeing the yang canon of the Nine Hundred and Six.
As his words neared their end, Mount Hao’s cinnabar cliffs gleamed bright;
while affairs were still fresh, Li Qi’s bamboo slips recorded them in history.

The unicorn chariot departed in a flash—
its soaring reins could not be pursued.
A single thought bridged the numinous,
and a thousand officials bowed in reverence.

Now the Prefect of Xunyang, Du Renlian, along with his assembled officers,
erected a shrine and altar.
He dispatched five Daoist priests from the Divine Capital—Meng Xianzhen and others—
to tend the incense and flames.
Though no rain fell, the waters surged violently,
as the River Spirit delivered timber for the hall;
though it was broad daylight, the winds reversed,
moving the Earth Lord’s dwelling to make way.

Whitewash and cinnabar, green and vermilion—
digging revealed hidden treasures;
bricks, tiles, stone, and mud—
arrived without human hands.
At night, immortal lamps appeared,
and the host of perfected ones flickered through the gloom;
at dawn, paper money took flight,
while myriad ghosts came and went at the riverside ford.

The wooden statue entered the temple and began to sweat;
the painted pillars cast light upon the earth.
Dragons leapt upon vermilion towers—
the tower’s shadow soared high, mingling with the clouds’;
mandarin ducks perched upon emerald tiles—
the tiles’ patterns shimmered like moonlight on woven flowers.

A year’s labor, like the autumn of wutong leaves,
and the ten thousand states gathered for the Lotus Assembly of incense and flame.
Climbing mountains, crossing seas—
no distance was too far;
starlight illuminated the cloud-altar—
to this day, its splendor endures.

From the Jiang-Huai region, tribute of gold and cowries—
people wove like shuttle-threads through the days;
from Min and Zhe, offerings of fragrant flowers—
sleeves formed curtains, sweat fell like rain.

Gazing again at the immortal’s footprints,
they stood before the peak of sagely governance;
surveying the case-mountain’s alignment,
they reached beyond the borders of firewood and mulberry.

Assuming the soaring momentum of a crane taking flight,
facing the form of fish ascending the stream.
From *Gen* bordering *Zhen*, governed by Greedy Wolf,
aligned with the Celestial Healer and Jade Hare’s position;
turning from *Xun* to *Qian*, entering *Guxi*,
it became the Land of the Quail’s Head and Golden Dragon.

Frost-edged swords and iron lions
coiled sinuously along the western ridge;
incense burners and stone tripods
clustered ruggedly upon the eastern peak.
Commanding two or three prefectures,
encompassing a view of hundreds of miles.

In the Tianbao era, it was a temple—
in the Shengyuan era, a prefecture;
in the Taiping era, it was renovated—
in the Xuanhe era, it became a palace.
Though its numinous radiance spanned antiquity,
its forms evolved through successive dynasties.

When Taizong ascended the great treasure,
he renewed its jade cauldrons and emerald splendor;
when the True Emperor grasped the Yuan Diagram,
he bestowed purple writs and golden tablets.
From the Xingguo era onward,
spring and autumn sacrifices were demanded of the local governors;
by the Zhenghe era,
its titles had been inscribed thrice in the Jade Register.

In the Xiangfu era, tax exemptions were decreed;
in the Tianxi era, ordination certificates were granted as grace.
Each month, three hundred catties of imperial incense were broken;
each year, five or six state rituals were held.
Golden rainbows and jade tablets
enhanced its favored radiance;
phoenix-script and stellar patterns
deepened its engraved renown.

Its inscriptions flourished like tripods’ longevity,
its light soared to the jade capital.
Star envoys guarded the ships—
jade-maned dragons coiled upon flowering branches in auspicious display;
imperial messengers offered tribute—
rainbow clouds bore canopies as whips cracked.

In the Yuanfeng era, troops unearthed copper coins from an earthen jar;
Emperor Shenzong issued a decree to bestow a sacred title in the Golden Court.
Four characters aligned in harmony—
all marveled at once.
In the Jianyan era, Zhang Yu was executed—
a dragon-horse appeared in the azure sky;
in the Kaixi era, Hao Xi was besieged—
a memorial of dogs and sheep was presented at the Purple Palace.

Its numinous brilliance grew ever more resplendent,
its blessings more abundant.
For it was the august presence of the Jade Void’s Vermilion Emperor,
the transformation of the Golden Portal’s Crimson Sovereign.
Its divine form, wondrous and pure,
held the jade scepter of the Great Primal Azure;
its auspicious countenance, flawless and fair,
wore the nine-hued radiance of the Red Empyrean’s mantle.

Cinnabar filled its feathered raiment,
jade and crystal adorned its hairpins.
Its crown was the crescent-moon diadem of the Golden Dawn;
its shoes, the vermilion-lustered boots of the Heavenly Wind.
Trailing robes of jade-thread,
clad in the vestments of sea and mountain.
Five seals congealed in cinnabar,
a single sword lay across the white silk.

Splitting its radiance, it became the Fire Emperor of Jade Refinement;
shifting its form, it became the True Lord of the Southern Summit.
As the Sovereign of the Blazing Pole,
or the direct minister of the Great Yang’s governance,
it patrolled the Three Realms,
overseeing the myriad perfected.

The Nine Dragons of the Primordial Emperor,
the Nine Capitals of the Median Emperor,
the Primal Capital of the Lower Emperor—
all became its envoys;
the True Primal of the Yellow Emperor,
the Primal Unity of Emperor Yao,
the Great Unity of Emperor Shun—
all were its true forms.

Yu of Xia’s court called it the Spirit of the Azure Waters;
the world of Zhou Mu knew it as the Celestial Numinous Envoy.
In the Tang, its traces began;
in the Song, its glory flourished.
Dawn light from gem-trees,
plucking five branches from the towering peaks;
evening glow from pearl palaces,
gathering eight cassia boughs from the flying bridge.

High clouds lifted the *Dongjing* scriptures at Qiantang,
where it deigned to descend in person;
Gong Qingchang inscribed its name in the registers of the Xiang family,
recounting its awe-inspiring power.

In the Huo Taihe era, it deepened the glow of cinnabar membranes;
in the Tang Baoda era, it repaired the blackened decay of its halls.
Midway, besieged by the flames of war,
half lay in ruins.
Through the labor of star-hammers and moon-axes,
it restored the smoke-wreathed eaves and misty rooftops.

Within, a square furlong;
without, three gates.
Magnificent and towering,
adorned in gold and azure splendor.

The Hall of the Three Officials,
the Hall of the Four Saints—
flanking the central palace;
the Hall of Daoist Discipline,
the Hall of Embracing Unity—
shimmering beside the empty chambers.

The Mountain Light Pavilion vied in freshness with the Towering Elegance Pavilion;
the Vermilion Mound Pavilion rivaled the height of the Sunset Glow Pavilion.
Treasuries stored scriptures—
opening the celestial library of maps and texts;
the Flowery Court extended blessings—
illuminating the human realm’s Dipper and Wings.

The inscribed plaque read *Clouds Without Intent*;
the spring murmured like rain heard by men.
Rainbow corridors and painted walls
depicted the numinous in crimson robes and azure caps;
on all four sides, powdered walls
enclosed the lush growth of purple woods and yellow mushrooms.

Granaries held grain until it rotted in strings;
storehouses held tea until its water turned fragrant.
The Revered and Majestic Mountain—
the River Earl turned its wheel to winnow spring grain;
the Fragrant Kitchen steamed mist—
the old woman who cooked rice also gathered firewood.

Caps adorned with rosy clouds,
ten thousand fingers opened mouths awaiting food;
the Moon Altar stood in the wind—
for generations, it had been the dwelling of immortals and spirits.

Facing the Overturned Boat Mountain,
backing the Flying Cloud Grotto.
Outside the gates, ancient stones
were carved into the Pavilion of Immortal Liu;
behind the palace, the lofty peak
became the Temple of Numinous Grace.

Nineteen Daoist abbeys—
home to those who plucked zithers, whistled, and wielded swords...

Faintly, the imperial sash’s tassels—
Voices carried before the kingfisher canopies.

Compared to ascending the Great Clarity’s Primal Heaven,
To receive the kalpa from the Five Numinous Emperors in person—
The Elder stabilizes Shu,
The Dark Mandate governs its unfolding.

Here, at the northwest corner of Kanglu,
I establish the Court of the Nine Heavens’ Investigation.
After seventeen generations,
The valley’s slaughter will be profound;
Within a day or two,
The foundation’s nanmu will be set.
