chunks.original_text: 官癣三五问，延秣马脂车之客。 碧流达舍，绿藓封谐。 天籁一呜，山呜谷应； 风竽才动，水动烟寒。 万枝红女媚芳塘，千丈苍官迎古路。 真神仙之窟宅，况泉石之膏盲。 素瀑紫岩，侧援星江之地； 白苹红寥，再游谧浦之时。 朝家太平兴国之宫。 为侍从奉祠之所； 真君应元保运之号，乃圣明褥典之封。 古今几何年，曾未镌翠泯之字？ 奢乳一小子，诅可赋白云之篇？ 有命奚辞，聊诗以记… 九疑真人元夷君，笑骑玉龙飞紫云。 手持五帝伏魔印，霓旌羽仗朝太清。 亲受混元皇帝劫，浮驾万鹤下红尘。 芝饼一憩仙韶响，千骑屯空驱火铃。 昭阳官中夜月丽，楼殿帘幕风泠泠。 明皇梦裹与神遇，乃知九天使者名。 浚晨辈出明光殿，宣谕百辟闻且惊。 玉殿再设香花席，羽盖琼轮泛杳冥。 忽聆青乌呜一声，举首天际瞻群真。 风雷震吼云气腾，麟车凤驾森不呜。 三十六官散天花，千官罗拜如云崩。 开元天子一稽首，翠葆深守语如纶。 传言太上爱黎庶，遣使廉访游八弦。 九天九地万品汇，尽我掌握令枯荣。 庐山西北地可庙，千岁之下崇香灯。 言终奄忽入空碧，诏遣独孤老守臣。 殷勤天使捧金币，营建宫庙福生灵。 一夜无风水自溢，千章和梓飘山根。 市妖运斧山灵奔，明年秋风咚落成。 万家共结莲花会，龙楼凤阁插天星。 寥寥五百春桃花，落花流水洞天春。 我来灶相九顿首，神霄故吏问山人。 为言圣宋启仙祚，五朝明主增宠荣。 历年春秋国一醮，宸昼光灿龙凤形。 顷年逆寇忘国恩，仙台亲控苍龙兵。 神通变化不可测，万民阴受雨露均。 金镂赐牌铭景既，宝岌朝凝瑞雪馨。 彤霞肃驾骑北斗，飘忽虚极嬉蓬瀛。 白鹤青鸾杳不归，博山香穗一缕青。 清都绛阙渺无际，醉拍玉栏呼雷霆。 九霄真皇分万化，景飞台举夜吹笙。 圣主焕文耀层汉，镂玉填金藏翠京。 国朝鸿烈等天地，充塞天地涵鱼鸢。 小诗何足纪盛事，聊歌丕德光林泉。 持蠡酌水归去来，一枕清风千万年。 授墨堂记 浔阳乃天下江山眉目之地，庐山盖仙灵咏真洞天虎溪福地也。 尝闻之，晋锺离权栖隐於山中欤，唐吕洞宾过山中，遇锺离，获刀圭之传，后与之俱仙矣。 绍圣问，轮困子杜旷着《 冲真先生胡公遇仙传》 。 胡公则太平兴国宫道士也，宫则九天采访之司也，居庐山之阴。 凡圣同居，隐显莫测。 胡公讳用综，昔为山中道正时，有道人姓回，冠华阳青销之巾，衣开元崇玄之服，垂飞云玄缣之绅，蹑寒雪素丝之履，美须眉，丰脸腴，绿鬓而隆准，碧眼而方颐，气宇昂昂，风神灿灿，过宫中，莫有延之者。 独胡公款以杯茗，既而语笑自若，乃指壶而点胸，索酒以待酌，一壶不竭，百杯有余，由昕而夕，饮不知醉。 复欲邀胡公饮于邸，筹新糖，脍小鲜。 胡公辞以日暮，而回道人乃掀髯长笑去矣。 宫之距城有一舍之遥。 翌日，胡公谒郡候，款城关尚未启钥，道人又自城而出，笑与胡相顾而去。 合吏云：子夜回道人已此候门久之。 胡公心亦异其人矣。 后数年，弊衫破帽，革带麻缰，自称大宋客，扣胡公之幽院，自肩二酒逞。 示胡，皆黄白之物。 取碎银以斋酒绘。 饮至日映，以铁刀剔土，沥残酒漱津，和土成墨。 掷之几上，铮然有声。 胡公醉卧胡床，而客拂袖不知所之。
chunks.translated_text:
Three or five officials scratched their scabies in inquiry,
welcoming guests with foddered horses and greased carriages.
Azure streams reached the lodges,
green moss sealed the harmonies.
A single celestial note sounded—
mountains echoed, valleys responded;
the wind’s panpipes stirred—
waters rippled, mists chilled.
A thousand red-clad maidens charmed the fragrant pond,
a hundred-zhang verdant lord greeted the ancient path.
Truly the cavern-dwelling of gods and immortals—
how much more the fertile blindness of springs and stones.

White cascades on purple crags,
clinging to the starry river’s land;
white duckweed and red reeds,
revisiting the tranquil shore’s hour.
The Palace of Great Peace and Prosperous Nation—
a place for attendants to serve the altars;
the title "True Lord Responding to Destiny, Preserving Fortune"—
a bestowal of sagely and luminous imperial favor.

How many years have passed?
Yet no jade-green moss has effaced the inscriptions.
A single pampered youth—
how could he compose a rhapsody on white clouds?
Since the command brooks no refusal,
I offer these verses in record...

The Perfected of Mount Jiuyi, Lord Yuan Yi,
laughing as he rides a jade dragon through purple clouds.
In hand, the Five Emperors’ Demon-Quelling Seal,
rainbow banners and feathered retinues pay homage to the Great Clarity.
Personally receiving the Primordial August Emperor’s kalpa,
he descends to the red dust on a thousand cranes.
Resting with a mushroom cake, the immortal music resounds;
a thousand riders mass in the sky, driving fire bells.

In the Zhaoyang Palace, the night moon gleams,
pavilions and curtains stir in the cold wind.
The Brilliant Emperor dreamed of an encounter with the divine—
thus learning the name of the Messenger of the Nine Heavens.
At dawn’s first light, he emerged from the Hall of Bright Light,
proclaiming the decree to the assembled lords, who listened in awe and astonishment.
A second time, the jade hall was arrayed with fragrant flowers,
feathered canopies and jade wheels drifted through the distant void.
Suddenly, a single cry of the azure bird—
all raised their heads to the heavens, gazing upon the host of perfected beings.
Wind and thunder roared, clouds surged,
unicorn chariots and phoenix carriages stood in silent majesty.
The thirty-six palaces scattered heavenly blossoms,
a thousand officials prostrated like crumbling clouds.

The Kaiyuan Emperor bowed once—
the jade parasols and deep guards spoke as if with silk threads.
The message: the Supreme Lord cherishes the common folk,
dispatching envoys to inspect and wander the eight extremities.
The myriad beings of the nine heavens and nine earths—
all within my grasp to command flourishing or withering.
"On the northwest of Mount Lu, a site for a temple—
a thousand years hence, let incense lamps be revered."
As the words ended, he vanished into the azure void,
leaving only the solitary old guardian to receive the decree.

The celestial envoy earnestly presented gold and silk,
building a palace to bless the living.
One night, windless, the waters rose of themselves;
a thousand catalpa and nanmu trees drifted to the mountain’s roots.
The market’s demons wielded axes, the mountain spirits hastened—
by the following autumn’s winds, the structure stood complete.
Ten thousand households joined the Lotus Assembly,
dragon towers and phoenix pavilions pierced the stars.

Five hundred springtimes of peach blossoms—
fallen flowers and flowing waters, the grotto-heaven’s spring.
I, the stove minister, kowtowed nine times,
the former clerk of Divine Empyrean inquiring of the mountain recluse.
He spoke of the sagely Song dynasty inaugurating immortal blessings,
five enlightened sovereigns augmenting honor and glory.
Each year, the state offered a grand libation—
the imperial day shone resplendent with dragon and phoenix forms.

In recent years, rebellious bandits forgot their national duty—
the immortal terrace personally commanded the Azure Dragon troops.
Divine transformations unfathomable,
the myriad people secretly received the even rain and dew.
A golden plaque inscribed with radiant scenes,
a jeweled censer congealed with fragrant auspicious snow.
Crimson clouds solemnly harnessed the Northern Dipper,
drifting through the void’s extremity, frolicking in Penglai’s isles.

White cranes and azure simurghs never returned,
only a wisp of incense smoke from the alchemical mountain.
The Azure Capital and Crimson Towers stretched boundless—
drunkenly slapping the jade balustrade, I called for thunder.
The True Sovereign of the Nine Empyreans divided myriad transformations,
the Terrace of Scenic Splendor raised, the night’s reed pipes played.
The sagely lord illuminated literature, dazzling the layered heavens,
carving jade and inlaying gold to store in the emerald capital.

The dynasty’s grand achievements equaled heaven and earth,
filling and saturating the cosmos, embracing fish and kites.
How could these humble verses record such magnificence?
I merely sing of mighty virtue to illuminate the groves and springs.
Holding a gourd to scoop water, I depart—
a single pillow of pure wind for ten thousand years.

*Record of the Hall of Bestowed Ink*

Xunyang is the world’s landscape’s brows and eyes,
Mount Lu the immortal’s chanting, perfected grotto-heaven, Tiger Creek’s blessed land.
I have heard that in the Jin dynasty, Zhongli Quan dwelled in reclusion upon the mountain,
and in the Tang, Lü Dongbin passed through the mountain, met Zhongli, and received the transmission of the elixir spoon—
later, they ascended together as immortals.

During the Shaosheng era, the wheel-bound Master Du Kuang composed *The Encounter with the Immortal: The Tale of Master Hu of the Primordial Perfected*.
Master Hu was a Daoist of the Palace of Great Peace and Prosperous Nation—
the palace being the Bureau of Inspection for the Nine Heavens,
residing on the northern slope of Mount Lu.
Saints and sages dwelled together,
concealment and manifestation unfathomable.

Master Hu’s name was Yongzong.
Once, when he served as the mountain’s Daoist overseer,
a Daoist named Hui arrived,
wearing a Huayang azure silk cap,
dressed in Kaiyuan-era Chongxuan robes,
a sash of flying-cloud dark damask,
shoes of winter-snow white silk,
handsome brows and beard, a plump face,
green temples and a high nose bridge,
blue eyes and a square jaw,
his bearing majestic, his spirit radiant.
He passed through the palace—
none invited him in.
Only Master Hu welcomed him with a cup of tea.
Thereafter, they conversed and laughed freely.
The Daoist pointed to his gourd and tapped his chest,
asking for wine to pour—
a single gourd never emptied,
a hundred cups still remained.
From dawn to dusk,
they drank without becoming drunk.
He then invited Master Hu to drink at his lodging,
preparing fresh sugar and minced delicacies.
Master Hu declined, citing the lateness of the hour,
whereupon the Daoist Hui lifted his beard in a long laugh and departed.

The palace lay a league from the city.
The next day, Master Hu paid a visit to the prefect,
but the city gates remained locked.
The Daoist Hui emerged from the city,
laughing as he exchanged glances with Master Hu before leaving.
The assembled officials said:
"At midnight, Daoist Hui had already waited at the gate for some time."
Master Hu’s heart marveled at the man.

Years later, clad in tattered robes and a broken hat,
a hemp belt and straw sandals,
he called himself a "guest of the Great Song,"
knocking at Master Hu’s secluded courtyard,
shouldering two jugs of wine.
He showed Master Hu—
both were yellow and white substances.
He took broken silver to buy wine and food.
They drank until the sun’s rays slanted,
then used an iron knife to scrape the earth,
draining the dregs to rinse his mouth,
mixing the soil into ink.
He cast it onto the table—
it rang with a clear sound.
Master Hu, drunk, reclined on his couch,
while the guest brushed his sleeves and vanished.

chunks.original_text: 满室异香，弥日馥郁。 其刀皆金色，人争市之。 乃以墨研酒而饵其半，宿疾顿苏。 胡公年及七旬，颜貌如处子，酒量不臧，八仙诚异遇矣。 若夫大宋二字，切音乃洞字也，二场者吕字也，所称客者宾也，则吕洞宾之相遇明矣。 胡公由是渐厌人间，一日一留诗蜕形而去，向之酝墨之地忽涌泉五支。 左丞王公案过之，为名墨仙泉。 侍郎宋公伯友与左丞皆有墨仙酬唱之什，有绿膏换得朱颜回，白发不用黄精拂之句。 太尉谯国曹公勋、清虚真人皇甫坦，采其事实以闻于德寿殿，高宗甚嗟异之。 胡公之居，先曰遇仙堂，改为授墨，重楼复屋，瑞气葱葱。 古井寒泉，四时莹碧。 奇哉，庐山异事也。 故为之书，将以补仙史之遗云。 地主祠堂记 陈氏原乎高卒，其派如流泉。 汉曲逆候佐沛公王关中，卒成相业。 自兹世代煌煌，子孙灿灿，阳而侯封，阴而庙食者代有人焉。 昔由颖阳徙居闽粤者甚族。 古无诸郡梅川侯姓陈，晋代人也，庙于南山李花林，尝逊地以为仙源洞宫。 古武荣郡莆田侯姓陈，亦晋代人也，庙于壶山风亭驿，亦逊地以为清源洞宫。 有如富沙之盖竹侯、临漳之灵着侯，皆陈族也。 名山大川，陈氏血食者，莫知其几。 唐庙隐君陈其姓，莫知其名，或曰讳伯宣者，晦迩康山，注《 史记》 以行天下。 诏征不起，就拜着作佐郎，家儒世仕。 既居圣治峰之前，开元问明皇夜宿昭阳，晓御灵光，凡两睹九天采访使者之相，面承圣训，使就庐山西北之隅，委江州守臣独孤正树庙，敕差孟仙真等五人奉香火。 先是，救黄未下，隙无人知。 一旦，有峨星曳霞者诣陈门曰：混元皇帝遣元夷苍水使者，持九麾五灵之节，廉访九天九地生死枯荣之籍。 今天子亲诣使者，欲於庐山建九天御史之台，五百年后福被黎庶。 吾以尔所居瑶壑葬月，玉渊影天，真胜处也。 宜捐厥地而基其庙欤。 尔他日换世，当为台属，使尔司是山而庙食矣。 陈既诺，道士出门，恍失所在。 后忽迅雷烈风移所居于宫左，即其址以为祠焉。 祠既落成，陈亦羽解，遂得世为此方地主矣。 厥后移居德安县之常乐里，久而又分派于丁山之别业，两被国朝义门旌表之命，遂以宫左故庐为地主香火之地。 国庙改祠为宫，而陈氏亦有跨鳖者一登瀛者、握兰者、入翰苑老坐钓台者。 弦诵琅琅，簪佩锵锵，阀阅堂堂，旌谛皇皇，盛哉盛哉。 其耳孙陈琢，控青亮，策黄鹄，委宫门直岁道士向德新市复楠，价陶涎，彻而鼎之，塑神像十尊，缔神宇六问，两重门，两过道，翠桶凝烟，朱廊浸月。 檐铎风而递响，灯宠昼而长焰。 花博织地，瑛础生苔。

The chamber filled with an extraordinary fragrance, rich and lingering for days. The knife turned golden in hue, and people rushed to purchase it. He ground the ink with wine and consumed half of it, whereupon his long-standing ailments vanished at once. Master Hu, though nearing seventy, bore the complexion of a maiden, and his capacity for wine remained boundless—truly an extraordinary encounter with the Eight Immortals.

As for the two characters "Great Song," when pronounced swiftly, they form the word *Dong*; the two scenes (*er chang*) compose the character *Lü*; and the "guest" (*ke*) signifies "guest" (*bin*). Thus, the meeting with Lü Dongbin becomes clear.

From that time onward, Master Hu gradually wearied of the mortal world. One day, he left behind a poem and shed his earthly form, departing. Where once he had mixed ink, five springs suddenly welled forth. Left Minister Wang, passing by, named it *Ink Immortal Spring*. Vice Minister Song Bofu and the Left Minister both composed verses in response, with lines such as:

*"Green ointment exchanged for a youthful face returned,
White hair needs no yellow essence to brush away."*

Grand Preceptor Cao Xun of Qiao Commandery and the Perfected Man of Pure Emptiness, Huangfu Tan, reported these events to the Hall of Virtuous Longevity, where Emperor Gaozong marveled deeply at them.

Master Hu’s former residence, once called *Hall of the Encounter with Immortals*, was renamed *Ink Bestowal Hall*. Its storied pavilions and layered eaves teemed with an auspicious aura. An ancient well and cold spring gleamed jade-green in all seasons. Wondrous indeed—the strange affair of Mount Lu! Thus, it is recorded here to supplement the annals of immortals.

---

**Record of the Local Deity’s Ancestral Hall**

The Chen clan traces its origins to the lofty Gao, its branches flowing like a spring. The Marquis of Qu Ni assisted the Duke of Pei in pacifying the Guanzhong region, ultimately achieving the office of Chancellor. From then on, their generations flourished, their descendants shining brightly, ennobled in life and venerated in death through ancestral halls for generations.

In ancient times, a branch of the clan migrated from Yingyang to Fujian and Guangdong, becoming a great lineage. The Marquis of Meichuan, surnamed Chen, was a man of the Jin dynasty, with his temple established in the Plum Blossom Forest of South Mountain. He once ceded land to form the Grotto Palace of Immortal Origins. The Marquis of Putian in the ancient Wurong Commandery, also surnamed Chen and of the Jin dynasty, had his temple at the Phoenix Pavilion Post in Hu Mountain, likewise ceding land to establish the Grotto Palace of Pure Origins. Others, such as the Marquis of Gaizhu in Fusha and the Spiritually Manifest Marquis of Linzhang, were also of the Chen clan. The number of their ancestral halls in famous mountains and great rivers is beyond reckoning.

During the Tang dynasty, the Reclusive Lord of the Temple, surnamed Chen (his given name unknown, though some say it was Boshi), lived in seclusion on Kang Mountain, annotating the *Records of the Grand Historian* and circulating it throughout the world. Though summoned by imperial decree, he refused to appear, and was later appointed Gentleman for Literary Composition. His family produced scholars and officials for generations. After settling before the Peak of Sagely Rule, during the Kaiyuan era, Emperor Minghuang once spent the night at Zhaoyang Palace. At dawn, he ascended the Hall of Numinous Radiance and twice beheld the envoys of the Nine Heavens’ Inspectors. Receiving the emperor’s decree, he instructed the Chen family to establish a temple in the northwest corner of Mount Lu, entrusting the prefect of Jiangzhou, Du Gu Zhengshu, with its oversight. Five individuals, including Meng Xianzhen, were appointed to tend its incense and flame.

Before this, the site had been neglected, unknown to all. One day, a figure robed in starry splendor and trailing rosy clouds arrived at Chen’s gate, declaring: *"The Primordial August Emperor has dispatched Yuan Yi, Envoy of the Azure Waters, bearing the banner of the Nine Standards and Five Spirits, to inspect the registers of life and death, withering and flourishing across the Nine Heavens and Nine Earths. Today, the Son of Heaven has personally sought the envoy’s counsel, desiring to build the Terrace of the Nine Heavens’ Censor on Mount Lu, that its blessings may extend to the common people five hundred years hence. I deem your dwelling—a jade ravine cradling the moon, a celestial abyss mirroring the sky—a truly sublime site. You should cede this land to lay the temple’s foundation. In your next life, you shall serve as an attendant of the terrace, presiding over this mountain and receiving offerings in perpetuity."*

Chen assented. The Daoist left, vanishing in an instant. Later, a sudden thunderclap and violent wind relocated Chen’s dwelling to the left of the palace, where its site became the temple. After its completion, Chen shed his mortal form and became the eternal local deity of this place.

Thereafter, his descendants moved to Changle Village in De’an County. Over time, they branched out to a separate estate on Ding Mountain, twice receiving the imperial commendation of *Righteous Household* during our dynasty. Thus, the former residence to the left of the palace became the site of the local deity’s incense and flame.

The state temple was later renamed a palace, and among the Chen clan, some rode turtles to ascend the isles of immortals, others plucked orchids, entered the Hanlin Academy, or aged by the fishing platform. The sound of recitation rang clear, the jingle of hairpins and girdle ornaments resounded, their gates and halls stood grandly, and their banners and inscriptions shone resplendently—magnificent indeed!

Their descendant Chen Zhuo, riding a blue steed and spurring a yellow crane, entrusted the annual duties of the palace gate to the Daoist Xiang Dexin. He gathered funds, casting them into a cauldron to mold ten divine statues and construct a six-bay temple hall with two gates and two passageways. Green eaves congealed with mist, vermilion corridors bathed in moonlight. Wind chimes beneath the eaves echoed in succession, while lamps shone brightly even at noon. Flowers wove a brocade across the earth, and jade foundations bore moss.

chunks.original_text: 宝帐垂轩，玉炉袅屋。 金碧烂目，朱紫惊人。 气焰威灵，俨若解语。 聪明正直，自古而今。 此盖前监宫事束溪杜道枢有以启陈琢也。 昔逍遥山金公避地以逊许旌阳，桐梧山孙公避地以逊葛太极，与夫闽中二陈之所以逊地为洞宫者，其与康山陈隐君一也。 隐君虽亡如存，万古一灵，其必能炼九乾六坤之铋，采三震四兑之汞，修成飞化之道，不为清灵之魂，则其去仙不远，尚何神哉？ 夫神者，《 易》 日：大而不可测之谓神。 《 阴符经》 日：不神而神所以神。 《 化书》 又日：万神一神也。 隐君苟能神，其神，则可以蹑元夷之域，登元始之乡，而与采访真君同一喘息，共一室庐，岂区区庙食而可以滞吾隐君也哉？ 隐君神人也。 其敢以告。 重建地主祠记 真君奉使采访，即庐山而驻节，记之者昭昭矣。 若夫地主陈公舍宅以为官，本末尤神。 夷考旧闻，自皇灵昼见於开元，天子择所妥灵事严，未有以称旨。 圣治之麓，隐君子陈公家焉，佳山水也。 】 日，方士款门，以迁巢为公讽，公欣然，顾不难於迁而揆力，未逮乃风霆夜骇，屋庐无挠，诂旦，尽室已南徙矣。 於是神职效珍，子来毕瘁，因溪阜为塘洫，架云霓於栋宇。 由庙而府，府而观，观而宫，真馆日增，异境亦日广有，非人谋所及。 原夫宏规伟制，虽云地辟天开，要皆公胸中之丘壑也。 人之情私户牖者，不知有藩墙之外，不忍其身之不宴，则皇恤乎异代之戚休。 今公捐世守之业，以为生灵请命，割吾庐之爱，以开后五百年黎庶之福，高识迈往，谊盘薄云。 使争席野老见之，能无魄汗？ 是足主兹山，与宫之香火相为久长矣。 岁在旗蒙大渊献，道院以兵毁，殃及于主祠。 事定载茸，其明年落成。 管辖宫事周得一、副知官事周承源＇请记其废兴。 余闻之，公自徙家，素传而世次莫考，好事者往往以谱疆附于公，独古碑有知宫事吕至信刻初降像，而以事击之，日：今乾步是也。 世以．为余族焉。 兵火屡更，家无完牒，不敢效崇韬祖汾阳以为公羞。 虽然，公之贤，虽微吾祖，犹应记之，况吕碑之传如许哉？ 於是乎书。 太岁丁丑至元十四年上元日，山之民石碉陈有宗记。 山泉居士昊蒙题盖。 重建地主祠祝版 至元十· 三年，岁次丙子，三月丙寅朔，初三日戊辰。 住持官事兼领管辖周得一、副知官事周承源、监临同主管宫事伍永怀、与宫门知事道众等，敢昭告于恩府：地主陈公，感应大王，惟神夙有仙苗，毓灵圣世，采访分司庐山，开治玉趾，亲临日； 舍此地当获灵佑。 言毕隐去。
chunks.translated_text:
Canopied jewel-enshrined curtains draped the pavilions, jade censers wafted fragrance through the halls. Gold and azure dazzled the eye, vermilion and purple startled the beholder. The radiance of their majestic power seemed as though they could speak, so keen and upright were they—unchanged from ancient times to the present.

This was all initiated by Du Daoshu of Shuxi, former supervisor of the palace. In former times, Master Jin of Xiaoyao Mountain had yielded his dwelling to Xu Jingsun in retreat; Master Sun of Tongwu Mountain had yielded his dwelling to Ge Taiji; and the two Chens of Min had likewise ceded their land to establish a grotto-palace. In this, the Recluse Chen of Kang Mountain was no different. Though the Recluse has passed, his spirit endures through the ages. Surely he could refine the lead of the nine heavens and six earths, gather the mercury of the three shocks and four marshlands, and cultivate the Dao of flight and transformation. If he does not become a pure and numinous soul, then his ascent to immortality is not far—how could he be merely a god?

For the term "god," the *Book of Changes* states: "That which is vast and unfathomable is called *shen* (spirit)." The *Classic of the Unseen Correspondence* says: "It is not spirit, yet its spirit is what makes it spirit." The *Book of Transformation* further states: "The myriad spirits are one spirit." If the Recluse can attain this spirit, then he may tread the realm of Yuan Yi, ascend the homeland of Yuan Shi, and share the same breath and dwelling as the Perfected Lord of Visitation—how could mere temple offerings confine such a Recluse? The Recluse is a divine being. This is my humble declaration.

---

**Record of the Reconstruction of the Local Deity’s Shrine**

When the Perfected Lord was dispatched on his visitation mission, he stationed his banner at Mount Lu—this is well-documented. Yet the origins of the local deity, Master Chen, who donated his residence to establish the palace, are even more divine.

Tracing ancient accounts: since the imperial numen manifested in broad daylight during the Kaiyuan era, the Son of Heaven sought a fitting place to honor the spirits, but none met his approval. At the foot of the sacred mountain, the Recluse Chen had made his home—a land of fine mountains and waters. One day, a fangshi knocked at his gate, subtly suggesting he relocate. Chen assented without hesitation, and though his strength was insufficient, that very night a storm raged like thunder, yet his house stood unshaken. At dawn, his entire household had already moved south. Thus, the divine office bestowed treasures, and laborers flocked to toil. They channeled the streams to form ponds, raised beams like clouds and rainbows. From shrine to mansion, mansion to abbey, abbey to palace, the halls of the Perfected multiplied daily, and wondrous realms expanded beyond human design.

In truth, though this grand vision may seem as though heaven and earth had opened it, it was all conceived within the Recluse’s own mind. Ordinary people, confined to their doors and windows, know nothing beyond their walls. Unable to bear their own discomfort, how could they care for the welfare of future generations? Yet the Recluse relinquished his ancestral estate to plead for the lives of the people, sacrificing his beloved home to secure blessings for the next five hundred years. His lofty vision and noble resolve soar beyond the clouds. If even rustic elders were to witness this, could they not but be struck with awe? He is truly worthy to preside over this mountain, and his incense fire shall endure as long as the palace’s.

In the year *qimeng* of the *Dayuanxian* cycle, the Daoist abbey was destroyed by war, and the calamity extended to the deity’s shrine. Once order was restored, reconstruction began, and the following year, it was completed. Zhou Deyi, supervisor of the palace, and Zhou Chengyuan, deputy director, requested a record of its rise and fall.

I have heard that since the Recluse moved his family, his lineage has been passed down without clear records. Those fond of such matters often append genealogies to his name, but only an ancient stele, inscribed by Lü Zhixin (supervisor of the palace), depicts the first descent of the image. The inscription notes: "This is the present *qianbu*." Later generations have claimed him as part of my clan. Yet wars and fires have repeatedly ravaged our family, leaving no intact records. I dare not presume to exalt him as the Duke of Fengyang, but even without my ancestors’ testimony, the Recluse’s virtue should still be recorded—how much more so with Lü’s stele as evidence? Thus, I write this.

On the fifteenth day of the first lunar month in the fourteenth year of the Zhiyuan era of the *Dingchou* year, recorded by Chen Youzong, a mountain dweller of Shidian. The colophon was inscribed by Wu Meng, the Mountain Spring Recluse.

---

**Prayer Tablet for the Reconstruction of the Local Deity’s Shrine**

In the thirteenth year of the Zhiyuan era, the year *bingzi*, on the third day of the third lunar month (the day *wuchen* of the first month), the following were respectfully announced to the Enlightened Prefecture and the Great King of Manifest Response, the Local Deity Chen:

The Perfected Lord, dispatched to inspect Mount Lu, arrived in person and declared: "By yielding this land, you shall receive divine protection." With these words, he vanished.

Presiding over the palace: Zhou Deyi, supervisor and overseer; Zhou Chengyuan, deputy director; Wu Yonghuai, co-supervisor and manager; along with the gatekeepers and the Daoist assembly.

chunks.original_text: 雷电宵驰，不惊春寐乱神运厥居山之南际，庙食一方，遐迩福被。 自唐而宋，越五百撰。 建炎寇江，阳九厄至，宫庭灰烬，草莱填翳。 随即中兴，扶颠起废，畚筑撒新，香火如故。 南渡于今，几更祠宇，朝谒耕繁，繁神之助。 岂谓乙亥祠又延毁。 大数将期，非神不枯。 地覆天翻，其毒太苦，仓库荡然，束乎无措，粒食不继，命悬一缕。 百孔千创，非昔年比。 旧通未偿，新债又举。 朝夕靡遑，妥灵无所。 辄不自揣，奋空撑挂。 幸藉檀那慨然乐施，经营新庙，还复旧址。 将次落成，悉资神护，涓日惟良，适逢修楔，敌牲丑酒，敬醉元誓。 少长咸集，庆安神位。 幸摄化於十方，俾库帑之丰裕。 簪褐聚居而吁和，主佃相依而安堵。 茂衍香花，敢忘神赐？ 尚飨。
chunks.translated_text:
Amidst the nocturnal rush of thunder and lightning, the spring slumber remained undisturbed, and the divine workings of the deity’s abode at the southern foothills continued unbroken. Here, the shrine received its due offerings, and blessings extended near and far. From the Tang through the Song, five hundred years passed in succession. Yet when the Jianyan rebels surged along the river and the *yang*-nine calamity struck, the palace halls were reduced to ashes, and weeds choked the ruins.

Soon after, the dynasty revived, restoring what had collapsed and reviving what had been abandoned. Baskets and trowels renewed the shrine, and incense and flame returned as before. Since the Southern Crossing, the temple halls have been rebuilt time and again, their morning rites as constant as the plow’s labor—all through the deity’s aid.

Who could have foreseen that in the year *yihai*, the shrine would again suffer ruin? The appointed time drew near, and without the deity’s power, all would wither. Heaven and earth upended, the suffering grew unbearable: granaries lay empty, all means exhausted, grain scarce, lives hanging by a thread. A hundred wounds, a thousand gashes—far beyond the trials of years past. Old debts remained unpaid, and new ones mounted. Day and night, there was no respite, no place to honor the divine presence.

Undeterred by our own inadequacy, we resolved to prop up the void with empty hands. By good fortune, the *dānapati* generously offered their joyful alms, and the new shrine took shape, restored to its former site. As completion nears, we rely wholly on the deity’s protection. On this auspicious day, coinciding with the Spring Purification, we present oxen, sheep, and wine, reverently fulfilling our original vow. Young and old gather as one to celebrate the deity’s settled abode.

May the deity’s transformative power extend to the ten directions, filling the treasuries to abundance. May the tonsured and the laity dwell together in harmony, and landlords and tenants live in mutual peace. May incense and flowers flourish—how could we forget the deity’s gifts? Partake, O Spirit, and accept our offering.

chunks.original_text: 维至元十六年，太岁己卯七月丙午朔，，初六日辛亥，通妙冲真大师、江州路道教都提点管辖诸宫观太平兴国宫都监住持· 宫事周得一、明素凝和大师、江州路道录提举诸宫观知太平兴国宫事周承源，名不道大师、江州路道判、太平兴国宫副知宫事刘宗传，与宫门知事道众等，敢昭告于恩府。 地生陈公，感应大王。 惟神秉灵此山，垂佑宫庭。 ．远来近悦，福被民生。 圣元革命，祠宇变更。 度材改筑，五载落成。 美哉轮奂，炳然丹青。 殿陛整肃，门径辟平。 规模宏远，莫之与京。 悉自神化，於人岂能，日#8吉时良，揭虔妥灵。 邻茗牲酝，于豆于登。 洋乎如在，昭鉴微诚。 真灵香火，协赞中兴。 簪褐聚居，各保安宁。 疵疠聿消，仓库充盈。 岁时祀事，敢忘报称。 尚飨。 九天采讨真君行宫记 善言天道者，至自然而止。 然其监曰天监，眷白天眷，视听秩讨，惟天之归之。 无为而无不为，无言而无不言，其自然者，固体用兼该，不过行其所无事耳。 古人知其然，故奉若其道，克享其心，参赞其化育，近续其休命。 若诿曰天道远，不可致诰，付之悠邈，以为自然，焉恶可？ 黄帝、尧、舜垂衣裳而天下治，与天为一矣。 至其下民必清问，岳牧必褊咨，明目而达聪，黜幽而陆明，何尝一日而忘天下？ 迨德下｛哀，犹有人主，耳目之宫惧其不广，且於内外着廉察之员，而后遐方绝域，莫逃於万里之门。 见此采访之宫，所以自天启之，而行宫之设尤人事之不可忽也。 真君自开元瑞应于圣治之麓，得陈氏故居以宅厥灵。 於是浔阳郭有西坡之屦、万寿之观。 专浅原之，白腾昆仑。 瓖溪之升龙、紫阳，皆祠之分达者。 殊庭珍馆，相望於江上矣。 非顾为是多事也，祠称采访，是为上苍监临之司，则幽遐必褊烛，淑慝必精别，将使采访之下任司牧之寄者，无负於惠养，承流宣化者，无负於抚字，为人臣子者，尽事君之忠，事亲之孝以无负於覆载。 庶可对越，以兔於戾。 否则，昭昭在上，毫发无爽，休咎将於是乎分，其敢不敬？
chunks.translated_text:
In the sixteenth year of the Zhiyuan era, the cyclical year *jimao*, on the first day of the seventh month, *bingwu*, and the sixth day, *xinhai*, the Venerable Master Tongmiao Chongzhen, Commissioner of Daoist Affairs for Jiangzhou Prefecture and Supervisor of All Palaces and Observatories, along with the Abbot of Taiping Xingguo Palace, Zhou Deyi; the Venerable Master Mingsu Ninghe, Registrar of Daoist Affairs for Jiangzhou Prefecture and Director of Taiping Xingguo Palace, Zhou Chengyuan; the Venerable Master Mingbudao, Vice-Director of Jiangzhou Prefecture and Deputy Director of Taiping Xingguo Palace, Liu Zongchuan; and the gatekeepers, administrators, and Daoist assembly of the palace, now reverently proclaim to the Enlightened Court:

Lord Chen of the Earth, the Great King of Manifest Response—
The deity, bearing numinous power upon this mountain, has long bestowed protection upon the palace halls. From afar and near, all rejoice, and blessings extend to the people’s livelihood. Since the sacred revolution of the Shengyuan era, the ancestral shrine has undergone transformations. With measured timber and rebuilt structures, completion was achieved after five years. How splendid the soaring halls, resplendent in vermilion and azure! The steps and terraces stand solemn, the gates and paths laid smooth. The scale is vast and unmatched—none can rival it. All this arises from the deity’s transformation; how could mere mortals achieve it?

On this auspicious day and hour, we reverently install the deity’s presence. With fragrant tea, sacrificial beasts, and fine wine, we present offerings in vessels of wood and bronze. May the deity, present as if in person, witness our humble sincerity. May the true spirit’s incense and flame aid the revival of the Dao. May the tonsured and the laity dwell together in peace, each safeguarding their well-being. May pestilence vanish and granaries overflow. ---

**Record of the Traveling Palace of the Perfected Lord of the Nine Heavens’ Investigative Authority**

Those who speak well of the Way of Heaven stop at spontaneity. Yet its oversight is called "Heaven’s Surveillance," its regard "Heaven’s Favor," its perception and judgment "Heaven’s Order." What Heaven returns to is this: non-action yet nothing left undone, silence yet nothing left unsaid. Spontaneity, in truth, encompasses both substance and function—it merely acts without contrivance.

The ancients understood this and revered the Way, aligning their hearts with it, assisting in its nurturing transformations, and perpetuating its blessed mandate. If one were to dismiss the Way of Heaven as distant and unattainable, consigning it to remoteness and calling it mere spontaneity, how could this be right?

The Yellow Emperor and the sage-kings Yao and Shun governed the world with ease, becoming one with Heaven. Yet they never ceased inquiring of the common people, consulting the feudal lords, sharpening their vision and hearing, banishing obscurity and illuminating clarity. How could they have forgotten the world for even a day?

When virtue declined, rulers still feared their ears and eyes were insufficiently broad. Thus, they appointed inspectors within and without, so that even distant frontiers could not escape the gates of oversight. This Investigative Palace, then, is Heaven’s own institution, and the establishment of traveling palaces is a matter of human affairs that cannot be neglected.

The Perfected Lord first manifested auspicious signs at the foot of Mount Shengzhi during the Kaiyuan era, taking residence in the former abode of the Chen clan. Thereafter, in the outskirts of Xunyang, arose the Western Slope Hermitage and the Temple of Longevity. From the shallow shoals of Zhuan to the soaring Kunlun, from the Dragon’s Ascent of Bao Creek to the Purple Yang, all were extensions of the Lord’s shrines. Along the river, rare halls and precious pavilions stood in succession.

This is not mere busyness. The shrine is called "Investigative," for it serves as Heaven’s supervisory office. The hidden and remote must be illuminated, good and evil meticulously distinguished. Thus, those entrusted with governance under the Investigative Authority must not fail in their duty of benevolent nurture; those who propagate the teachings must not fail in their care for the people. As subjects and children, they must fulfill their loyalty to rulers and filial piety to parents, lest they betray the covering and bearing of Heaven. Only then may they face the divine and avoid transgression.

Otherwise, with Heaven’s luminous gaze above, not even a hair’s breadth escapes scrutiny. Fortune and misfortune are decided here—how dare we not revere?

The significance of this Daoist institution far surpasses that of ordinary temples and incense offerings. Reflecting upon the twin-zhong prefecture—though distant by a hundred li from the sagely governance—its sole branch shrine appears meager compared to those of other regions. The Zhou clan of Cui Lu stands as the foremost family of the prefecture. Among them, Zhou Shu, styled Gongshu, is himself a paragon of the lineage. Having once suffered the ravages of war, his household was left with no survivors. Though he sought an heir far and wide, none was found.

He pondered: even those who fulfill the common duties of human relationships may lament that not all descendants are worthy. Should misfortune leave one without posterity, the choice of an heir must still prioritize virtue—yet such decisions often remain unresolved for years, difficult to settle. How much more so in my case, where upheaval has left me an impoverished elder, each day uncertain? To seek some infant merely to secure my own survival would be a grave miscalculation. All that my ancestors have painstakingly accumulated—every ounce and inch—would be cast aside lightly. How could my heart find solace in this?

I must inwardly examine my conscience: if my actions can be established before Heaven and Earth, attested to by spirits and gods, and thus align with the aspirations of my ancestors, then even if the matter bends to necessity, how dare I demand it fully conform to worldly conventions? Now, the Investigative Traveling Shrine remains an absent institution in our prefecture. I wish to expand its scope so that my family’s ancestral rites may rely upon the sacred incense of the divine, enduring without end—thus ensuring my ancestors are not left without support.

Having consulted with Zhou Deyi, Supervisor of the Taiping Xingguo Abbey affairs on Mount Lu, and Zhou Chengyuan, the Abbey’s Director and Daoist Registrar, I now pledge several qing of fields, along with the estate and its structures; several mu of land, where the ancestral graves lie. chunks.original_text: 岁自官庭分遗道倡之公清者以主之。 上可以效膑华祝，为作民父母之圣主，祈天永命； 次可以希风鲁颂，为辅世长民之贤臣，集福延年； 圣号所谓应元保运神化昭顺，此其证也； 又次可以为吾之高曾以下得听法闻经，超凡希圣之阶； 又次可以为吾邑井乡党得日修胜事，岁济丰登之便。 圣谶所谓五百年后福及生灵，又此其旨也。 吾祖父如有知焉，幽幽之中能不释然以慰，跃然以喜哉？ 闻者莫不称善，乃白之郡邑，给以书契，盖至元十三年六月日也。 储是年之租入为祠宇之创始。 未落成，公叔以疾终，得年七十有五。 先己自叔其颠末，遗言求记之者。 有宗未熟公叔而稔其事，乃为志其大盘，且志于众曰：舍宅之源，委既如右矣。 观其所自叔，则於祀祖先、资冥福护、丘陇之事，一编之中屡致意焉。 以继志述事之难其人，而托之方外之士，则受其托者良亦不轻。 一言之发，显幽临监，大其生也。 既以是属之其人，则其殁也，将以是请之於神，苟得请焉，则非受公叔之托，实膺上真之托矣。 重然诺者，其良图之图之如何？ 经纪必务於周密，委任必择於谨厚。 以住山甲乙之规，视周氏之宗杞，使其香火相继於无穷，则公叔为不死矣。 至元十七年清明日，石碉居士陈有宗记并书。 少中大夫江州路总管兼府尹鸦门杨仁风题盖。

Each year, officials shall appoint a Daoist of upright and pure conduct from the abbey to oversee its affairs. In the highest sense, this will allow the offering of splendid prayers to serve as the sagely lord and parent of the people, beseeching Heaven for an enduring mandate. Next, it will emulate the odes of Lu, aiding the worthy ministers who assist the age and guide the people, gathering blessings and prolonging years. The sacred title "Responsive to the Primordial, Guardian of Destiny, Divine Transformation Manifesting Harmony" serves as its proof. Further, it will provide a means for my ancestors from the generations of my great-grandfather onward to listen to the Dharma and hear the scriptures, ascending the steps from the mundane to the sagely. Still further, it will enable the villages and communities of my prefecture to daily cultivate meritorious deeds and annually secure abundant harvests. The sacred prophecy that "five hundred years hence, blessings shall extend to all living beings" likewise reflects this purpose. If my ancestors possess awareness, how could they not feel profound solace and exultant joy in the unseen realm?

All who heard this approved, and it was reported to the prefectural and county authorities, who issued written deeds. chunks.original_text: 太平兴国宫营造记 浔阳为江南重镇，庐阜为得阳名山，神禹之所尝登而刻石者，秦皇汉武亦皆纪功其上。 传记所载，班班可玫，它山盖不得拟也。 山中道释之庐不可缕数，而太平兴国宫独以九天采访真君宅灵异梦，一加显焉。 自唐开元帝感口奉备极，既命昊道子图写像貌，复命独孤正建立祠宇，神运之木随用随足，谈者以为异。 由唐而来，世代凡几更革，林谷凡几变迁，由府而观，由观而宫，虽或兴或废，而真君之灵则犹一日。 上之尊崇愈至，下之信向愈笃，又岂他神可得而拟哉？ 岁乙亥，国家混一六合，九江市不易肆，各得全生，而宫去城差远，不无过中之扰。 知宫事周得一、副宫事周承源慨然有感，人宫庭之毁剥，田园之荒芜，欲图缮茸而无其力。 左承吕公时开大府，亟以告焉，随助以凛粟，贷以耕牛，俾招集羽流，经理旧业，越三年，租入渐复，其故。 於是废者兴，仆者祖，殿堂廊麻，一时俱新。 湖邑有周公叔者，悉以其家产为香火之奉。 宫前之田，问有为豪家所据者，亦皆归疆。 由是宫计始裕，道众日增，钟磬日响，九重滨使，降香东西，行者莫不举乎加额。 比灵改观，神人咸悦。 是固二周君办一肯心之所致，而非吕公恻然于始，则二君何从致其力哉？ 在昔#11建炎初，宫尝毁矣。 道元大师周孚先实扫此而更新之。 今二君皆其近族后嗣，信於此山，有绿如此。 余行四方，每叹大事之壤烂颓废而不克振者，何可胜算？ 岂皆其势之不可为哉？
chunks.translated_text:
**Record of the Construction of Taiping Xingguo Abbey**

Xunyang stands as a key stronghold of Jiangnan, while Mount Lu is the famed mountain of Deyang. It was once ascended by the Great Yu, who carved his inscriptions upon its stone; the First Emperor of Qin and Emperor Wu of Han likewise commemorated their achievements there. The records of these events are clear and abundant—no other mountain can compare.

Within its peaks, the abodes of Daoists and Buddhists are too numerous to count, yet Taiping Xingguo Abbey alone has gained renown through the numinous dream of the Nine Heavens’ Inspector of Perfected Lords. Since the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, when the emperor received an oracular revelation and bestowed the utmost reverence, he commanded Wu Daozi to paint the deity’s likeness and ordered Du Guzheng to erect a shrine. Miraculously, the timber required for construction replenished itself as it was used—an event that struck all who heard of it as extraordinary.

From the Tang dynasty onward, through countless dynastic changes and the shifting of forests and valleys, the site has transformed from a prefectural temple to an abbey. Though it has known rise and decline, the numinosity of the Perfected Lord has endured unwaning. The higher its veneration has grown, the deeper the devotion of the people below—how could any other deity compare?

In the year *yihai*, as the realm was unified under one rule, the markets of Jiujiang thrived unaltered, and all lived in peace. Yet the abbey lay somewhat distant from the city, and its distance did not spare it from disturbances. The abbey’s overseer, Zhou Deyi, and his deputy, Zhou Chengyuan, were moved by sorrow at the sight of its ruined halls and overgrown fields. They longed to restore it but lacked the means.

At that time, Left Minister Lü Gongshi held high office. When they brought their plight to him, he promptly provided grain and lent oxen for plowing, enabling them to gather Daoist followers and revive the old estate. Within three years, the rent income gradually recovered. Thus, what had fallen was raised, what had collapsed was rebuilt, and halls, corridors, and chambers were all renewed at once.

There was a gentleman of Huxi named Zhou Shushu who devoted his entire family fortune to the upkeep of the sacred incense. Some of the abbey’s front fields had been seized by powerful families, but these too were reclaimed. From then on, the abbey’s resources grew abundant, its Daoist community expanded, and the sound of bells and chimes rang daily. When envoys from the ninefold court descended to offer incense from east and west, all who passed by raised their hands to their brows in reverence. The abbey’s transformation delighted both gods and men.

This was surely the result of the single-minded devotion of the two Zhou gentlemen. Yet had Minister Lü not shown compassion at the outset, how could they have accomplished such a feat?

In the early years of the Jianyan era, the abbey was once destroyed. The Great Master of the Dao, Zhou Fuxian, swept its ruins and restored it anew. The two gentlemen today are his close descendants, and their connection to this mountain runs deep. As I travel the four quarters, I often lament the countless grand undertakings that have crumbled into ruin, beyond hope of revival. Is it truly that their circumstances made restoration impossible?

chunks.original_text: 盖上下悠悠而无恻怛之念尔。 乃若潜山、青城，盖#12与真君同时着灵，而兵革之余，皆不复如旧，又安得不有感於斯。 余九年寄述有祷，未尝不孚，留滞未能即归故隐，岁率一至宫中，办香致敬。 二君俾记颠末，用不敢辞，姑为纪大略，俾来者考焉。 若夫土木凡用则不着。 至元十八年岁次辛巳，八月甲子，承直郎江南渍溪书院提学年镕撰拜书，嘉议大夫常德路总管、兼府尹李秉彝篆额。 太平宫新庄记 真君殿碑，盖龙兴据其所具而作。 及以疾归，留宫喻月，与身见而言传者或异，遂更订，而丹书之既入石矣，犹有一遗，其日始田履亩财及三千，今万有奇。 若合其旧为一而言，今则不然，皆冲靖真常凝妙法师汤君#13提点知宫，录江州路道教之后之致者，独万有一千。 其道有三… 日货取、曰施入、日力作。 余叹其用志之确，亲劳之多，无文以彰之世。

For the most part, those above and below drift heedlessly, without a thought of compassion. Consider Mount Qian and Mount Qingcheng—both, like the Perfected Lord, once manifested numinous power in the same era. Yet in the aftermath of war, neither has been restored to its former state. How could one not feel moved by this?

For nine years, my prayers in exile have never failed to find response. Though lingering delays have kept me from returning to my former retreat, I come to the abbey each year to prepare incense and pay my respects. When the two gentlemen asked me to record these events, I could not refuse. Here, then, is a brief account for future generations to consult. As for the mundane details of construction, they are not noted here.

This stele for the Hall of the Perfected Lord was composed based on the materials he provided. Later, when illness compelled his return, he remained at the abbey for a month. Some details, as told secondhand, differed from what he had witnessed himself, so corrections were made. Yet even after the inscription was carved in red and set into stone, one omission remained: originally, the fields measured no more than three thousand *mu*; now, they exceed ten thousand. chunks.original_text: 乌乎知为？ 目其诸庄与地在所，反其施入之主之名，自多衰之以及其寡，今最货取三千六百五十，惟石门千二百八十为多。 其不足是者，启石二百八十，锦溪七百五十，石塘九百一十，龙冈九百六十，上龙溪千二百三十。 惟启石居兴国大治，余皆江之德化。 最施人者五千三百五十，惟翠麓二千二百为多，高岸半之，元山千二百，万安千七百，福兴千七百四十，赵陈二千一百，惟高岸居兴国之永兴，元山居薪之黄梅，其故主则厉坚孙、项至大，余皆江之属县。 翠麓湖口、万安德安、福兴彭泽、赵陈瑞昌，其主周恕、胡荣、吕师山，则碑#14福州路同知者与齐永年。 云力作者，创四茗磴於德化县，曰义兴庄，凡四十有二盘，又垦田二千。 肇为五庵，官之前三，日东西太平与紫元，宫之后二，日涌翠、谷峰。 其始皆菅茅朴徽，众所薪牧之囿皆募人钱缚铨斧而出，高时松杉梧茗，皆摘实授子，畦而苗之，移置其地。 下种姜芋、之。 藷昔与水可尘稻者，皆令募人有其利不入公宫以劝夫未至者。 余闻之，肩舆历至其所而观焉。 经始久者方五年，近者一岁，而木之布列冈阜，薪者虽没草问而生意茁然，久者已离立如人，将数万举#15 。 其畦而未分，犹盈亩焉。 篁筱斩梢而不伤其鞭，畚故土取诸他山为个不可计，意者倍徒乎。 木笋已丛出其下，特未林耳。 君登高丘，指宫林以相语曰：闻之故耆#16之山始亦榛莽如是，吾所材而用之，皆基先民。 今荒山可芟治者犹或数里，天假吾年而为之不置，或得尽辟。 百年木皆连抱，可使后人资以治宫，亦吾於世生不虚也。 余曰：呜呼，君之所言，政古人所谓人弃我取，本富之要也。 边是为心，何事不可为，何功不可集？ 宜人之动荡鼓舞，割所爱惟惧施入之后。 不然，彼其家田，民赖以食其力者也，将以尺帛斗米遗之，犹恋掺移时，殉陶然收恩而后以授，况是连阡亘陌之田，直或千金‘，无所望报，弃之若鸿毛。 非有以服其心者能然耶？ 余惟久此，又闻其将大众之法。
chunks.translated_text:
Alas, how could one know? Let us survey the abbeys’ manors and their lands in their respective locations, and trace the names of those who made donations—from the most generous to the least. Now, the greatest income from commercial exchange amounts to three thousand six hundred and fifty *mu*, with Shimen alone contributing one thousand two hundred and eighty as the largest share. Those falling short of this are: Qishi, two hundred and eighty; Jinxī, seven hundred and fifty; Shitang, nine hundred and ten; Longgang, nine hundred and sixty; and Shanglongxī, one thousand two hundred and thirty. Of these, only Qishi lies in Xingguo’s Daye, while the rest belong to Jiang’s Dehua.

The most generous donors number five thousand three hundred and fifty, with Cuilu contributing two thousand two hundred as the largest. Gao’an follows with half that amount, Yuanshan with one thousand two hundred, Wan’an with one thousand seven hundred, Fuxing with one thousand seven hundred and forty, and Zhao Chen with two thousand one hundred. Of these, only Gao’an lies in Yongxing of Xingguo, and Yuanshan in Huangmei of Xin; their former patrons were Li Jiansun and Xiang Zhida. The rest belong to Jiang’s subordinate counties: Cuilu to Hukou, Wan’an to Dean, Fuxing to Pengze, and Zhao Chen to Ruichang. Their patrons—Zhou Shu, Hu Rong, and Lü Shishan—are the same as those recorded on the stele of the Assistant Prefect of Fuzhou Circuit, alongside Qi Yongnian.

As for manual labor, four tea terraces were opened in Dehua County, named Yixing Manor, comprising forty-two levels in all. Additionally, two thousand *mu* of fields were reclaimed. Five hermitages were first established: three before the abbey—East Taiping, West Taiping, and Ziyuan—and two behind—Yongcui and Gufeng. Initially, all were overgrown with reeds and brambles, grazing grounds for the common folk. Workers were hired to clear the land with axes and hoes, and from the heights, pines, cedars, parasol trees, and tea plants were gathered by seed and sapling, then transplanted in orderly rows. Ginger and taro were planted, along with yams and water chestnuts where rice could not grow. The profits from these were granted to the workers to encourage those who had not yet joined. Having heard of this, I traveled by sedan chair to see for myself. The earliest projects began five years ago, the most recent just a year past. Yet already, the trees spread across the hills, and though the undergrowth is dense, new life sprouts vigorously. The oldest trees now stand tall as men, soon to number in the tens of thousands. Those still in rows, undivided, fill the fields. Bamboo shoots are pruned without harming their roots, and baskets of soil, carried from other mountains, are beyond counting—doubly so, one might imagine. Beneath them, bamboo shoots already cluster, though the groves are not yet fully grown.

Master Tang ascended a high mound and pointed to the abbey’s groves, saying: “I have heard that the mountains of old were once as overgrown as this. The timber we use now was laid down by our predecessors. There are still several *li* of untamed mountains that could be cleared. If Heaven grants me years enough to persist, perhaps all may yet be opened. In a hundred years, the trees will grow thick as a man’s embrace, providing future generations with the means to maintain the abbey. Then my life in this world will not have been in vain.”

I replied: “Ah! Your words echo the ancient adage, ‘What others discard, I take’—the essence of true wealth. With such a heart, what task cannot be accomplished, what merit cannot be gathered? It is no wonder people are stirred to action, offering what they love, fearing only that their donations may come too late. Otherwise, those fields belong to their own households, on which the people depend for their livelihood. Even a foot of cloth or a peck of rice, given as alms, would be clung to for a time, accepted with reluctance and gratitude before parting. How much more so for fields stretching across *qian* and *mo*, worth perhaps a thousand gold, with no expectation of repayment, cast aside like goose down? Only one who has truly won their hearts could achieve this.”

Having dwelt on this for some time, I further learned of his plans to propagate the abbey’s teachings among the masses.

chunks.original_text: 道流非有故不入田民家。 民之入钱取薪炭山者，皆给之券。 恒遣力人持挺行逻林问，盗采者有罚。 钱谷入出，井井有稽，舂磨之细，不遗糠纥。 公官大庖，日炊米十斛，可食千人。 其徒皆就食宫堂，来必道氅以示不亵。 职官事者，各有子院，有釜鬲，不作饮食，惟待煮茗类水之须。 其僮奴之守舍，与诸庵远宫数里者，为饭皆日赋之。 子院不得设塑像，日一夕惟即瞻礼於宫。 余问其然，则曰：子院强则公宫弱，强日益富，则公宫日益不足。 不足势必下求子院，一则应，再而缓，三则柔者德之以色，刚者拒之以言。 上下之情，寝以离矣。 不若同甘共苦，以公官所凛养之为可恒也。 呜呼，他道流能远计若是乎？ 尝与一二知己私窃评之，白须娟砾，有熊豹之姿，已见其力足任事，加以沉深有谋，寡言而信，威而和，诚而恪，视数百人黄童白叟，约束如一，使不为老子法，用世而为将帅，可以进退三军，立功万里。 今顾为九江黄冠师，枯槁山林，已是也耶？ 因叔田及此。 君名德润，字季玉，号邮涧。 其左右君靡朝以夕，尽其劳绩，忠於其宫。 同成功者，中外四十九人，纪诸殿碑，可考而知。 尝观汉费凤、韩仁诸碑，书多不满石，或三之一，或半焉，而空其后。 岂待天嗣有所书耶？ 故今例之，亦法古之一也。

The Daoist followers never entered the homes of common folk without cause. Those who brought money to gather firewood or charcoal from the mountains were all issued vouchers. Regularly, strong laborers were dispatched to patrol the forests with staves, and those who stole timber were punished. The inflow and outflow of money and grain were meticulously recorded, and even the finest details of milling—down to the last husk—were not overlooked.

The great kitchen of the public abbey daily steamed ten *hu* of rice, enough to feed a thousand people. All its disciples took their meals in the main hall, arriving always in Daoist robes to show reverence. Those who held official duties each had their own subsidiary cloisters, equipped with cauldrons and tripods, though they prepared no meals themselves, only boiling water for tea as needed. For the young servants who guarded the lodgings and those in remote hermitages several *li* away, meals were distributed daily.

No painted or sculpted images were permitted in the subsidiary cloisters; each day at dusk, the residents would go to the main abbey to pay their respects. When I asked why this was so, they replied: "If the subsidiary cloisters grow strong, the public abbey weakens. As they daily accumulate wealth, the public abbey becomes increasingly impoverished. In its need, it will inevitably turn to the subsidiary cloisters for aid. The first request may be met, the second delayed, and by the third, the compliant may appease with kind words, while the unyielding will refuse outright. Thus, the bond between above and below gradually dissolves. Better to share both hardship and abundance, sustaining all through the public abbey’s resources—this is the only enduring way."

Alas! Could followers of other Daoist traditions plan so far ahead? Once, in private discussion with a few confidants, we assessed him: his white beard and piercing eyes gave him the bearing of a bear or leopard, revealing strength enough to shoulder great tasks. Combined with his depth of thought, strategic mind, trustworthiness despite few words, authority tempered by harmony, sincerity, and reverence—he governed hundreds of disciples, young and old alike, with uniform discipline. chunks.original_text: 杨泰明弃官学道于庐山 泰明为长安县令，本一儒生，事父母孝，时谓杨孝子。 尝佐郭子仪幕府，性恬静，不求仕进。 每劝子仪曰：军政虽曰尚严，人命至重，不可轻杀。 子仪掌兵二十余年，驭下宽厚，不妄诛戮，军士爱之如父兄，皆泰明阴赞之力。 永泰元年，弃官来庐山峰项结庵，造青精饭，服以辟谷，然相香祷于九天使者真王，求长生之道，积一十四年。 时当秋夕，天宇清霁，忽於朝礼之地，见神人金冠绛袍，白珠络缝，傍有一人执玉斧，一人捧玉函。 神人曰：我乃九天使者，采访人问善恶。 以汝积世有功於民，秉心清苦，精持道行，诚达九天，玉清太素三元君命我授汝《九天太真道经》。 泰明再拜伏地，叩首称谢。 徐启玉函，授以宝书，仍告戒日：始终精勤不替，道成之日，吾当召汝。 语讫，风云骤起，已失所在。 开经观之，乃《高上大洞真经》三十九章也。 泰朋从此依经行持，屏迹人世，凡三十六年。 至宪宗元和八年正月一日午时，祥云来迎，泰明乘云升举。 出《真仙感遇记》 李云乡医道有功 云卿，唐之隐士。 每云上真高仙，必须阴功济物，精持戒行，遂留心医道。 智识颖悟，凡用药不犯生命，止使金石草木，自以古仙制方传于后人。 其间有用虫鱼为药，绿此不得轻举，因k!为鉴戒，来居庐山。 数州求医者盈门，不受财帛之赠，绝欲断荤，所居近九天使者庙。 每旦焚香，祝日：云卿以医药救民疾苦，不务财利，尽未来世，永无退心。 神明灵通，必蒙加护。 凡居山六十余年，颜色黄润，目#1光射人，识者皆云阴德所致。 一日，因随采药人至探山中，忽睹一人圆冠紫袍，揖日：我此山之神也。 九天使者真王传命，以汝救物有功，使我授汝太清九华神丹，太微天帝君飞天呈步地纪金简玉字一通。 自此当屏迹人问，精意修持。 云卿再拜，告日：九天使者，不审云卿可得见否？ 神人日：汝秽气未除，未可见也。 方以手授神丹玉字之诀，其神已隐不见。 蕾买卿乃就圣治峰土穴为室，专修其道。 后唐同光二年八月一日白日升仙。 出《神药总录》 向子文遇龚庆长 子文，长沙人。 唐宝历二年，得官衡州，贫不能归，爱山水之胜。 一旦，谒岳庙时，当盛暑，留宿旬余。 忽有1人青布紫裘，面如琢玉，神色威整，须眉如画。 子文异其骨相，翌旦，往见问之。 乃日：余龚庆长也。 世家洛阳，少遇司马隐元于呜皋山下。 隐元者，自云委羽洞天之灵官也。 凡五岳、四渍、洞天福地，各有灵官主之，校量功罪，采访善恶，闻于九天使者之府。 隐元语庆长日：汝宿生常居要职，有辩冤雪死之劳。 当时士民阴受汝赐，逮朱沘僭逆，伏节死事，忠愤之气毅然不衰，故得再生为人，他时通悟，必能记忆矣。 九天使者录汝之功，命我授汝石精金光藏景录形神剑之法，中黄太一默朝之道，因得度世。 近登紫霄峰望气，见岭外妖气，，欲往禳除，经过岳 祠，故来朝谒。 子文为之致恭，庆长顾侍者取琴鼓之，其曲曰《金鲸跃海》、《雨滴秋荷》、《醉淘月》、《白雪引》之类。 音韵清越，非凡声也。 陪从数日，临别，子文再拜日：幸得际遇，欲从先生南游，可乎？ 庆长曰：未可也，汝尚当仕进，更十八年，中条山相见。

Yang Taiming resigned from office to study the Dao on Mount Lu. Taiming, originally a county magistrate of Chang’an, was a scholar by birth, filial to his parents, and was known as "Filial Yang." He once served in Guo Ziyi’s幕府, by nature serene and indifferent to official advancement. He often advised Ziyi, saying: "Though military governance values strictness, human life is of utmost weight—one must not kill lightly." Ziyi commanded troops for over twenty years, ruling with leniency and refraining from indiscriminate executions. His soldiers cherished him as a father or elder brother, all due to Taiming’s subtle counsel.

In the first year of Yongtai (765 CE), he resigned his post and came to the peaks of Mount Lu, where he built a hut. He prepared *qingjing* rice and consumed it to practice *bigu* (grain avoidance). Burning incense, he prayed to the Perfected King of the Nine Heavens’ Envoy, seeking the Dao of immortality. For fourteen years, he persisted. One autumn evening, the sky cleared after rain. Suddenly, at his place of morning worship, he saw a divine being in a golden crown and crimson robe, adorned with white pearl strands. Beside him stood one holding a jade axe and another bearing a jade casket.

The divine being said: "I am the Nine Heavens’ Envoy, sent to inspect human good and evil. For your lifelong merits toward the people, your pure and arduous heart, and your steadfast cultivation of the Dao, your sincerity has reached the Nine Heavens. The Three Primordial Lords of Jade Purity and Great Simplicity have commanded me to bestow upon you the *Scripture of the Great Perfected Dao of the Nine Heavens*." Taiming prostrated himself, kowtowing in gratitude. He slowly opened the jade casket and received the sacred text. The divine being admonished him, saying: "Persist in diligent practice without fail. On the day your Dao is perfected, I shall summon you." With these words, winds and clouds surged, and the divine being vanished. Upon opening the scripture, he found it to be the *Supreme Scripture of the Great Cavern*, in thirty-nine chapters.

From then on, Taiming followed the scripture’s practices, withdrawing from the world. For thirty-six years, he remained secluded. In the eighth year of Yuanhe (813 CE), on the first day of the first lunar month at noon, auspicious clouds descended to welcome him. Taiming ascended upon the clouds.

*From* Records of Encounters with Perfected Immortals

Li Yunxiang’s Merits in Medicine and the Dao
Yunxiang was a recluse of the Tang. He often said that lofty immortals and perfected beings must accumulate hidden merits to aid others and uphold precepts with precision. Thus, he devoted himself to medicine. Gifted with keen insight, he never harmed living creatures in his prescriptions, using only minerals, herbs, and plants. He transmitted ancient immortal formulas to later generations. When his methods required insects or fish as medicine, he refrained from hasty action, taking this as a caution. Later, he came to reside on Mount Lu.

Patients from several prefectures filled his door, yet he accepted no gifts of silk or wealth. He abstained from desires and meat, living near the Temple of the Nine Heavens’ Envoy. Each morning, he burned incense and prayed: "Yunxiang uses medicine to relieve the people’s suffering, seeking no profit. May I never waver in this resolve for all future lives. May the divine and numinous grant me protection." He lived on the mountain for over sixty years, his complexion golden and lustrous, his gaze piercing. Those who knew him attributed this to his hidden virtues.

One day, while following herb-gatherers into the depths of the mountains, he suddenly saw a man in a round cap and purple robe, his face like carved jade, his bearing majestic, his beard and brows as if painted. Yunxiang, struck by his extraordinary appearance, visited him the next morning and inquired. The man said: "I am Gong Qingchang. My family is from Luoyang. In my youth, I met Sima Yinyuan at the foot of Mount Minggao. Yinyuan claimed to be a spirit official of the Weiyu Grotto-Heaven. Each of the Five Peaks, Four Seas, and grotto-heavens has spirit officials who assess merits and transgressions, reporting good and evil to the Court of the Nine Heavens’ Envoy. Yinyuan told me: 'In a past life, you held an important post and labored to redress grievances and exonerate the wrongfully killed. The people silently benefited from you. When Zhu Ci usurped the throne, you died for loyalty, your righteous indignation unwavering. Thus, you were reborn as a human. In time, you will awaken and recall these memories.' The Nine Heavens’ Envoy recorded your merits and commanded me to transmit to you the methods of the *Stone Essence and Golden Light Concealing Form Sword*, the *Silent Audience of the Central Yellow Great One*, by which you may transcend the world. Recently, I ascended Purple Cloud Peak to observe the *qi*, and saw demonic vapors beyond the ridge. I intended to exorcise them but passed by the mountain shrine, so I came to pay respects."

Yunxiang treated him with reverence. Qingchang instructed his attendant to fetch a zither and played melodies such as *Golden Whale Leaping the Sea*, *Raindrops on Autumn Lotuses*, *Drunken Panning the Moon*, and *White Snow Prelude*. The tones were pure and transcendent, unlike ordinary sounds. After several days of companionship, at parting, Yunxiang bowed and said: "Fortunate to have met you, may I follow you on a southern journey?" Qingchang replied: "Not yet. You must still pursue an official career. In eighteen years, we shall meet at Mount Zhongtiao."

*From* Comprehensive Records of Divine Medicines

Xiang Ziwen’s Encounter with Gong Qingchang
Ziwen was from Changsha. In the second year of Baoli (826 CE), he was appointed to Hengzhou but was too poor to return home. Enamored of the scenic mountains and rivers, one day, during the height of summer, he visited the Yue Temple and stayed for over ten days. Suddenly, he saw a man in a black cloth robe lined with purple, his face like polished jade, his demeanor dignified, his beard and brows as if drawn. Ziwen marveled at his extraordinary appearance. The next morning, he visited and inquired. The man said: "I am Gong Qingchang. My family is from Luoyang. In my youth, I met Sima Yinyuan at the foot of Mount Minggao. Yinyuan claimed to be a spirit official of the Weiyu Grotto-Heaven. Each of the Five Peaks, Four Seas, and grotto-heavens has spirit officials who assess merits and transgressions, reporting good and evil to the Court of the Nine Heavens’ Envoy. Yinyuan told me: 'In a past life, you held an important post and labored to redress grievances and exonerate the wrongfully killed. The people silently benefited from you. When Zhu Ci usurped the throne, you died for loyalty, your righteous indignation unwavering. Thus, you were reborn as a human. In time, you will awaken and recall these memories.' The Nine Heavens’ Envoy recorded your merits and commanded me to transmit to you the *Stone Essence and Golden Light Concealing Form Sword*, the *Silent Audience of the Central Yellow Great One*, by which you may transcend the world. Recently, I ascended Purple Cloud Peak to observe the *qi* and saw demonic vapors beyond the ridge. I intended to exorcise them but passed by the mountain shrine, so I came to pay respects."

Ziwen treated him with reverence. Qingchang turned to his attendant, who fetched a zither and played melodies such as *Golden Whale Leaping the Sea*, *Raindrops on Autumn Lotuses*, *Drunken Panning the Moon*, and *White Snow Prelude*. The tones were pure and transcendent, unlike ordinary sounds. After several days of companionship, at parting, Ziwen bowed and said: "Fortunate to have met you, may I follow you on a southern journey?" Qingchang replied: "Not yet. You must still pursue an official career. In eighteen years, we shall meet at Mount Zhongtiao."

Ziwen bowed again, entreating instruction. Qingchang said: "To study the Dao, first cultivate merit and conduct. When you encounter the right time and fulfill your aspirations, you must strive diligently. As for breath cultivation and alchemical ingestion, these are secondary matters." Ziwen pleaded repeatedly, but Qingchang replied: "We must wait until our next meeting." Ziwen said: "If there is further teaching or admonition, I vow to uphold it." After a long silence, Qingchang said: "Your father and grandfather lie in temporary burial at a monastic abode, much afflicted by ghostly servitude. You should promptly select an auspicious site to complete this great matter." Ziwen wept and bowed in gratitude, then departed with light steps.

*From* The Southern Journey of Minister Li Wen

**Xu the Remonstrator Repairs the Temple with Private Funds**
The Remonstrator, appointed as Jiangxi Military Commissioner in the second year of the Dahe era of the Tang, used thirty thousand *min* of his own money to renovate the Lushan Temple of the Divine Envoy, commissioning artisans to apply cinnabar and bright pigments. The magistrate of Xunyang dispatched an official to oversee the work. The official entered the city to summon a painter, then returned with him, the artisan bearing pigments on his back. As they left the city gate, the official suddenly stripped off his robe and belt and cast them to the ground. The painter, suspecting drunkenness, retrieved them and followed. Soon after, the official discarded his clothes and hat. After traveling thirty *li*, he was barely clothed. Nearing the temple, a figure like a sturdy soldier, clad in black with a white leather apron, emerged from the ravine and seized the official, dragging him away. The painter cried out: "He is merely drunk—pardon him!" The soldier only glared, dragging the official to sit in the water. The painter then realized he was a ghost and fled in terror to alert those at the temple. When they returned together, the black-clad figure had vanished, and the official sat as before—dead. Upon reviewing the accounts, they found that half the funds had been embezzled.

*From* Remnants of the Taiping Era

**Liu Deben Donates Wealth to Relieve Famine**
Deben, styled Xiaoshu, was a native of Ezhou. Skilled in many arts and fond of antiquity, he sought no official position but traveled as a merchant on the great river. In the tenth month of the sixth year of the Qianfu era of the Tang, Huang Chao captured Ezhou, causing panic along the Yangtze. Judging himself unable to return home, Deben distributed ten thousand *shi* of grain to the starving poor and took refuge on Mount Lu. One day, a Daoist with disheveled hair and a deerskin robe visited, declining to give his name. They roamed the mountain together for a year. One day, wandering to the foot of the Five Elders Peak to admire the scenery, they lost track of time until dusk. Hand in hand, they entered a ravine and saw an old man leaning on a staff within a stone gate. Deben bowed and recounted his journey. The old man said joyfully: "Come with me to the rear courtyard." After walking four or five *li*, they saw a gate, resplendent in cinnabar and azure, inscribed in golden seal script: *Gate of Purple Radiance*. Upon entering, they beheld tiered pavilions and interconnected halls, guarded by stern sentinels. Deben trembled, not daring to lift his gaze. The old man said: "This is the Grotto-Heaven of Chanting Perfection. The True King, Envoy of the Nine Heavens, surveys the mortal realm. You have donated vast family wealth to relieve the starving—your virtuous deed is commendable, and thus you are permitted to visit this divine abode. Your name shall be inscribed in the *Register of Immortals of the Nine Heavens*, and you shall transcend death." Deben bowed again and asked: "Where does the True King, Envoy of the Nine Heavens, reside?" The old man replied: "You have been reborn four times in this human form, burdened by deep karmic obstructions from past lives. Your bone structure is not yet purified—such matters are not for you to inquire. You should strictly uphold precepts, clarify your spirit, aid others, benefit beings, and advance without slack. The True King perceives even the subtlest deeds; in time, he will surely grant you deliverance." Deben bowed in thanks, and the old man led him out the gate.

chunks.original_text: 未瑜闽之间，恍然不见，已还旧止。 德本问道者曰：老仙何人也？ 道者曰：即此洞天灵官，九天使者真王之隶也。 尔既曾造神宫，躬授严训，吾与汝请从此别。 遂揖而去。 出《洞大灵迩记》 张怀武阴功友物 唐天佑初，江西连帅南平王锺某遣道士沈太虚设醮于九天使者庙。 太虚醮罢，恍若梦见图像前一人揖日：吾张怀武也。 尝为军将，微有阴功及物，采访命我为灵官。 既寤，访怀武之名，无能知者。 归以语进士沈彬。 彬后二十年游醴陵，邑令陆君与客方食，有许军吏后至，语及张怀武。 彬问之，许日：怀武者，蔡之裨将，顷因甲辰年大饯，闻豫章独稔，即将部属奔焉。 既即路，两军稍不相能。 比#2至武昌，衅隙大作，克日将战，禁之不可。 ·怀武乃拔剑谓其徒曰：吾与汝今日之行，非有他图，直救性#3命。 尔奈何不忍小忿自相攻战。 失战，强者伤，弱者亡，如是，则何为去父母之国而死於道路耶？ 两军所以致争者，以有怀武故也。 今我为汝等死，两军亦无后艰矣。 遂自刎。 於是众皆恸哭，相与和亲，比及豫章，无死亡者。 出《张智官记》 王琳放生葬死 琳，京兆人。 唐大顺二年，任邢州尧山尉。 时方兵兴，死於血刃者甚众。 琳欢曰：无辜之民肝脑涂地，深可哀也。 遂舍家赀具棺椁。 数年之问，所葬不可数计。

Suddenly, the scene between Min and Yu faded away, and Deben found himself back at his original dwelling. He asked the Daoist: "Who was that old immortal?" The Daoist replied: "He is the Divine Officer of this Grotto-Heaven, a subordinate of the True King, Envoy of the Nine Heavens. Since you have already visited the divine palace and received his solemn instructions in person, I shall now take my leave of you." With that, he bowed and departed.

*From the* Record of the Great Divine Proximity

**Zhang Huaiwu’s Hidden Merit in Aiding Beings**
During the early Tianyou era of the Tang, Nanping Prince Zhong, the military governor of Jiangxi, dispatched the Daoist Shen Taixu to perform a jiao offering at the Temple of the Nine Heavens’ Envoy. After the rite, Taixu seemed to dream and saw a figure before the statue bow, saying: "I am Zhang Huaiwu. Once a military officer, I accrued slight hidden merit by aiding others, and the Celestial Envoy appointed me as a Divine Officer." Upon waking, he inquired about Zhang Huaiwu’s name, but none could provide an answer. Returning home, he recounted this to the scholar Shen Bin. Twenty years later, Bin traveled to Liling, where the county magistrate Lu and his guests were dining. A military clerk, Xu, arrived late and mentioned Zhang Huaiwu. Bin asked about him, and Xu replied: "Huaiwu was a deputy general under Cai. During the great famine of the jiachen year, he learned that Yuzhang alone had a good harvest and led his troops there. En route, tensions arose between the two armies. By the time they reached Wuchang, hostilities had escalated, and battle seemed imminent despite all attempts to stop it. Huaiwu then drew his sword and addressed his men: ‘Our journey today has no other purpose but to save lives. Why, then, do you allow petty grievances to drive you to mutual slaughter? If you fight, the strong will be wounded, the weak will perish—why abandon your homeland and die on the road?’ He continued: ‘The conflict exists because of me. Today, I shall die for you all, and the two armies will face no further hardship.’ With that, he slit his own throat. The soldiers wept bitterly, reconciled, and by the time they reached Yuzhang, none had perished."

*From the* Record of Divine Officer Zhang

**Wang Lin’s Release of Life and Burial of the Dead**
Lin was a native of Jingzhao. In the second year of Dashun of the Tang, he served as the magistrate of Yaoshan County in Xingzhou. Jixu, styled Daofu, was a native of Huangzhou. In the second year of the Tianxi reign, he served as registrar of Yanshi County in Henan Prefecture. Stricken with blindness, he resigned his post. Several months later, both eyes regained their sight. Moved by this miracle, Jixu observed the precepts and devoted himself to the Dao with even greater diligence. He lived to ninety-seven years of age. He composed *The Vow of Audience with the True* and *Rhapsody on Washing the Eyes with Divine Water*. Wen Biao, styled Zhongbing, was the son of a farming family from Dehua County in Jiangzhou. Diligent in study and profoundly filial, at sixteen he traveled to the Imperial Academy. In the seventh year of the Yuanfeng era, his father fell gravely ill. Biao hastened to the Hall of Visitation, prayed for leave to return home, then slit open his abdomen and excised his liver, from which he prepared twenty-four medicinal pellets. These he mixed with other herbs and administered to his father, whose illness immediately abated. When the prefecture and county learned of the matter, they sought to report it to the imperial court. Biao wept and said, “This is but the ordinary duty of a son—why make it known?” Thus his reputation grew even greater. His father lived another twenty-four years before passing away, the same number as the liver pellets. When Biao first cut out his liver, he mistakenly incised his right flank, whereupon he suddenly heard a voice from the void say, “It is on the left.” He swiftly withdrew the blade, then cut into his left side and obtained it. Blood flowed across the ground, and his spirit dimmed into darkness. In a daze, he saw a Daoist offer him a red bird to eat, and he revived. Later, Biao journeyed again to the capital but died en route. His family established a shrine beside the palace. Cai Songxi of Mount Song inscribed a poem:

*I hear that in those days he carved out his liver,*
*Ten thousand spirits in the Nine Heavens’ halls looked on.*
*The blood still stains the blade that plucked the blossom,*
*While the father, swallowing the medicine, rests at ease within.*
*His lofty conduct reached the ears of the Supreme Emperor,*
*Yet fine renown was never sought, nor high office.*
*Where has that peerless purity of jade now gone?*
*Surely to the Three Mountains, riding a rainbow phoenix.*

In the fifth year of the Qiandao era, Biao’s nephew Wen Jie likewise cut flesh from his thigh to cure his mother’s illness. At the time, Sima Zhibai composed *Records of the Filial Sons Wen*. From *Prefectural Gazetteer of Filial Conduct*

Gao Yunju Reads the *Great Cavern Scripture*

Yunju bowed deeply in reverence. The immortal asked, “Do you read this scripture—do you also comprehend its essence?” Yunju replied, “I have heard it is the exalted text of thirty-nine chapters. You must strive diligently.” Before the words were finished, he suddenly ascended into the void and vanished.

**Zhou Ju Receives the Ten-Character Scripture by Divine Transmission**

Zhou Ju was a native of Wu. In the first year of the Jianyan era, he returned to his hometown from the capital. At that time, false rebels and bandits arose on all sides. Suddenly, a figure in a star-crowned cap and feathered robes appeared, saying, “Tomorrow you will perish in the calamity of war. If you recite the Ten-Character Scripture, you may escape death, resolve grievances, and prolong your life.” Zhou knelt to the ground and entreated him. The feathered-robed one said, “The *Nine Heavens Responding to Primal Thunder, Universally Transforming Heavenly Worthy*—this is the Ten-Character Scripture.” Having bowed to receive it, Zhou looked up, but the figure had vanished. He suspected it was a divine transmission and steadfastly committed the words to memory.

The next day, he indeed encountered bandits who pursued him into the woods. In his distress and fear, he urgently recited the invocation. Before the sound had left his lips, thunder crashed violently. The bandits, terrified, fled, and he thus escaped disaster.

**Retreat of Zhang’s Bandits in the Jianyan Era**

In the winter of the first year of the Jianyan era, the rebel Zhang Yu gathered tens of thousands of followers, crossed the Huai River, and seized Chizhou. On the tenth day of the twelfth month, they advanced upon Jiangzhou. At the time, the prefect, Academician of the Dragon Diagram Pavilion and Grand Master for Court Audiences Chen Yanwen, donned armor himself, led the people, and ascended the city walls, vowing to defend to the death. The bandits besieged the city for three days, and the situation grew perilous. The people of the prefecture wailed and prayed, prostrating toward the mountains in supplication.

Suddenly, banners appeared above the clouds, and a halo of radiance spread across the fields. A true form emerged, seated upon a lion, resembling a dragon-horse, with an entourage of riders arrayed in the misty qi. The entire city beheld it. Moments later, a great snowfall began, and the bandits, unable to endure the open air, suffered heavy casualties. A thousand-strong cavalry unit entered the palace grounds, setting fires everywhere, yet even bamboo huts and paper curtains would not ignite. Glancing at the palace gates, they seemed to perceive something, and in panic, they fled.

After the bandits retreated, the prefect and the people of the prefecture held a thanksgiving jiao ritual for over a month. To this day, the scholars and commoners of Jiangcheng hold an assembly and perform a jiao ritual on the seventh day of the fourth month each year, a tradition originating from this event.

Hearing of your tireless reading of the *Cavern Scripture*, I came to observe. If you persist without ceasing, in time you will naturally attain its mysteries. You must strive diligently.” Before the words were finished, he suddenly ascended into the void and vanished.

chunks.original_text: 矢石交攻，将尽屠於生齿。 望琳宫而请命，罄丹捆以祈哀，威现旌幢，气成龙马，祥云四合，知神骑之护持。 大雪连朝，觉寇锋之潜挫。 恭惟道力，敢怠斋心。 式展冲科，庶酬洪造。 霓旌羽盖，愿暂降於丛霄； 风马云车，坤来临於洞府。 冀终大赐，永保群生。 每年四月上七，江城士庶建醮意旨。 伏为建炎年问，贼徒来犯九江，一城生灵将遭屠戮，彼时荷蒙九天采访真君云端垂佑，一郡生灵皆得更生。 自后合郡士庶恭诣福地，建醮谢恩。 迨于嘉定兵犯鄂城，祸连数郡之郊，势迫九江之境，民悬忧於近死，望泣真官，时举荷於生全，顿消妖视。 计恩瑜昔，思报何穷。 谨结会，修设谢恩清醮一百二十分位。 伏愿干戈永息，合境安宁。 次冀各家俱膺百福。
chunks.translated_text:
Amidst the crossfire of arrows and stones, the city’s people faced imminent slaughter. Gazing toward the Jade Palace, we pleaded for deliverance, exhausting our sincerest offerings in desperate supplication. Then, banners of divine might appeared, qi coalescing into dragon-horses, auspicious clouds gathering on all sides—we knew the numinous hosts had come to our defense. For days, heavy snow fell, and the enemy’s advance was silently broken. With reverence for the Dao’s power, how could we fail to purify our hearts? Now, in humble observance of the profound rites, we seek to repay this boundless grace.

May the rainbow banners and feathered canopies descend briefly from the celestial heights; may the wind-borne steeds and cloud chariots deign to visit this grotto-palace. We pray for the ultimate bestowal of blessings, that all living beings may be eternally preserved.

This is the purpose behind the annual assembly of Jiangcheng’s scholars and commoners, who perform the jiao ritual on the seventh day of the fourth month.

During the Jianyan era, when bandits invaded Jiujiang, the entire city’s populace teetered on the brink of massacre. At that time, the Nine Heavens’ Investigating Perfected Lord deigned to extend his protection from the clouds, granting the people of the prefecture a new lease on life. Thereafter, the scholars and commoners of the region reverently journeyed to this blessed site to perform the jiao ritual in thanksgiving.

Later, during the Jiading era, when war reached the outskirts of Ezhou and disaster spread across several prefectures, the crisis pressed upon Jiujiang’s borders. The people, fearing death’s approach, wept as they beseeched the Perfected Lords—only to witness their prayers answered with deliverance, the demonic forces instantly dispelled. Recalling past mercies, how could our gratitude ever be repaid?

Thus, we gather in assembly to conduct a grand thanksgiving jiao ritual of one hundred and twenty altar stations. We humbly pray that weapons of war may forever fall silent and the entire region enjoy enduring peace. May every household be blessed with a hundredfold prosperity.
chunks.overlap_context:
Jiao Ritual Address:**

The Vermilion Emperor of Jade Clarity, resplendent in numinous power, has long guarded this famed mountain. The True King of the Golden Portal, bestowing blessings, first established his foundation in this land of fortune. Such matters are known in ancient times, and the rites are revered in our present dynasty. Recently, the Huai bandits have run rampant, and violent rebels have raged with insolence. Advancing by both land and water, they sought to seize our river city.

chunks.original_text: 周氏沉溺木筏 瑞昌县居民周氏，以财雄乡里，多货卖江湖问。 绍兴三年，买上江杉木为大筏，其直十万余缙，将至建康遍售，命九江同姓人主之行有日矣。 同姓者诣庐山采访真君殿，次签词云：四顾那自一，抱疑有二心。 遂尔不能改，如何就没沉。 周其姓者谓业已办装，不肯止。 才至谧江门，果溺。 出《夷坚丙志》 开禧诛逆曦事 开禧二年十二月，四川宣抚副使兴州都统制吴曦叛。 三年正月十八日，僭号蜀王，遣伪将禄禧部兵守夔门，本路帅臣蒋介解印付之，禧二月十九日至夔。 介趋江而归，二十四日泊万州。 介之客有赵潭者，善降诸神。 是夕介命潭请梼卜其去就祸福。 所执箕笔迅动异常，忽大书云：昊曦世受国恩，敢谋僭叛，将降四蜀於左衽。 九天采访使者奏其事，上帝震怒，敕灭其族，事不出三月，秘之。 介惧泄神语召祸，缄封甚密。 三月初十日至忠州，逢露布，曦果以二月二十九日就诛。 介聚十数客拆缄，共赌惊叹。 万去兴州二千余里，神之降先，曦死盖五日。 异哉，是年季夏之四日，宣教郎四川宣抚使司干办公事、嘉定薛绂谨识。 见存石刻于本宫 钱方平神授运生章 方平，淮海人。 淳佑四年上元节，日渐停午，神情恍惚，伏几而睡。 梦一髦髻道人称曰：吾乃应元公也。 未及问答，探怀中出一幅纸，有文训。 方平读日：道迹辅玄化，云傲肃神尤。 清华洞灵岩，万境随周流。 翼翼会霞真，光灿平浮。 揖召帝子家，回象明飞轿。 变运举若此，邈尔不可求。 骞林动余荫，凤质难稽勾。 瑶药发栖香，禁阙舒神谋。 密简眷通翳，六运朝元游。 羽爽超劫轮，时而济虚柔，剥度昭六沉，积屿停山上。 琳叶滞宝鸾，察举成空幽。 霓节表佐见，侍相采良俦。 大哉混沌中，群息胜气投。 黄房宴马尊，九盖夺君伴。 转降尔至妙，开教当三楼。 子避复以命，王检停千秋。 诵毕，日：此《九天运生章》，子密记之，异日来太平宫访吾。 方平疾读，悉记，欲扣其原。 忽家人惊寤，当亦罔测。
